Scientists are just beginning to learn how these common tumors in women are linked to phthalates—chemicals found in hundreds of everyday household items and cosmetics. These chemicals have been linked to uterine fibroids—non-cancerous tumors ranging from the size of a seed to a soccer ball that grow in or around the uterus.

Photograph by Hannah Whitaker, Nat Geo Image Collection

Photo by @javier_aznar_photography | After several days of lying in the mud for hours as I tried to photograph shore birds, I was drawn to a group of fiddler crabs. I observed them communicating with a sequence of waves and gestures. 

Fiddler crabs are known for their sexually dimorphic claws—the females have two small claws, whereas the male (seen here) has a small and a large one, used to both attract females and threaten other males. The crabs play a key role in the preservation of wetland habitat, aerating the substrate as they burrow in. 

The photo was taken in Ecuador, on the shore of a mangrove, with the sun reflecting in the water at sunset. Follow @javier_aznar_photography to see more amazing creatures. #red #crab #fiddler #fiddlercrab #ecuador

Photo by @acacia.johnson | A mother polar bear and two cubs roam the hillside of Kapp Waldburg on Spitsbergen, Norway. Here in the remote Svalbard archipelago, polar bears can be found anywhere, scavenging for food on shore during the summer months when sea ice is less prevalent. These bears were leaving a colony of nesting black-legged kittiwakes, whose eggs could make a snack for the mother and cubs. Follow me at @acacia.johnson for more stories from the Arctic and beyond. #svalbard #polarbears #wildlife #arctic

Photo by @michaelchristopherbrown | A goat herder stands for a portrait near the town of Ngiko, just outside of Virunga National Park headquarters in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. The park is Africa’s most biodiverse protected area, home to over a thousand mammal, bird, reptile, and amphibian species as well as 1/3 of the world’s endangered mountain gorillas. Virunga is known as the park of fire and ice for its diverse habitats ranging from the Rwenzori peaks to savanna and volcanic plains. Despite its status, Virunga is constantly threatened by war, poaching and other illegal activities, and natural disasters. With the support of donors, the Virunga Foundation actively conserves the park, which spans over 3,000 square miles (7,800 sq km). Over 5 million people reside within a day’s walk of it, many living in extreme poverty and enduring more than 30 years of conflict. The fertile lands in and around Virunga are prime for agricultural exploitation. By preserving the land, many of the world’s poorest are forced to sacrifice opportunity. To tackle this social justice issue, with the support of the EU, Virunga National Park has founded an initiative to foster a locally-led "green" economy based on ecotourism, sustainable agriculture, and energy. Follow me @michaelchristopherbrown for more human stories from around the world.

Photo by Erika Larsen @erikalarsen888 | At Zoo Tampa, an all-female team led by Jaime Vaccaro treats injured and sick manatees—like this one—at the Manatee Critical Care Center, which has three 16,000-gallon medical treatment pools, two underwater pools, and a public observation area. Manatees are a keystone species whose behavior can alert us to environmental and habitat changes that affect our survival. These beautiful creatures are easy to love—attracting adults and kids alike—but recent die-offs show that if we are not alert, they can be gone in the blink of an eye.

Photo by Matthieu Paley @paleyphoto | Like many of my colleagues, I get often asked, “How do you become a National Geographic photographer?” My answer is often that you don’t “want" to be a National Geographic photographer; you just want to be a photographer who pursues a story like your life depends on it. That story must keep you up at night and make your heart beat faster. If you pursue it and work your craft, good things will invariably come. But it takes time—years. It’s not always easy, and aspiring photographers can be too impatient. 

This photograph is from a story I worked on and off for more than 15 years, in Afghanistan’s Wakhan Corridor. It had turned into an obsession, requiring multiple expeditions in every season, learning the language and the landscape, and dealing with stress and joy. The image was taken in 2017 in a high pasture in the Pamir mountains, reachable after a two-week-long expedition. Sidol (at left), Jumagul (center), and Assan Khan were returning on their yaks after monitoring the growth of grasses at lower elevations. Herds would be kept off that pasture so the grasses could be harvested, dried, and used by the Wakhi people for animal fodder in the winter months. I was talking on the satellite phone with my wife on a hill when I saw these beasts climbing up toward me. I had to hang up … and was forgiven! 

Read the story at the link in bio. For more insights into our world, please follow @paleyphoto.

An abundance of rain in California has set the stage for an epic “sea of flowers” this spring. Here’s how to see this increasingly rare phenomenon—responsibly.

Photograph by Justin Benttinen 
@natgeotravel

Photo by David Chancellor @chancellordavid | I remember as a child that "snow days" were simply unique. It was as if an extra day had been given to us all. I had the same feeling recently when I arose well before dawn to find the African bush blanketed in fog. It wasn't a reason to slip back under the duvet; rather, it was a gift. Imagine for a moment that all that has evolved to predate and to disappear from its prey's view now has the assistance of fog. Then things can get really interesting. To see more follow me @chancellordavid.
Photo by @tasneemalsultan | Al Balad, Jeddah’s historic center and a UNESCO World Heritage site, premiered a two-day music festival in December called Balad Beast. #jeddah #saudiarabia

Photo by Charlie Hamilton James @chamiltonjames | A mother sea otter holds her baby in the waters off California. From birth, this young pup will spend most of its life in the sea, only occasionally coming out onshore. That means its fur needs to be kept in tip-top condition. Mum does this at first and grooms her pup meticulously. Sea otters have the warmest fur of any animal, with up to a million hairs per square inch. They rely on it to keep warm, even in the freezing seas of Alaska, but it requires constant grooming. Historically, sea otters came close to extinction throughout much of the range because of fur trapping—their dense warm pelt being highly prized. But strict laws protecting them in the United States has helped rebuild their population. One of the biggest threats that sea otters face in the waters off California these days are great white sharks.

Photo by @jasperdoest | “Don’t eat too much,” says Grazia Cosmano, 102, and stick to fruits and vegetables. “Keep it as simple as possible.” That’s how Cosmano became one of an unusual concentration of centenarians in Italy’s Calabria region, says Valter Longo, a biochemist and director of the Longevity Institute at the University of Southern California. Longo, whose parents are from Cosmano’s hometown of Molochio, has known her since childhood. When she turned 100, he added her to his study of Calabria’s centenarians and their diet.

Thank you, Grazia, for your life lessons but, most important, for the joy and laughter. 

Read more at the link in bio and follow me @jasperdoest for more images about the science of longevity. #longevity #healthyaging #longevitydiet

Photo by @babaktafreshi | The National Geographic app opens with this image of the night sky above Utah's Capitol Reef National Park. Designated an International Dark Sky Park, it's indeed one of the darkest places I've visited for nighttime photography. Captured here under the Milky Way and the stars of the Summer Triangle is Capitol Gorge. It's a popular trail by day, but at night you're alone with the striking sounds of nocturnal species. My colleague and I used dim red light during the walk to preserve our night vision and to avoid disturbing animals. That's why in some national parks the light painting technique—using bright light to illuminate landscape at night—is forbidden. It helps keep the night environment natural. Explore more night wonders @babaktafreshi. #stargazing #nightphotography #utah #capitolreef

Photo by @luisadorr | Daniela Santiváñez, 26, is a member of ImillSkate, a women's skateboarding collective in Cochabamba, Bolivia.

As a child, she was introduced to the skating world by her brother. After she graduated from university, in 2019, she bought her first skateboard and dedicated herself to practicing.

As a nod to the their heritage, the collective performs in traditional pollera skirts, which are mostly associated with Indigenous women from the highlands. "They're considered part of the marginalized population in Bolivia," says Santiváñez, whose great-grandmother wore polleras. The group aims to instill cultural pride and eradicate discrimination. 

To read more about the women, check out the January issue, on newsstands now, and read more at the link in bio.

Photo by Laura Morton @laurakmorton | Fueled by snacks and energy drinks, competitors in a hackathon organized at Hacker Dojo, a Silicon Valley community technology hub, stayed up late into the night working on their projects. I photographed the scene while on assignment for National Geographic to capture the culture of the Silicon Valley. These events, which play an integral role in the tech industry, bring software developers and others together to collaborate intensively on a programming hack over a set period of time. While the focus is unique to each hackathon, the goal is usually the same: to create a piece of functioning software or hardware by the end, often in competition for prizes. For more photographs of people and places, follow along @laurakmorton.

Photo by @martinschoeller | Grace Yellow Hammer, Navajo Nation

“The Navajo elders asked me to be their ears, their eyes, and their voice. I was chosen; I didn’t want to. I cried. But that’s what both Navajo traditional elders and Hopi traditional elders told me to do. That’s my job now. So one minute I am over there, one minute I am over here. I went to the United Nations in Geneva to report what was happening to the people 16 times. As long as I am in good health, I will carry the message. That’s all I am: the message carrier."

I thank Grace for her words and time. For more portraits and stories in this series, follow me @martinschoeller.

Photo by Orsolya Haarberg @fjellheimengalleri | Aerial photograph of an Arctic river delta with both dry and water-filled channels in Norway's Adventdalen Valley. Please follow @fjellheimengalleri for more images.
#AdventRiver #Adventdalen #Spitsbergen #Svalbard #Arctic

Photo by @joelsartore | Meet Samba, a two-year-old northern tamandua at the Summit Municipal Park in Gamboa, Panama. This species' anatomy works to its advantage in its forest and scrub habitat, where it spends most of the day sleeping in trees then ventures onto the ground at night in search of food. Tamanduas have a long, prehensile (grasping) tail that can be used as an extra hand or foot while climbing trees. A specialized mouth and tongue allow these guys to consume up to 9,000 ants a day. And the purpose of that thick hair? To protect the tamanduas from being bitten by angry ants as they dine! To see more species featured in the Photo Ark follow me @joelsartore. #tamandua #anteater #samba #longtail #bignose #animal #wildlife #animalphotography #wildlifephotography #studioportrait #PhotoArk

Photo by @paoloverzone | Today’s custodians of Egypt’s cultural heritage include Mohamed Megahed, who oversees the pyramid complex of Pharaoh Djedkare at Saqqara. In this image, he is looking at the hieroglyphics inside the tomb of Khuwy, a nobleman from the 5th dynasty, at Djedkare’s cemetery in south Saqqara. Follow @paoloverzone for more images and stories.

Photo by Keith Ladzinski @ladzinski | Hippos violently spar and thrash in the shallows of Kenya's Mara River. A fully grown male can weigh over 9,000 pounds (4,000 kg)—an extraordinary amount to throw around. They're notoriously temperamental and territorial, causing about 500 human casualties in Africa each year. To see more photos from this part of the world, please visit @ladzinski.

Photo by @brianskerry | Orcas swim through a fjord days before the polar night in the Norwegian Arctic. (A polar night is a winter phenomenon typical of the polar circles when the sun doesn’t rise above the horizon for 24 hours or more, sometimes for months.) In the fall, orcas often move into these fjords, following the migrations of herring from offshore. Throughout the darkness of winter, the orcas will feed on herring, using complex dialects to communicate.

Photo by @estherhorvath | The Canadian town of Churchill is considered the polar bear capital of the world. In 2017, 18 international artists volunteered their time to paint a series of murals on empty buildings all over town. Some highlighted the local symbol. Please follow @estherhorvath for more polar stories.

A canine elixir for longevity could lead to one for us: They live in our houses, breathe the same air, and suffer many of the same ailments that affect older people.

Photograph by Becky Hale

Photo by @sarahyltonphoto | A view of the Mullick Ghat flower market in Kolkata, India, one of the largest such markets in Asia. For more stories, follow me @sarahyltonphoto. Read the full story at the link in bio. #kolkata #flowermarket #india

First thought to belong to an English lady-in-waiting, the lavish silk clothing from a 17th-century Dutch vessel is just one of many mysteries surrounding the last voyage of the Palmwood Wreck.

Photograph by Kaap Skil Museum

Photo by @williamodaniels | Monga, Democratic Republic of Congo, 2016. A worker records the details of a woman and her children during a measles vaccination campaign. Following an outbreak of the disease, vaccination centers were set up throughout the region, including this one inside a church in the village considered the epicenter of the outbreak. See the link in bio for the full story and follow me on @williamodaniels for more.

Photo by Elliot Ross @elliotstudio | In Georgia's Caucasus Mountains, travelers cross a turbid stream with the help of a local and his horses on a fall morning. These streams ebb and flow in daily fluctuations—as the day warms, the glaciers that feed these streams begin to melt at faster rates, transforming a morning stream into an afternoon river.

Photo by @lucalocatelliphoto | Off the coast of Italy, Nemo’s Garden is composed of six biospheres that make for a lunar, almost alien scene. It's an experiment to test whether  underwater greenhouses could be an agricultural option for arid coastal countries that must put resources into desalinating water for crops. 

Each dome has a platform that allows divers to partially enter the shell (as seen in the foreground). Plant cultivation is based on the hydroponic technique, whereby soil is replaced by a substrate that contains the nutrients and minerals needed for plant growth. As sunlight penetrates the humid domes, it leads to further condensation, generating the water source for the plants. Since no pests can penetrate the environment, it also doesn't require the use of chemical pesticides.

This story is part of a long-term project on circular solutions, created with the support of the Gallerie d'Italia Torino @gallerieditalia and in partnership with the Ellen MacArthur Foundation. Please follow me @lucalocatelliphoto to learn more about the solutions in our future. To read this story, go to the link in bio. #solutions #future #environment

Photo by @michaelchristopherbrown | Children play in the streets of Kabul, Afghanistan, in 2009. In 2021, after two decades at war with the U.S., the Taliban resumed power. The future of the country hangs in the balance, with 70% of the populace under 25 years of age.

The James Webb Space Telescope is discovering distant clusters of stars that formed surprisingly early—presenting new mysteries about how the universe evolved.

Image by NASA, ESA, CSA, M. Zamani (ESA/Webb)

Photo by Erika Larsen @erikalarsen888 | Crystal River, Florida, is considered the manatee capital of the world, and Kings Bay, fed by springs, is home to the Crystal River National Wildlife Refuge, sheltering manatees year-round.

In the winter months, residents view manatees from footbridges and recognize them by the scars they bear from boat propellers. Of adult manatees, 95% have been hit by a boat once, and 25% have been hit at least 10 times. Propeller scars become unique markings and are the easiest way to identify these marine mammals. A collection scientists started in the late 1970s, the Manatee Individual Photo-Identification System database, now provides an extensive portrait of more than 3,800 manatees.

Photo by @javier_aznar_photography | The flowers of a cannonball tree, on long stalks projecting from the trunk, are large, beautiful, and aromatic. The tree is named for its  cannonball-shaped fruit. In contrast to the flowers, the fruit releases a fetid scent at maturity, when it hits the ground and breaks open, attracting different animals. Follow @javier_aznar_photography to learn more about the organisms  of the Amazon rainforest.  #flowers #amazon #rainforest

Photo by David Chancellor @chancellordavid | In South Africa, each morning I rise before dawn, drawn into a land of light punctuated by the sounds and scents of the wild. Slowly the forms of lions materialize from the darkness. Frosty footprints are left in the crisp air, leaving with the warmth of the sun. From a world of mystery and darkness, the land is quickly transformed into the Africa that I love. Another day is born before my very eyes. To see more follow me @chancellordavid.

Photo by @joelsartore | Female acorn weevils use their long snouts, or rostra, to drill into a developing acorn from multiple angles, breaking up and softening the tissue inside before  boring into it once more to lay their eggs. The weevil larvae feed on the acorn as they develop. Photo taken at Waubonsie State Park in Iowa. To see more species featured in the Photo Ark follow me @joelsartore. #weevil #acorn #insect #photography #wildlifephotography #studioportrait #PhotoArk

Photo by @acacia.johnson | A cabin faces Safety Sound, Alaska. This protected lagoon near Nome has been a critical hunting, fishing, and gathering ground for Alaska Native peoples for millennia—favored for its protected waters and rich migratory bird life. Today it's globally recognized as an Important Bird Area, key to conservation efforts. Follow me at @acacia.johnson for more stories from Alaska and beyond. #alaska #safetysound #nome

Photo by @moisessaman | At the Burkina Institute of Technology in Koudougou, Burkina Faso, designed by celebrated architect Francis Kéré and completed in 2020, poured clay forms the massive walls. A facade of eucalyptus wood creates shade. Above each classroom, a vent allows hot air to escape. It's a prime example of how traditional building materials and cooling techniques are being reclaimed by contemporary architects as the climate warms. Teachers say the cooler conditions inside the classrooms thwart fighting among students and improve concentration. For the full story, see the link in bio.

Photo by @bertiegregory | A mobula ray zooms into a school of lanternfish. These rays were previously thought to be passive filters only capable of feeding on microscopic plankton. We now know they regularly hunt small fish using the flaps on either side of their head, called cephalic lobes, to funnel fish into their huge mouths. Filmed for my new show now streaming on @disneyplus. #EpicAdventuresWithBertieGregory

Photo by @nicholesobecki | One of the fastest animals in the world is racing for survival. Huge reductions in their natural habitat are among the threats that have pushed the number of adult cheetahs globally to around just 7,000. The fight against the newest threat—rampant trafficking, with cheetahs being sold over social media—is being waged in an unexpected place: Somaliland, a resource-poor, self-declared autonomous republic in the Horn of Africa. Central to its efforts is the legal front, where many are pushing to increase jail sentences for traffickers. These five cubs were shown to a judge as evidence during the trial of an infamous trafficker. Moving wild animals like cheetahs to safety is a dangerous undertaking, as it requires maintaining the animal's safety and care throughout the journey. Logistical expertise, coordination with veterinary care and local authorities, and genuine respect for the animals’ well-being must be perfectly orchestrated. | That’s where @dhl_global comes in. As leaders in #logistics, DHL understands the importance of this work. Discover how their international network can help the plight of endangered big cats across the globe. https://on.natgeo.com/rescueandrewilding

Photo by @timlaman | I climbed a strangler fig tree in Borneo to capture this shot of a red leaf monkey (Presbytis rubicunda) mom and baby feeding on figs high in the rainforest canopy. The monkeys are known by many names, including maroon langur and maroon leaf monkey. I’m on my way home after working for six weeks in Indonesia on assignment for National Geographic. To see more rainforest wildlife visit me @timlaman. #borneo #indonesia #gunungpalungnationalpark #wildlifephotography #conservation #onassignment

Seasonal affective disorder can occur in both winter and summer. Here's why it happens, and how you might treat it.

Photo Illustration by Jennifer Lee Blanton, Getty Images

Photo by @joelsartore | For their first couple years of life, juvenile Peruvian spider monkeys like this one @rarec.center depend heavily on their mothers for everything from protection and transportation to vital nutrients obtained through mom’s milk. Once weaned, these primates will become important gardeners of their forested homes, consuming more than 130 species of fruit and dispersing the seeds. To see more species featured in the Photo Ark, follow me @joelsartore. #monkey #primate #animal #wildlife #PhotoArk

Photo by Robbie Shone @shonephoto | In Italy's Buso della Neve del Zingarella, time is recorded in layers upon layers of ancient ice—stored in this giant plug wedged between the rock walls of the cave. For Italian geologist and explorer Francesco Sauro, this is a special cave. Sauro recognizes the importance of sampling and studying this ice now, before it melts away and crashes to the floor, disappearing forever. In "When the Magic Melts," in the October issue, author Denise Hruby and I document the contributions of scientists—and tour guides—as they work against the clock in this rapidly disappearing landscape. Read the full story at the link in bio and follow @shonephoto for more.

Photo by @luisadorr | This is Dani, a member of the ImillaSkate women's skateboarding collective in Cochabamba, Bolivia. As a child, she was introduced to the skating world by her brother. In 2019, after she graduated from university, she bought her first skateboard and dedicated herself to practicing.

The word imilla means “young girl” in Aymara and Quechua, and the group performs in the traditional attire—pollera skirts and hats (and hair in braids)—of the country's Indigenous highland women. Dani says that her great-grandmother wore polleras, and dressing in the same style is a point of pride. For the full story, check out the January issue or go to the link in bio.

Photo by Reuben Wu @reuben | On the Norwegian island of Spitsbergen, huge radomes making up the Svalbard Satellite Station seem to hover in the mist. From a series of images documenting the unearthly beauty of the ground station, which supports orbiting satellites. For more photos and stories, follow me @reuben.

Photo by Orsolya Haarberg @fjellheimengalleri | On a cold December day in Sweden's Sarek National Park, I came across this male ptarmigan. As I approached slowly, the bird did not flee—and I spent the whole day near this spot. For most of the day, the bird stayed under the cover of its snow cave, leaving the burrow only at the end of the day to feed. Please follow @fjellheimengalleri for more images from the Nordic countries. #Sarek #Laponia #Lapland #Sweden #ptarmigan #lagopusmuta

Three recent criminal acts at the Dallas Zoo have alarmed officials, including the theft of two emperor tamarins that were later recovered. And it’s not the only zoo under threat.

Photograph taken in Manu National Park, Peru by Charlie Hamilton James @chamiltonjames, Nat Geo Image Collection

Photo by Erika Larsen @erikalarsen888 | Blue Spring State Park in central Florida is a winter haven for about 800 manatees. Save the Manatee Club's Cora Berchem and Wayne Hartley do a daily count and general health checks during the winter. They can distinguish the manatees by their body scars from injuries such as being struck by boats. Having done this work for more than 30 years, Hartley has memorized hundreds of scar patterns.

Read the full story at the link in bio. 

The ability to read the skies was imperative to the survival of enslaved and free Africans, helping them track time, weather, and seasons. Now, Black astronomers are inspiring a new generation to enter the field. 

Photograph by Babak Tafreshi @babaktafreshi, Nat Geo Image Collection

Photo by @brianskerry | A newborn beluga whale "smiles" for the camera. It's part of a beluga population that winters near Greenland and migrates through the Northwest Passage of Canada in summer. They often spend weeks in Cunningham Inlet, an estuary ecosystem in the high Arctic. Seawater temperatures hover around minus two degrees Celsius (29 F), but freshwater from a river flowing into the ocean is about four degrees warmer, making this a perfect place to give birth and nurse calves. Read the full story at the link in bio.

Photo by @paoloverzone | Egyptian archaeologist Zahi Hawass examines the mummy KV21B in a storage room at the Egyptian Museum in Cairo before performing DNA sampling and a CT scan to determine its family tree. This mummy was discovered with another, KV21A, in a tomb discovered in 1817 in the Valley of the Kings. Both mummies may be queens from the 18th dynasty. Hawass and other Egyptian archaeologists consider KV21B a candidate for the body of Nefertiti. Follow @paoloverzone for more images and stories.

Photo by @javier_aznar_photography | A tent-making bat (Uroderma bilobatum) drinks water from a pond in the Ecuadorian Amazon. In this single frame, I used a flash on stroboscopic mode, lighting the bat three times in this sequence. Bats are invaluable for their ecological services: they disperse seeds, pollinate flowers, and feed on millions of insects, potentially limiting the spread of some viral diseases. Follow me @javier_aznar_photography to discover more about wildlife in the jungle. #bat #water #ecuador

Photo by @nicholesobecki | To understand aging, researchers look for clues in animals, such as those studied by the 51-year-old Amboseli Baboon Research Project in Kenya. As part of that work, Benard Oyath and Jackson Warutere prepare to take blood and other samples from Olduvai, who was tranquilized and then released back to the wild. The project’s scientists have found that baboons with strong social connections in adulthood can recover from harmful health effects of a stressful childhood. I am glad to see Olduvai included in the January 2023 magazine story about the science of longevity and how to live longer and better. To see more of my work on humanity’s connection to the natural world, please follow @nicholesobecki.

Photo by @moisessaman | At a quarry in Pissy, on the western edge of Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, men, women, and children—some younger than 10—extract granite that will be broken down to make concrete and gravel for house construction, exemplifying a move away from traditional building materials. The extraction process involves burning tires in order to create the heat necessary to crack massive slabs of granite, which are then broken down into ever smaller pieces and carried in large loads on the workers' heads up the quarry’s steep slopes. Quarry workers estimate that they burn at least 200 tires a day. The noxious fumes from the tires along with the extreme heat create hazardous working conditions for those who labor there for up to 14 hours a day. Although there are several mechanized quarries around Ouagadougou that have undercut prices, the quarry at Pissy persists because of the insatiable demand for new concrete housing.

Photo by @joelsartore | Red foxes, like this one @greenwoodwildlife, are mostly solitary, but that doesn’t mean they don’t have a lot to say. There have been more than 25 different kinds of vocalizations observed in red foxes, which are used to communicate to individuals both nearby and far away. Researchers have also found that foxes have their own distinct voices, so individuals can be distinguished from one another. To see more species featured in the Photo Ark, follow me @joelsartore. #fox #animal #wildlife #photography #PhotoArk

Photo by Elliot Ross @elliotstudio | La Gorce Arch, Glen Canyon, Utah. With a two-decade-long drought gripping the western United States, water levels in Lake Powell have plummeted, particularly during the last two years. A silver lining to the water crisis: over 100,000 acres (40,000 ha) of Glen Canyon are now out from under the artificial lake, revealing natural wonders such as La Gorce. As the waters retreat, a flood of flora and fauna is appearing at a pace greater than scientists anticipated, which brings hope for the restoration of one of America’s lost natural wonders—Glen Canyon. Follow me @elliotstudio as I continue to explore stories surrounding the Colorado River Basin.

Photo by @beckythale | When journalist Nikole Hannah-Jones showed up for a portrait wearing a fuchsia shirt, it was a gift. Sometimes I can influence the details of a shoot, but this project came together quickly. With just a few hours' notice, I hopped on the train from Washington, D.C., to New York City for the session. It's not often that I have the opportunity to photograph someone whose work I follow. Hannah-Jones's "The 1619 Project" has challenged me to think about the narratives that have shaped my identity and has stayed with me. And though she doesn't need a fuchsia shirt to make her extraordinary, I was grateful for it nonetheless. For the full story on her project, see the link in bio.

Photo by @ralphpace | A juvenile southern sea otter (Enhydra lutris nereis) dives below a large wave on its way to find mussels to eat in Monterey Bay, California. 

Although sea otters are generalists when it comes to feeding, they often prefer specific foods. As conditions change and the sea gets rougher, otters will still forage in very shallow waters when the seas are high. 

As excellent swimmers capable of holding their breath for nearly 8 minutes, otters can stay below the heavy waves until smaller sets of waves come in or until they can swim to deeper waters.

Photo by Pete McBride @pedromcbride | A study in layers: The Grand Canyon's Bright Angel Trail descends 4,380 feet (1,335 m) from the 270 million-year-old Kaibab Formation to the 1.7-billion-year-old Zoroaster Granite on the river. Formed on the ocean floor, the Kaibab Limestone is the canyon's uppermost layer, sitting around 9,000 feet (2,700 m) in elevation due to the plate tectonics that uplifted the Colorado Plateau. For more from the Grand Canyon, follow @pedromcbride. #arizona #grandcanyon #travel #landscapes #geology

Photo by Charlie Hamilton James @chamiltonjames | In southwest England, a kingfisher attempts to feed her chicks at their riverbank nest. Kingfishers, despite being exquisitely handsome, are born blind, bald, and ugly—recalling the ugly duckling story. Mum and dad feed the chicks all day long for nearly a month, catching small fish along the river and bringing them back to the nest—a tunnel dug into the bank, with a small chamber at the end. Inside, it's almost completely dark, so the parents work by touch to find an open beak, stuffing in a fish headfirst. Successful broods will fledge between six and eight chicks.

Photo by @michaelchristopherbrown | When I first visited Linfen, in 2010, just minutes after walking out of the central train station I saw through the hazy air this overgrown government building. China’s environmental protection agency said the coal belt city had the worst air in the country. At the time, the World Bank reported that 16 of the 20 most polluted cities were in China. Since then, Linfen’s government has made some efforts to clean up the city, ordering pollution controls such as closing substandard mines, limiting the traffic of coal trucks, and the promoting gas over coal as a heating source. There is controversy around the amount of progress in combatting the pollution, including criticism from the Chinese state itself.

Read the full story at the link in bio. 

The nation's six million feral pigs are destroying crops and preying on endangered species. But the most serious threat they pose is to human health.

Photograph by Rolf Nussbaumer, Nature Picture Library

Photo by @hannahreyesmorales | This portrait of Marta and Apolinar is one of my favorites—and it reminds me of the healing power of love. They're seated on their bed, which is covered by mosquito netting. For Marta, an assault survivor, Apolinar's support was part of her healing process at a time when there was no support structure for victims. She was assaulted in a mass rape during World War II. 

For situations like this, the question I ask myself is, how I can portray the complexity that comes with survival and healing without playing down the severity of the trauma we carry. Follow me @hannahreyesmorales for more stories from the Philippines and beyond. #ValentinesDay

Photo by Robbie Shone @shonephoto | While on assignment to photograph melting ice caves in the Alps, I observed that the  formations inside Eiskogelhöhle in Austria (pictured) have not changed much since my first visit there, in 2013—the volume of ice is still the same. One possible theory could be that due to its high elevation, this cave carries cooler winds throughout the year and never really gets warm enough to melt the ice. It's over 500 meters (1,650 ft) higher than Schwarzmooskogel, which is melting fast. In "When the Magic Melts," my article in the October issue, author Denise Hruby and I document the contributions of scientists—and tour guides—as they work against the clock in this rapidly disappearing landscape. Read the full story at the link in bio and follow @shonephoto for more.

Photo by @jenniferhayesig | A mother harp seal coaxes her pup into the water for a swimming lesson with a calming nose-to-nose kiss of recognition: I am your mother; you are my pup. She then guided the pup through icy water for several minutes until she detected several aggressive males circling below. Each February, harp seals are born on the sea ice in the Gulf of St. Lawrence in eastern Canada, and their mothers will nurse them for 12 to 15 days before she leaves to mate and migrate north to the Arctic. To survive, the pup relies on fat reserves and a few weeks of stable ice until it learns to swim and forage for food. This image is part of a series celebrating love on #ValentinesDay.

Photo by Keith Ladzinski @ladzinski | A vivid Mwanza flat-headed rock agama recharges under the sun, in Kenya's Masai Mara. Agama lizards are widely distributed throughout Africa, with a total of at least 37 species. To see more photos from this part of the world, please visit me @ladzinski.

Photo by David Guttenfelder @dguttenfelder | To slow Don Lueck’s dementia, his doctors suggested that he learn a new skill. He took up art in 2019 and has made more than 17,000 paintings. The hobby helped the gregarious 77-year-old endure pandemic-imposed isolation in his Madison, Wisconsin home. “Painting every day during this time saved our lives because his brain was actively engaged in a creative process he loves,” says his wife, Jenny Villwock. “He often includes faces or creatures in his painting—someone with whom he could socialize.” This portrait of Lueck, surrounded by some of his paintings, is part of the January 2023 cover story, “Living Longer—and Better: How Science Could Change the Way We Age.”

Photo by Daniella Zalcman @dzalcman | Gulls land on a small iceberg in the Arctic Ocean toward the end of summer, when the sea ice has reached its annual minimum. According to NASA, September Arctic sea ice is now shrinking at a rate of 12.6 percent a decade, which can lead to more intense summer heat waves, sea-level rise, and significant habitat destruction for wildlife populations.

Photo by @isadorakosofsky | Jeanie Thompson, 81, and Will Seward, 84, kiss on the sidewalk in Los Angeles. Jeanie and Will met at a retirement community in East Hollywood. But this photograph tells only one part of their story. In 2011 Will was evicted from a retirement community where he shared an apartment with Adina, a longtime companion. He moved into another assisted-living community nearby, where he met Jeanie. They connected immediately. Torn between Adina and Jeanie, Will tried to maintain a relationship with both. Eventually, after a period of discomfort, conflict, and uncertainty, Jeanie and Adina accepted the unconventional dynamic. “There are many different kinds of love,” said Adina. Jeanie, Will, and Adina formed a trio, often spending days roaming around the east side of Los Angeles. Their relationship challenged sociocultural norms and stereotypes about how older adults should live their lives. More than anything, their time together revealed ageless questions about freedom, romantic love, the nature of intimacy, and what constitutes a relationship. To see more stories on older adults and relationships, follow me at @isadorakosofsky. 

In honor of Valentine's Day, we are posting images about love in its many forms. #ValentinesDay

Photo by Erika Larsen @erikalarsen888 | Zoo Tampa’s Manatee Critical Care Center has three 16,000-gallon medical treatment pools, two underwater treatment pools, and a public observation area. This view gives visitors a real-time understanding of the steps taken to care for rehabilitating manatees. Here animal care supervisor Jaime Vaccaro uses an underwater vacuum to remove algae, leftover lettuce, and feces from the tank.

Photo by David Chancellor @chancellordavid | I’ve spoken before about my work documenting the rewilding of Saudi Arabia and the Arabian leopard as a powerful symbol of restoration and regeneration. I’ve spent days and days sitting calmly, waiting and watching these magnificent creatures. Although it can be frustrating (I’m not a patient person), I’m extremely happy to find that my work is becoming more difficult, more complex, with the arrival of each new cub. Here, we see the latest one. 

Born at the Arabian leopard breeding center in Taif, Saudi Arabia, these apex predators will one day be released back into this ecosystem. The center is operated by the Royal Commission for AlUla (RCU). This winter, RCU is releasing more than 1,500 Arabian gazelles, sand gazelles, Arabian oryx, and Nubian ibex into their ancestral habitat. The last piece of the puzzle will be the return of the Arabian leopard. Before that happens, the land will need to be re-greened to support the prey, as the pyramid of a functioning ecosystem rises from the desert sand. One day, this leopard will sit in these mountains and watch from a great distance as people walk by, unaware of its presence. Until then, the longer it takes for me to see it here, the better its chances of survival are in the wild. 

Today, February 10, marks the second Arabian Leopard Day, which sheds light on the plight of this majestic creature and the conservation work under way to ensure its survival. To see more on this story, follow me @chancellordavid.

Read the full story at the link in bio. 

Bats have long been sold in local markets in their range countries for meat, souvenirs, or traditional medicine. Yet the online trade amplifies the threat to bats and creates a different and greater demand.

Photograph by Merlin Tuttle, Science Source

Photo by @beckythale | A western lowland gorilla, called Calaya by zookeepers, carries her newborn, Moke, at the National Zoo in Washington, DC. They were photographed for a story on animal milk banks. To read the full story, go to the link in bio. This image of parental care is part of a series celebrating love on #ValentinesDay.

Photo by @stephenwilkes | Reflecting Pool, Lincoln Memorial, Washington, DC. On a dark and gray winter’s day, I spotted the subtle yet perfect illumination of the thousands of coins tossed in the pool. At first glance, they looked like stars in the night sky. Make a wish! To see more from my travels near and far, follow me @stephenwilkes. #wish #pool washingtondc #reflection #coins #nightsky
Photo by @rubensalgadoescudero | Agho kisses his granddaughter, Ehizogie, outside his home in Abomey, Benin. Stay tuned for more intimate family moments in honor of #valentinesday.

Photo by @timlaman | A female Pennant's red colobus in early morning light. This critically endangered species is endemic to Bioko island, in Equatorial Guinea. I photographed the monkey and many others on a RAVE, a Rapid Assessment Visual Expedition, for National Geographic. Follow me @timlaman for more wildlife and bird photographs. #wildlifephotography #conservation #wildlife #BiokoIsland

Photo by @beverlyjoubert | For lion cubs in the wilds of Botswana, the odds of survival can be precariously low—and it's often their mother’s care and fierce dedication that will be the deciding factor in beating those odds. She must shield her young from hunger and the elements, protect them from the menace of rival carnivores, and impart those critical early skills they’ll need to survive in the rough-and-tumble world of a top predator. Yet even amid the grueling work of motherhood, there is always time for a tender moment of grooming and affectionate nuzzling. It’s heartwarming to witness the ties that bind in the animal kingdom for #valentinesday. To see more of my work, follow me @beverlyjoubert.
#lioncub #bigcatsofinstagram #wildlife

Photo by @alessandro.cinque | An alpaca fetus is analyzed under a microscope at the Quimsachata Research and Production Center in the Puno region of southeastern Peru. The center, using a process that includes insemination and embryo transfers, aims to create genetically “improved” alpacas that offer higher fiber quality and are more resilient to disease and the effects of climate change. Indigenous communities often raise money to buy one of these specimens to add to their livestock. Tens of thousands of families depend on alpacas for their livelihoods, but climate change poses a growing risk to the animals and the communities they sustain. The Andes are experiencing shorter but more intense rainy seasons and longer periods of drought. Frosts and hailstorms have become more common. Changing weather patterns are shrinking natural pastures and reducing grass quality, forcing alpaca herds to compete for food. Read the full story at the link in bio, and to see more of my work, please follow @alessandro.cinque.

Photo by @edkashi | A couple dances at a fisherman's wedding in the village of Crișan, Romania, where a quarter of the population is ethnic Ukrainian, on February 17, 2001. Stay tuned for more joyful moments in celebration of #valentinesday.

Photo by @michaelchristopherbrown | This photograph was made during the February 2013 nor'easter, also known as winter storm Nemo, as I wandered through Central Park. New York City was a home base from 2005 to 2017. And while all cities are unique and special in their own way, living in here in my 20s and 30s was magical. The experience recalls what Hemingway wrote about Paris: “If you are lucky enough to have lived in Paris as a young man, then wherever you go for the rest of your life, it stays with you, for Paris is a moveable feast.”

Photo by Prasenjeet Yadav @prasen.yadav | The snow leopard evolved to live in the high-elevation desert of India's Himalayan range, and every part of its body shows adaptations to this environment. Take the nose, for example. Large nostrils and a broad nasal cavity make it easier for the snow leopard to inhale large amounts of oxygen-poor mountain air. The nasal cavity houses particularly large and thick mazes of bone and tissue called turbinates. When a snow leopard inhales freezing air into the turbinates, the air becomes heated as it mixes with warm air exiting the lungs. Now that's an incredible life hack that evolution has provided to these big cats. Follow me at @prasen.yadav for more photos from India.

Photo by @celestesloman | Portrait of twin brothers and models Hector and Jan Carlos Diaz, 24, in New York City. Stay tuned for more images celebrating the love of family members, partners, animals, and more for #ValentinesDay.

Photo by @jasperdoest | We know kissing as a greeting and as a way of expressing love, desire, and respect. But what about monkeys? Do they also kiss? 

Yes. Some species, such as macaques and baboons, will often make communication gestures known as lip-smacking, which can lead to contact with the lips. It usually occurs between adult female monkeys and their young infants. 

Aside from kissing, monkeys will hug and groom each other. Grooming is a way to show affection and respect. It helps to reduce tension by lowering the heart rate and releasing endorphins, the "feel-good" hormones. Follow @jasperdoest for more images of the wonders of nature. #monkeylove #kiss #valentinesday

Read the full story at the link in bio. 

The centuries-old art of folding paper is yielding new applications in spacecraft, architecture, and even the human body.

Image by Craig Cutler

Photo by Robin Hammond @hammond_robin | “We met on our job. Eventually, we had to admit that we were attracted to one another. A couple of years later, we decided that we loved each other and wanted to be together,” says Evelyn Jenkins Whitaker (at right). She and her wife, Sonja Jackson, have been together for 18 years. Their families, they say, have “embraced us.” 

For six years, in 14 countries, I recorded stories from LGBTQ folks for my project Where Love Is Illegal. Sadly, not all families are as accepting as Evelyn and Sonja’s. Many people told me it was their relatives whose discrimination was the most intense and most damaging. With each Valentine’s Day, it is my hope that we move closer toward recognizing that love is love—nothing else should matter. You can see Evelyn and Sonja’s story, and many others, at @whereloveisillegal. #ValentinesDay

Photo by @amivitale | Wildlife keeper Lekupania receives a nuzzle from an orphaned giraffe at @sararafoundation on Namunyak Wildlife Sanctuary in northern Kenya. A Samburu warrior, Lekupania used to look after his family’s livestock until he become an animal whisperer. He saved Fupi, the giraffe in this photograph, who had been injured after falling into a ditch. Since then, Fupi has been rehabilitated and returned to the wild by Lekupania, along with a number of other giraffes. Now all the rehabilitated giraffes come every morning to check on Lekupania. They do rounds of the stables and greet him, then make their way back to the wild. Follow @sararafoundation, @r.e.s.c.u.e, and @amivitale to learn more, including how to help ongoing conservation efforts. Stay tuned for more images of love celebrating #valentinesday. #giraffe #conservation #kenya #africa #babyanimals #kisses

Photo by @brianskerry | A female humpback whale and her newborn calf (estimated to be two days old) swim in the waters off Rarotonga in the Cook Islands. Humpback whale mothers invest a great deal of energy into their calves. The gestation period is about a year long, and once the calf is born, mom spends another year teaching it all the skills it will need to survive. Stay tuned for more images of love celebrating #ValentinesDay.

Photo by @yagazieemezi | When I was asked to choose an image to tie to Valentine’s Day, I pondered which one could hold all the meanings we often place on the day. Then I remembered this 2018 portrait of Shari, Kobby, and their son in Accra, Ghana. It was a favorite photographic moment for me—I had the joy of being welcomed into it. They've since divorced but happily co-parent. I reached out to them for their permission to once again share the sweet family scene along with their feelings about it. Here's what they said:

"It was such a profoundly tender picture. We had friends and family reach out for weeks after it first went online, either complimenting us or telling us they would never have shared such an intimate shot. We wanted to blow it up, frame it, and hang it over our bed. It captured something of what we wanted our family to be.

Much has changed since then. Yet thankfully some things have not. It remains crucial to us both that he continues to know what love looks like; that he still feels as safe and as held as he was in the picture. And that starts with how we treat him and each other—with respect and kindness, patience and genuine care. We want him to know that love isn't just roses and Valentine's Day cards. Sometimes, it's messy, hard-won, and unconventional. But we too are what love looks like. And we're very proud of that."

Photo by @javier_aznar_photography | A male sun glass frog (Hyalinobatrachium aureoguttatum) stands guard over a heart-shaped egg clutch in the Ecuadorian Chocó rainforest. This father will kick out any animal trying to prey on its offspring, and gather dew from leaves to keep the eggs hydrated until they hatch into tadpoles. As with many other glass frog species, dads help their young reach the next habitat: the water, where the tadpoles will spend some time before returning to the forest. Follow @javier_aznar_photography to discover more amazing frogs. This image of paternal care is part of a series celebrating love on #ValentinesDay.

Photo by @kiliiiyuyan | Mikhail Bahe feeds her baby on a traditional Navajo cradleboard, or awéétsʼáál, in her family’s modern hogan on the Navajo Nation in Arizona. Traditional Diné parents like Mikhail use cradleboards to keep their babies safe until they are ready to crawl—a technology that's evolved over thousands of years of parental love. Follow me, @kiliiiyuyan, for more from the worlds of Indigenous communities, and stay tuned more images of love as National Geographic celebrates #ValentinesDay.

Photo by @hannahreyesmorales | Birds fly over the city of Hatay, Turkey, at dusk. Hundreds of thousands of Syrians who fled the conflict in their country have taken refuge in this area near the Syrian border. 

I made the image in late 2019 for a story on lullabies. I  documented Syrian families who took lullabies with them as they left, passing them on to children as a way to preserve a sense of home and safety amid destruction. 

It's hard to find the words when I see images of the aftermath of last week's earthquake here. For families escaping conflict, the disaster intensifies an already extremely difficult situation. Please consider donating to reputable organizations working on the ground.

Read the full story at the link in bio. 

This mushroom season is one for the record books. Here’s why—and how to start shroom-hunting.

Photograph by @michaelchristopherbrown

Photo by @nicholesobecki | Generally speaking, smaller animals have shorter life spans than larger ones, but bats break the rule. Eighteen of the 19 mammals that live proportionally longer than humans based on body size are bats. (The naked mole rat is the other.) This spectacularly colored yellow-winged bat, with soft gray fur and long, translucent ears, reminds me of how diverse these flying mammals are, with nearly 1,400 species living everywhere on the globe, except for extreme desert and polar regions. Read the January 2023 story about the science of longevity, and how to live longer and better, at the link in bio. To see more of my work on the interdependence of humans and nature, please follow @nicholesobecki. Read the full story at the link in bio.

Photo by @luisadorr | Brenda is a member of ImillaSkate, a women's skateboarding group in Cochabamba, Bolivia.

Brenda and her mother are Indigenous Aymara and considered to be pollera women because of the colorful traditional skirts—polleras—they wear. Brenda started skateboarding 6 years ago and found that it gave her direction and helped her overcome fear. "It makes me feel capable because I can break my own limits and I can dare to do things that I have never thought about," she says. "And like this I can get over my daily fear."

It's very hard to skateboard wearing a voluminous skirt, but Brenda has been improving her skills through perseverance and practice. For her, skateboarding with ImillaSkate represents her roots, the place she comes from, and who she is.

For more about ImillaSkate and fighting discrimination against Indigenous people, check the January issue of National Geographic. Read the full story at the link in bio.

Photo by Reuben Wu @reuben | The harvest moon appears to hover above one of the giant turbines at Block Island Wind Farm, the first commercial offshore wind farm in the United States, operating since December 2016. 

By complete chance, the day of this shoot coincided with a full moon. Once I figured out what was possible, I was able to plan my exact location, altitude, helicopter flight time, and camera setup to make the perfect alignment. For more photos and stories, follow me @reuben.

Photo by Orsolya Haarberg @fjellheimengalleri | Reindeer battle heavy winds in Sweden's Sarek National Park. Unlike other deer species, reindeer females grow antlers and keep them throughout the winter. The antlers help them defend their food sources in a harsh environment. Follow @fjellheimengalleri for more images from the Nordic countries. #Sarek #Laponia #Lapland #reindeer #rangifertarandus

Photo by @moisessaman | Four-year-old Alloua Anooga lies on a traditional mud-brick wall at his family’s home in Tiebele, Burkina Faso. The village has some of the best preserved remaining examples of traditional painted Burkinabe architecture. 

Crafted from mud and designed to allow for ventilation, the houses are then finished with coats of decorative paint that protect the dwellings from the rain. Despite the local king’s determination to preserve traditional ways of home construction, most locals have moved outside the royal court, or compound, in order to be able to build with concrete or in other nontraditional ways. There is a popular perception that concrete equates to modernity and that earth bricks are a symbol of poverty and backwardness. In addition, some local Christian and Muslim clerics see traditional architecture as an extension of animist beliefs, so they advise residents against living in mud-brick homes after they have converted to Christianity or Islam. NGOs and community elders are pushing back, hoping that cultural and ethnic identity will persuade some families to reembrace their cultural architecture tradition. Read the full story at the link in bio.

Photo by Erika Larsen @erikalarsen888 | In western Florida, at a small interpretive center in Ellie Schiller Homosassa Springs Wildlife State Park, visitors can view a manatee skeleton and learn about the manatee's role in the ecosystem. The park has been a tourist attraction since the early 1900s, when trains stopped to let passengers off to walk the short trail to the spring. Homosassa Springs has four rehabilitating manatees: Two are permanent because they were rescued as juveniles and never acquired the life skills they needed to survive in the wild.

Photo by @brentstirton | Happy World Pangolin Day! A patient caregiver at a secret site in Zimbabwe cares for a rescued pangolin, helping the traumatized animal find ants and termites to eat and keeping him safe from predators and traffickers. Pangolins are the world’s most trafficked nonhuman mammals, highly prized in Asia for their meat as a delicacy and their scales as part of traditional medicine. The Tikki Hywood Foundation undertakes public awareness campaigns about pangolins, trains law enforcement and judiciary personnel, conducts research, and rehabilitates animals that have been confiscated from the illegal trade. Based in Zimbabwe, it operates with partners across Africa. The trust also engages with other organizations and governments throughout Africa to highlight the plight of pangolins, raising awareness of their conservation status and helping people learn about caring for rescued pangolins. #WorldPangolinDay
Photo by David Guttenfelder @dguttenfelder | A pair of lion cubs cuddle as they wake up in Kenya's Masai Mara National Reserve.

Photo by @acacia.johnson | A brown bear rests in the tundra near the boundary of Alaska's Izembek National Wildlife Refuge, close to the southern tip of the Alaska Peninsula. A proposed road connecting the nearby communities of King Cove and Cold Bay is the subject of a decades-long controversy: While residents of King Cove want improved access to medical care via the all-weather airport at Cold Bay, the road would cross through a globally important bird and wildlife habitat in the Izembek refuge. The land swap required to build the road would also upend a decades-old law that protects tens of millions of acres of Alaska's public lands, setting a precedent that could endanger all of the state's wildlife refuges.

Photo by @paoloverzone | Paleontologist Paul Sereno holds a fossil of a human jaw discovered during excavations at the Gobero site in Agadez, Niger. Taking the name given to the area by the Tuareg, nomads who have ruled that region for centuries, the site offers a glimpse of the Green Sahara, an era of time between 10,000 and 5,000 years ago when the land was lush with vegetation. People known as Kiffians were the first to settle in Gobero more than 9,700 years ago. Follow @paoloverzone for more images and stories.

Photo by @brianskerry | Happy World Whale Day! A pod of orca swim off Dominica. Orca sightings are quite rare in the Caribbean, and these are believed to be the first images of orca near Dominica. There were eight animals in this group. For more on whale culture, go to the link in bio. #WorldWhaleDay #Orca #Whales

Photo by @beverlyjoubert | A bad "hair" day can afflict us all… The black heron may look comically disheveled here, but its hunting savvy is nothing to snigger at—and the watery landscapes of Botswana’s Okavango Delta are the perfect place to deploy one of the most ingenious and crafty fishing tactics in the avian world. The bird's "umbrella" method (also known as canopy feeding) involves spreading out those dark wings to create a shadowy trap for unsuspecting prey. Drawn in by the illusion of a shady hideaway, fish are soon dispatched by a few flicks of the heron's beak. 

To see more of my work, follow me @beverlyjoubert.

#birds #blackheron #birdwatchers

Photo by @javier_aznar_photography | Alberto Sánchez, a scientist and curator of the herpetological collection at the National Museum of Natural Sciences in Madrid, holds a desert monitor (Varanus griseus) that had become trapped in a cistern in Western Sahara. Thousands of animals fall in these water wells throughout Morocco and other countries where water is scarce. What’s good for humans can be a deathtrap for some animals, which can enter these spaces seeking shelter, food, or water. They often die by drowning when the wells fill with water, or by starvation or dehydration when the wells run dry—often in a short time because of the high temperatures reached in these rooms. Follow @javier_aznar_photography to see more amazing creatures. #reptiles #conservation #westernsahara #animals

Photo by Robbie Shone @shonephoto | In 2013, when I first visited this spot in the Schwarzmooskogel ice cave, the rocks and boulders were almost completely buried by ice. Today much of it has melted, exposing the rocks. In the background, the impressive snow cone for which this hall is named is also shrinking. It’s a sad sight to see. In the article "When the Magic Melts," in the October issue, I document the contributions of scientists—and tour guides—as they work against the clock in this rapidly disappearing landscape. Read the full story at the link in bio and follow @shonephoto for more.

Photo by Charlie Hamilton James @chamiltonjames | Maasai herdsmen discuss lions as a storm brews behind them. During the period in which this image was shot, lion predation on cattle in the area around the village of Talek, on the edge of Kenya's Masai Mara Reserve, was high. The Maasai had been grazing their cattle inside the reserve in day and night shifts, bringing them into regular contact with the local lions. The result was a strange relationship: the lions developed strategies to hunt the cattle, mainly at night, and the Maasai learned to avoid them by texting each other the locations of the lions. It was exhilarating and terrifying to photograph—on foot—at night, and I was amazed by the bravery of the guys, who would run right up to the lions, throwing stones to scare them off. The lions would usually stand their ground, growling aggressively, and although they do occasionally attack, I never witnessed it.

Read the full story at the link in bio. 

Nearly all women suffer from hot flashes during menopause. Researchers have finally figured out what triggers them—paving the way for the first new class of treatments since 1941.

Illustration by My Box, Alamy Stock Photo

Photo by @katieorlinsky | In 2015 Dave Dalton and his dog team cross Eagle Summit in the Alaska interior, the most challenging section of the Yukon Quest, a 1,000-mile (1,600 km) sled dog race. Alaska's sled dog racing season is currently in full swing; it's a tradition with over 3,000 years of history in the Arctic Circle. Indigenous communities there used sled dogs long before Europeans bred the animals for transportation and hauling as they colonized the region in the 19th century. It wasn’t until the 1960s, when highways were built and snowmobiles became widespread, that dogs were no longer needed for transport. Still, the practice of mushing, as traveling by sled dog is known, remained a cultural and recreational activity in communities across the Arctic, and the world of competitive racing began.

Photo by @luisadorr | Belén is the youngest member of ImillaSkate, a women's skateboarding group in Cochabamba, Bolivia.

A physiotherapy student, Belén would like to match her career choice to her passion. She started skateboarding 4 years ago because she was amazed by the balance skills and the level of difficulty of the maneuvers. She'd like to use her knowledge as a physiotherapist to help skateboarders.

"Imilla" means "girl" or "young lady" in Quechua and Aymara, the most widely spoken Native languages in Bolivia. 
“We want to motivate the female skateboarding scenario in Bolivia so this sport can grow and we can get more spaces to practice—so we can participate in sports tournaments around the world as other athletes do," says one member of the skating group. "Another thing we want to do is to show that no matter how you look, how old you are, or what’s your gender, you can be part of the skate community and feel the freedom of skateboarding. We believe that everyone deserves respect, and we must get rid of discrimination and mistreatment towards people who are different from you. Diversity makes beauty.”

For more about ImillaSkate and fighting discrimination against Indigenous people, check the January issue of National Geographic. Read the full story at the link in bio.

Photo by @martinschoeller | In 2022 I began a series photographing and sharing the experiences of Native peoples in America. The portraits were taken at Albuquerque's Gathering of Nations, the largest powwow in North America. This is Percy Edwards, from the Colville Confederated Tribe: 

"My whole family lives on the reservation. My brother has danced all his life; my mom was a shaman, a medicine woman. In '03 my brother comes to me and says, 'Fill out this paperwork for eagle feathers.’ I am going, ‘what?’ I had shunned the Native life; I was a businessman living in faraway California. I had been the CEO of two companies, but still I gave the order and sent it to the fish and game department in Colorado. Three years later, a big box showed up with dry ice and I pulled out a frozen bald eagle.

So I started plucking the feathers and at night I start dreaming of dancing with the Old Ones. One morning I woke up, I saw  face paint on me and a badger on my head. I turned to my wife and said, 'I want to start dancing.'" 

Edwards's passage refers to the ability of Native Americans to apply to the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service for access to eagle carcasses, parts, and feathers, which are used for ceremonial or religious purposes.

Thank you Percy Edwards for your words and time. For more portraits and stories in this series, follow me @martinschoeller.

Photo by @moisessaman | Maxim Kiemdrebeojo, 17, has been living at an orphanage in Kougoudouli, Burkina Faso, since 2009. The building, made with laterite brick, was designed by Francis Kere, a Burkina Faso-born architect and globally renowned advocate of ecosensitive architecture. Some of the children housed at the orphanage are from communities displaced by conflict in the north and east of the country, while others have been given up by their desperate parents for economic reasons. Read the full story at the link in bio.

Photo by @brianskerry | A curious gray seal swims right up to my camera in the waters of the Gulf of Maine. Gray seal populations throughout New England were decimated after centuries of hunting, but their numbers have rebounded substantially since the U.S. Marine Mammal Protection Act was passed in 1972. This image is from my upcoming story in @natgeo. 
#Gulf of Maine

Photo by Reuben Wu @reuben | An enormous boulder outcrop in Bolivia's Eduardo Avaroa Andean Fauna National Reserve is illuminated by a light-carrying drone during a long exposure. Located in the Altiplano, the dunes and rocks of the Siloli Desert have been eroded by wind-blown sand over millennia. For more photos and stories, follow me @reuben.

Photo by @nicholesobecki | A Sudanese family from Karima tours the nearby tombs of El Kurru, where some of the earliest Kushite kings and queens were buried in the eighth century B.C. Just as many Europeans look to ancient Greece symbolically, many Africans are inspired by one of that continent's earliest civilizations, the kingdom of Kush. The Kushites erected mighty temples and tombs and some 255 pyramids—more than twice the number Egypt constructed next door. Read the full story at the link in bio. To see more of my work on the interdependence of humans and nature, please follow @nicholesobecki.

Photo by David Guttenfelder @dguttenfelder | A view over the coastline of Mahé, the largest island in the Seychelles. To boost the archipelago's resilience in the face of climate change and what's known as a blue economy—a sustainable living from the sea—the Seychelles exchanged its mounting national debt for dedicated ocean protection. In the “debt for nature” swap, the Nature Conservancy, a U.S. nonprofit, took on the debt in exchange for protection of its ocean areas. The initial pledge included creating 13 marine protected areas.

Photo by @paoloverzone | A member of the conservation team at the temple of Amenhotep III, in Luxor, Egypt, uses air pressure to clean an alabaster statue. The mortuary temple was Thebes’s largest funeral complex. Only parts of its design remain, including the Colossi of Memnon, two large stone statues measuring nearly 60 feet (18 m) in height. A team of German-Egyptian researchers led by archaeologist Hourig Sourouzian has been digging at this incredible site for years. Read the full story at the link in bio and follow @paoloverzone for more images and stories.

Read the full story at the link in bio. 

Human composting, water cremation, and green burials are gaining traction as people seek to minimize their environmental impact in death.

Photograph by Mat Hayward, Getty Images For Recompose

Photo by @richardbarnes | I have been photographing a National Geographic story on repatriation for the past 3 years. Repatriation concerns the return of objects mostly from European and American museums to the countries or peoples that originally produced them. Some of the artifacts were given under duress, and others were looted outright, but still others, such as the Nefertiti bust, now in the Neues Museum in Berlin, may have been obtained legally. It's no secret that colonial powers were rapacious in the theft of objects sacred to the people who created them—from the Benin Bronzes looted in a British raid in 1897 to the Mandu Yenu throne, whose return the Bamun kings in Cameroon have been seeking for decades. It's a complicated and nuanced debate: Some former colonial powers, along with museums including the Smithsonian Institution, embrace return or transfer of control, and others justify their position by claiming that many of the objects in their collections would never have been preserved if it were not for a globe-trotting curator or colonial overlord who recognized their value and saved them from neglect or ruin. Nonetheless, I have witnessed a sea change since I started this project, with many museum directors, curators, and concerned government officials advocating for return in as conscientious and equitable a way as possible. It's never too late. Read the full story at the link in bio.

Photo by Robin Hammond @hammond_robin | “I had to flee Uganda, because my life was in danger,” says Tasha, a transgender woman. She went to Kenya, hoping she’d find safety and acceptance. She quickly came to realize that transphobia was a real threat there too. “I only move out if it’s really important—very, very important—because I’m scared for my life.” Tasha posed for my long-term project, Where Love Is Illegal. She appears on the cover of my new book of the same name. You can see her story and many others at @whereloveisillegal. 

This portrait was photographed using a large-format camera on instant film.

Read the full story at the link in bio.

A National Geographic team has made the first ascent of the remote Mount Michael, looking for a lava lake in the volcano’s crater.

Photograph By Renan Ozturk @renan_ozturk

Photo by Muhammed Muheisen @mmuheisen | This is Hamzeh, a lion that was rescued from a zoo outside Aleppo, Syria, in 2017. Since then he has been rehabilitated and is living at the Al Ma’wa Wildlife Reserve in Jerash, Jordan. The reserve belongs to Al Ma’wa for Nature and Wildlife, part of the Princess Alia Foundation that provides emergency medical treatment, rehabilitation, and rehoming for animals. For more photos and videos from different parts of the world, follow me @mmuheisen and @mmuheisenpublic. #MuhammedMuheisen #Jordan #Sanctuary #Wildlife

Photo by @joelsartore | Who knew two rodents could be so cute? But these Mongolian gerbils are also what we call “desert tough”—they've learned how to survive even under the most extreme circumstances. In the semideserts and steppes of Mongolia, this species developed long legs for jumping and running away from predators; teeth to deal with hard seeds and plant matter; and water conservation techniques that allow them to survive in an unpredictable climate. Photo taken @gladysporterzoo in Brownsville, Texas. To see more species featured in the Photo Ark, follow me @joelsartore. #animals #wildlife #PhotoArk

Read the full story at the link in bio. 

It’s not just dogs: Even worms and ants can be trained to detect markers of illness, from COVID to tuberculosis.

Photograph by Johner Images, Getty Images

Photo by @katieorlinsky | I captured the northern lights, also known as aurora borealis, on a February night in Canada's Yukon Territory in 2014. This incredible yet common phenomenon takes place near the magnetic poles, the result of collisions between electrically charged particles from the sun that enter Earth's atmosphere. It was the first time I saw the lights. Since then I've continued to work in the Arctic, but I still remember this night as the most spectacular display I've seen.

Photo by Elliot Ross @elliotstudio | In the predawn light of the Colorado Plateau, Lake Powell and its “bathtub ring” glow. This white line of mineral deposits has been left by the reservoir’s shrinking water levels—the result of a 22-year drought that has stretched water resources to their limits across the American West. Follow @elliotstudio as I continue to explore stories surrounding the Colorado River Basin.

Photo by @moisessaman | Tiebele, a village in southern Burkina Faso, has some of the best preserved remaining examples of traditional painted Burkinabe architecture. 

Crafted from mud and designed to allow for ventilation, the houses are then finished with coats of decorative paint that protect the dwellings from the rain. Despite the local king’s determination to preserve traditional ways of home construction, most locals have moved outside the royal court, or compound, in order to be able to build with concrete or in other nontraditional ways. There is a popular perception that concrete equates to modernity and that earth bricks are a symbol of poverty and backwardness. In addition, some local Christian and Muslim clerics see traditional architecture as an extension of animist beliefs, so they advise residents against living in mud-brick homes after they have converted to Christianity or Islam. NGOs and community elders are pushing back, hoping that cultural and ethnic identity will persuade some families to reembrace their cultural architecture tradition. Read the full story at the link in bio.

Photo by @acacia.johnson | The port of Nome, Alaska, extends into the Bering Sea, and the loss of sea ice due to climate change could soon turn it into a major transport hub as the Arctic Ocean becomes increasingly navigable by ship. A planned expansion would make Nome the first deep-draft port (able to handle large ships) in the U.S. Arctic region. Follow me @acacia.johnson for more stories from Alaska and beyond. #alaska #nome #arctic #climatechange #seaiceloss

Photo by @chrisburkard | What does it take to surf in the Aleutian Islands? Months—even years—of planning. Countless late nights pouring over maps and swell charts trying to forecast waves that we'd only heard about from rumors. The extreme weather coming off the Bering Sea kept us slightly nervous as we waited for our window to fly in, hoping to catch the swell of a lifetime. The conditions lined up, the sky opened, and we couldn't believe the intersection of remote, snowy volcanoes and a perfect swell … truly an unforgettable experience.

Read the full story at the link in bio. 

A new report rating 10 companies on their animal welfare policies shows some promote exploitative experiences like elephant rides and cub petting.

Photo by Karine Aigner @kaigner
#WorldWildlifeDay

Photo by Javier Aznar @javier_aznar_photography | This portrait of a chachi tree frog (Boana picturata) was photographed in the Ecuadorian Chocó. Although the species is common in some areas, there is little data about it. A recent study that called the frog "an underexplored source of bioactive peptides" found three new antimicrobial peptide families in the skin secretions of the frog—a reminder that we must protect its habitat. As we bring many animals to extinction, we are destroying opportunities to find cures for diseases such as cancer and to discover new antibiotics for multiresistant bacteria among other substances. 

Thanks to nonprofits such as @fundacion.jocotoco, this region of Ecuador and the species that inhabit it have a chance to survive. Follow @javier_aznar_photography to discover some of the animals in the rainforests of South America. #ecuador #frog #animals #wildebeest 
#WorldWildlifeDay

Photo by @brianskerry | A sperm whale calf swims beneath her mother in the eastern Caribbean Sea. Sperm whale families are matrilineal and led by the older, wiser females of the group. For the full story on whale culture, see the link in bio. #WorldWildlifeDay

Photo by @beverlyjoubert | They're alert and watchful even during a thirst-quenching stopover at a rainwater pan in Botswana’s Okavango Delta. Though lions don’t need to drink every day—they can rely on the blood of their prey for a good portion of their moisture requirements—a convenient water source in the heat of the day is not to be passed up. I've witnessed so many fierce and violent facets of lion life, making a peaceful moment of rest and refreshment soothing to observe. To see more of my work, follow me @beverlyjoubert. #lions #bigcats #bigcatconservation #WorldWildlifeDay

Photo by @joelsartore | This adorable critter is a baby American badger photographed at Nebraska's @newildliferehab. In the wild this little one would belong to a litter, born in early spring. Blind at birth and almost completely helpless, baby badgers are nursed by mom until they are two to three months old. Despite their vulnerable state, youngsters may emerge from the den as early as five weeks old, but won’t fully venture out on their own until the six-month mark. To see more species featured in the Photo Ark follow me @joelsartore. #badger #baby #animal #wildlife #photography #PhotoArk #WorldWildlifeDay

Photo by @jasperdoest | Sometimes you come across people who brighten your world. Mert Akkök is one of those. We came across him as Floortje Dessing and I traveled overland from Amsterdam to Nepal in search of human-animal relationship stories.

Akkök plays the flute for his beloved animals in his living room, a place of solace and comfort for the 70+ strays he has welcomed and rescued on his farm just south of Istanbul. He joined a growing number of city dwellers moving to the countryside, where he cares for his four-legged friends. His blind horse, Reyhan, is drawn to the mellow sounds of the music and has even damaged his saxophone in her enthusiasm.

Through it all, Akkök's door remains open, providing his furry family with a safe haven. “We enjoy each other's company,” he says. “They're like my kids now, and I would only give them to decent and good people who can take very good care of them.”

Follow me @jasperdoest for more on the relationship between humankind and nature. #compassion #humananimalbond

Photo by @bertiegregory | Despite being one of the most numerous fish groups on the planet, lantern fish are rarely seen—and thus little is known about them. They undertake a daily vertical migration: they come to the surface at night, returning to the deep during the day. Occasionally, for reasons we don’t understand, they get caught at the surface and a feeding frenzy develops. Photographed for my new show, now streaming on @disneyplus. #EpicAdventuresWithBertieGregory
