Read the full story at the link in bio. Happy #WorldBeeDay!

Photo by @tasneemalsultan | Ahmed, a Luxor farmer, sustains his crops through the annual flooding of the Nile River, brought on by the rainy season in upstream Ethiopia and Sudan. The floods carry nutrient-rich sediment that for 5,000 years has nourished fertile lands and sustained Egyptians. Dams now better control the floods in high-water years but also interrupt the river's natural cycle.

Photo by @drewtrush | A camera trap I installed caught this black bear patrolling its territory in the Black Canyon of the Yellowstone River in Wyoming's Yellowstone National Park. Black bears are found throughout the park, and can weigh up to 300 pounds (135 kg). They're inherently curious and always manage to destroy my camera setups when they start investigating. This bear knocked over the fixture soon after the picture was taken.

Photo by @stephenwilkes | I love visiting Italy's Cinque Terre area. Stunning Manarola is Cinque Terre’s most iconic view. I was amazed by how the colorful houses contoured the cliffs they were built upon. Throughout the day, the light and color would change by the minute. To see more from my travels near and far follow me @stephenwilkes.

Read more at the link in bio.

Collagen production is vital for the health of hair, nails, bones, joints, and other parts of the body. But those popular supplements may not be worth the money.

Photograph by Gianluca Colla, Nat Geo Image Collection

Photo by @joelsartore | I met this endangered Matschie’s tree kangaroo and her adorable joey while visiting @zoomiami. Living high in the mountainous rainforests in New Guinea, the Matschie’s tree kangaroo looks a bit like a cross between a kangaroo and a lemur. Topping out at around 22 pounds, Matschie’s tree kangaroos may not rival their bigger kangaroo counterparts in size, but with powerful limbs and a long tail, these mighty mammals are built for climbing trees. Despite their impressive abilities, tree kangaroos sleep 60 percent of the time, curling up in whatever tree they happen to be in. They are known for making the occasional trip to the ground in search of food, but at heart they are permanent tree dwellers. To see more species featured in the Photo Ark, follow me @joelsartore. #PhotoArk #WorldTreeKangarooDay

Photos by @paoloverzone | A hundred years ago the discovery of Tutankhamun’s tomb in the Valley of the Kings in Luxor, Egypt, revolutionized the world of archaeology and inspired a wave of Egyptomania that still resonates. The tomb is famous for its extraordinary wealth of artifacts and treasures, including his golden mask, considered one of the most beautiful pieces of ancient Egypt. The burial chamber is decorated with paintings that depict scenes from ancient Egyptian mythology. His mummy is still inside the tomb, where it was buried more than 3,000 years ago. The tomb itself is relatively tiny compared to others in the Valley of the Kings, but even after a century, its sacred aura and mystery remain intact. Today, with generations of Egyptian archaeologists looking after the boy king’s grave, Egyptology is entering a new era. Read more about the discovery of Tut’s tomb at the link in bio. Follow @paoloverzone for more images and stories.

Photo by @ismailferdous | On a recent spring day, a group of young Jewish adults gathered for a barbecue picnic at Prospect Park in Brooklyn, New York. They had come from all over the United States, some even from Canada, but now they call Brooklyn home. The air was filled with the sound of sizzling meat, the smell of charcoal, and the hum of laughter and conversation. As they grilled and feasted on delicious food, they shared stories about their diverse Jewish backgrounds and experiences and discovered common threads that bound them together. For more stories follow @ismailferdous. #JewishHeritageMonth

Photo by @kiliiiyuyan | The Pacific Ocean lashes the coastline of the Kaikoura Peninsula in New Zealand. The region hosts one of the great areas of marine mammal activity in the world, including thousands of dolphins and Cape fur seals year-round. An offshore submarine canyon adds to the richness of the South Island’s eastern coast. Follow me @kiliiiyuyan for more from the living waters of the world.

Photo by Bethany Mollenkof @fancybethany | Against the backdrop of a family quilt in Tennessee, my mother holds my daughter when she was a few months old. The image is part of an ongoing photo project I call When Did You Begin? I explore themes tied to ancestry, family archives in the digital age, pregnancy, aging, and the evolving nature of motherhood.

Photo by @javier_aznar_photography | A mouse opossum (Marmosa sp.) in the Ecuadorian Amazon. The animals can be seen at night when they're out looking for insects and fruits to feed on. Follow @javier_aznar_photography to see more wildlife.

Photo by @babaktafreshi | The 52-foot-tall (16-meter-tall) Delicate Arch near Moab, Utah, is an icon of the U.S. Southwest and depicted on the state’s license plates. Here in Arches National Park, the desert becomes a rock wonderland and stars appear to touch the Earth. Located far from cities and streetlights, Arches is one my favorite dark-sky places. I started the 1.5-mile (2.4-kilometer) uphill hike in daytime and waited until the end of astronomical twilight for this single-exposure photograph of 15 seconds. Thousands of light-years beyond the arch, the core of our galaxy sets on planet Earth’s horizon. The Milky Way appears from the constellation Scorpius (bottom) to the Summer Triangle (top). | Adobe @Lightroom gives beginner and professional photographers easy tools to edit their photos, no matter where they are.

Photo by @martinedstrom | These wolf cubs photographed in Sjunda, Sweden, just outside of Stockholm, symbolize one side of a hotly debated topic among Nordics: wolf conservation. The survival of these cubs and their pack represents a massive victory for some, but the predators, which have been known to attack livestock, are hated by others. Authorities consider these wolves’ exact whereabouts closely guarded secrets, as poaching recently has become their leading cause of death in the wild. These cubs, part of a litter of seven born in 2021, were captured by camera trap in 2022 and are included in an ongoing project about the Indigenous Sami population, reindeer herding, and predators. Follow @martinedstrom for more on the story.

Read more at the link in bio.

Some people eat more or gravitate toward highly palatable, high-calorie foods when they’re under stress, others lose their appetites. And some people’s eating habits don’t change at all. The reasons for the differences are complex.

Photograph by Brian Finke

Photo by @jasperdoest | In Żabice, Poland, love is in the air as white storks clatter their bills to strengthen their bond. It serves as both a ritual greeting and a means to shoo away rivals during copulation. And what's remarkable is that the bird does this even as they hatch from the egg—despite having neck muscles not quite strong enough to perform the clattering well. These intricate behavioral patterns are deeply rooted in their genes. Life is truly awe-inspiring. Follow @jasperdoest for more images of the wonders of nature.

Photo by Keith Ladzinski @ladzinski | Vehicle lights outline Trail Ridge Road in Colorado's Rocky Mountain National Park, the highest-elevation continuous paved road in the United States, cresting at an impressive 12,183 feet (3,713 m). In the distance, Longs Peak is silhouetted by the glow of the Denver area. Roughly 4.3 million people visited the park in 2022, making it the 4th most visited U.S. national park.

Read more at the link in bio.

Orcas are well known for their intelligence and remarkable hunting techniques: whether it’s turning great white sharks upside down or working together to take down large whales. Over the last three years, a population of them off the Iberian Peninsula have been gaining attention—and causing angst among sailors—by attacking and even sinking boats in the area.

Photograph by @paulnicklen, Nat Geo Image Collection

Read more at the link in bio.

The coast of western Australia is littered with shipwrecks with terrifying stories, but none may be as horrific as that of Batavia. For hundreds on board, the terrifying 1629 wreck was just the beginning—mutiny, murder, and slavery followed for months.

Photograph by A. Paterson, ‘Shipwrecks of the Roaring 40s’, Australian Research Council

Photo by @tasneemalsultan | Built more than 3,000 years ago, the Karnak Temple includes the shrine of Seti II, which  was a sanctuary for the sacred boats of Amen-Re, Mut, and Khons during harvest processions. You can see engravings on the shrine walls including in the middle chapel, home to the golden-necklaced sacred bark of Amen-Re with the head of a ram.

Photo by Reuben Wu @reuben | A Perseid meteor burns in a bright streak as it enters the Earth's atmosphere above Lake Michigan. Every year around mid-August, the Perseid meteor shower puts on a spectacular show for stargazers across the globe, a phenomenon caused by Earth passing through debris left behind by the Swift-Tuttle comet. In its peak years, the number of meteors seen can reach 200 an hour. I captured this single exposure during an all-night time lapse on August 11, 2016, near Muskegon, Michigan. For more photos, follow me @reuben.

Photo by Matthieu Paley @paleyphoto | Woolook Bu is part of a very remote community of Afghan Kyrgyz living 14,000 feet up in the Pamir mountains of Afghanistan. I watched as she rounded up her herd and, suddenly, in a natural display of love and affection, embraced a young calf that had just been born the day before.

Photo by @acacia.johnson | With wing and engine secured for protection, an airplane sits buried in snow at the airport in Fairbanks, Alaska. Since the first mail-delivery plane took off in 1924, small aircraft—capable of landing on short runways or on natural features such as tundra, glaciers, beaches, and water—have played a critical role in Alaska’s development. Today most of the state depends on aviation for essential transport between communities and to access remote wilderness areas. Flying is also part of Alaska’s culture: The state has six times more pilots per capita than any other in the United States. Follow me at @acacia.johnson for more stories from Alaska and beyond.

Read more at the link in bio.

China's Zhurong rover spotted evidence that frost may have cemented dunes together as recently as 400,000 years ago. NASA's Perseverance found signs that a powerful waterway once carved its way into Jezero crater.

Composite by NASA, JPL-Caltech/MSSS

Photo by @joelsartore | The tawny frogmouth may be small, but this bird is full of personality. Categorized as a “false owl” because of its owl-like body and froglike mouth, this bird, found throughout Australia, has a look like no other. During the day, they sleep in the trees, perfectly positioning their bodies to mimic branches, which provides protection from predators. When the sun goes down, the tawny frogmouths come to life, hunting everything from nocturnal insects to small mammals, reptiles, frogs, and other birds. Most of the bird’s prey is obtained by pouncing to the ground from an elevated perch while some prey items, such as moths, are caught in flight. Photo taken @fortworthzoo. To see more species featured in the Photo Ark, follow me @joelsartore. #PhotoArk
Photo by @amytoensing | Green grass and blooming tulips are a sight for sore eyes after a long winter in Syracuse, New York.

Photo by @estherhorvath | Isabelle Schulz is station leader of the French-German research base AWIPEV, part of an international Arctic science consortium working out of the village of Ny-Ålesund in Norway's Svalbard archipelago. Until about 10 years ago, this fjord froze over regularly in winter and you could cross it on skis or snowmobile. That's no longer possible: Svalbard is at the epicenter of global warming, where the average winter temperature has risen by about 7 degrees Celsius over the past three decades—as observed by atmospheric measurements at AWIPEV. Please follow @estherhorvath for more polar stories.

Photo by @rubensalgadoescudero | Maung Ko, an ethnic Shan farmer, poses with his cow in the village of Lui Pan Sone in Kayah State, Myanmar (Burma). Solar lamps let him milk his cows early in the morning or late in the evenings, freeing up his days to spend more time with his family or working in the fields. Around 50% of the population in Myanmar have access to electricity, the vast majority of which live in cities, according to most recent data from the International Energy Agency. Access is even bleaker in rural areas, where only 3,000 of the estimated 68,000 villages in the country’s rural areas have access to the power source.

This image is part of my Solar Portraits series, which focuses on electricity access around the world and the impact of solar power in different communities. Follow me @rubensalgadoescudero to see the world through my lens.

Photo by @paoloverzone | In 1751 a meteorite landed in Hrašćina, Croatia, with witnesses reporting an explosion and a fireball in the sky—claims that were later dismissed as fairy tales. The largest chunk of that meteorite, weighing 88 pounds, is now displayed in the Natural History Museum Vienna. Read more about how early cultures used metal from meteorites in the June 2023 magazine or in the link in bio. Follow @paoloverzone for more images and stories.

Photo by @ismailferdous | An immersive experience at New York City's American Museum of Natural History, "Invisible Worlds" delves into the intricate networks of life that exist at different scales, many imperceptible to the human eye. From the microorganisms that thrive in our bodies to the cosmic web that binds the universe together, displays showcase the interconnectedness of all living things. The exhibit's use of technology allows visitors to become part of the story, with their movements affecting the projections around them. For more pictures follow me @ismailferdous.

Read more at the link in bio.

The first evidence of octopuses (yes, this is a correct plural term) dreaming comes from scientists observing a sleeping octopus startling awake. Was this a nightmare? Or is the eight-armed invertebrate just getting old?

Photograph of a day octopus taken by @joelsartore, Nat Geo Image Collection.

Photo by Muhammed Muheisen @mmuheisen | The Jordanian city of As-Salt, a UNESCO World Heritage site, was a center for trade and cultural exchange during the Ottoman era, whose influence endures in the architecture. For more photos and videos from different parts of the world, follow me @mmuheisen and @mmuheisenpublic. #MuhammedMuheisen

Photo by @joelsartore | North American river otters are built for life on the water. Thick, protective fur keeps them warm as they navigate chilly waters; short legs and webbed feet make them incredibly fast swimmers; and a long, narrow body and flattened head help streamline their movements. Otters like this one @wildlifecenterastoria are also capable of staying underwater for up to eight minutes, during which time they can use their long whiskers to help them detect prey. To see more species featured in the Photo Ark, follow me @joelsartore. #PhotoArk #WorldOtterDay

Read more at the link in bio.

Western New Mexico is home to the Gila Wilderness—a maze of forested canyons that in 1924 became the world’s first legally protected wilderness area. Although designated to remain untouched by humankind, the wilderness and other protected areas that surround it have been shaped by thousands of years of human habitation.

Photograph by @katieorlinsky

Photo by @isadorakosofsky I A family gathers on a dune at White Sands National Park in New Mexico. White Sands contains the largest gypsum dunefield in the world, including hearth mounds—remains of prehistoric campfires found nowhere else. The park is also home to the largest collection of fossilized footprints, from the Ice Age, and tells the story of potentially more than 20,000 years of human presence. Some believe the footprints challenge scientists’ timeline of when humans first came to North America. 

An ancient sea once covered most of the southwestern United States. During that time, layers of gypsum were deposited on the seafloor. The rise and fall of sea levels millions of years ago initiated the process of making gypsum sand. More recently, astronauts have used this slice of desert, over 275 square miles (700 sq km), as a geographic reference point. I've been atop these unique dunes many times as a photographer; the park is a refuge where one cannot help but feel the presence of generations of seekers and storytellers before us.

Photo by @kiliiiyuyan | I’m on assignment in Greenland, where narwhals come to feed and give birth to calves deep into fjords when the sea ice retreats. The light was golden at around midnight during the 24-hour daylight of polar summer. Narwhals have been hunted by the Inughuit here for millennia, and today hunters continue to use the same traditions  alongside a newer quota management system designed to ensure the narwhal population remains healthy. The region’s wildlife is prolific due to both excellent traditional management and an area of high current known as the North Water Polynya. The polynya remains ice free even in winter and creates an incredible habitat for narwhals, walruses, as well as the polar bears and people that depend on them. Follow me @kiliiiyuyan for more from the Arctic and beyond.

Read more at the link in bio.

Ingredients normally purchased at a store are often hidden in plain sight: tucked into the woods near our homes, or in our own backyards. Foraging doesn’t have to be intimidating and can strengthen our relationship with the wild.

Photograph by Christian Beutler, Keystone/Redux

Photo by @beverlyjoubert |There is no safer haven for an elephant calf. Few dangers can reach it here, nestled under its mother’s protective underbelly and encircled by the additional bulwark of the herd. And as the calf grows, the herd will continue to be a source of guidance, wisdom, and support. From lessons on foraging techniques and migratory routes to playful interactions and complex communication, from cultural learning to gentle companionship, all of this can be found within the embrace of the herd. Observing elephants in Botswana’s Okavango Delta, one of the last major strongholds for the species, it's impossible not to sense their deep-rooted connections and interdependence. To see more of my work, follow me @beverlyjoubert.

Read more at the link in bio.

In some situations, multivitamins can be helpful. In others, they can lead to dangerous nutrient deficiencies or imbalances. Experts suggest assessing your nutritional needs before popping a daily multivitamin.

Photograph by @beckythale

Photo by Luján Agusti @lujanag | Lago Escondido, Tierra del Fuego, Argentina. Jorge Tagle, a member of the generations-old Bronzovich gaucho family, poses in front of a fabric background. A lover of country life and horses, Tagle works in the family business, Baqueanos de Tierra del Fuego. Settlers in Tierra del Fuego, nicknamed “the end of the world,” developed a culture based on the arduous farmwork needed to survive the low temperatures and rugged geography of the continental south. Here, those who choose to live outside of cities do so for the love of freedom and nature—and they do so knowing that they will have to endure the inclement weather. I documented the life and work of Baqueanos de Tierra del Fuego in southern Patagonia. Follow me @lujanag to learn more about life and traditions in Tierra del Fuego.

Photo by @sarahyltonphoto | I often get asked why I choose to photograph with a camera—medium format—that's older than me. This image of Lake Vembanad in India's Kerala state  illustrates my answer. 

There are constraints with the analog process: I may fumble while reloading film, it can take too long to focus, or it's too dark for the film to properly work. But my answer to this question comes easy: It makes me more intentional in my vision. I slow down and I feel the magic in every photograph that comes to life in a negative. So while I "miss" many opportunities, each photograph that emerges holds meaning—and isn't that the point? For more on this dispatch, go to the link in bio. For other stories, follow me @sarahyltonphoto

Photo by @jasperdoest | After enduring a lifetime of abuse, Asian elephant Suzy has found refuge and a chance to be an elephant again. Her horrendous living conditions at the circus, which included malnutrition and a lack of medical care, resulting in blindness, have been replaced with a supportive and nurturing environment at the Elephant Conservation and Care Centre in Mathura, India. Now Suzy can feel what it’s like to be free from the whip of a bullhook and enjoy long walks with her newfound elephant friend, Asha. Follow me @jasperdoest for more on the relationship between humankind and nature.
Photo by @tasneemalsultan | A woman weaves a necklace with delicate beads at Abu Dhabi's House of Artisans, a center for showcasing traditional Emirati crafts.

Read more at the link in bio.

Baby animals are adorable, and when we see one that appears to be in trouble, it’s not surprising that we want to help. Recognizing when an animal’s truly in trouble and learning how to safely lend a hand is something that’s difficult to discern, even for well-meaning nature lovers.

Photograph by Stephen St. John, Nat Geo Image Collection

Photo by @paoloverzone | Conservators Zahraa Youssef Ahmed (at right) and Asmaa Ahmed document and archive singular artifacts found at the temple of Amenhotep III in Luxor, Egypt. They are part of a German Egyptian research team led by archaeologist Hourig Sourouzian. Built during the 18th dynasty, the funerary temple was a monument to Amenhotep III, a venue for the pharaoh’s worship and posthumous glorification. Meet other custodians of Egypt’s cultural heritage—and preview the new Grand Egyptian Museum—at the link in bio. Follow @paoloverzone for more images and stories.

Photo by @timlaman | A misty morning in the cloud forest of the Arfak Mountains, West Papua, Indonesia. The forests of the great island of New Guinea are the most intact in the Asia-Pacific region. Both Papua New Guinea in the east and the Indonesian provinces in the island's western half have over 80% of their forest intact, representing both a carbon store and biodiversity. I’ll be sharing more @TimLaman as I continue to explore Papua’s forests.

Tattoos have a fascinating history dating back at least 5,200 years. Head to the link in bio for a look at some of the most intriguing tattoos archaeologists have found from the past—and what they can tell us about the ancient world.

Photograph by Gunther Deichmann

Read more at the link in bio.

In the United States, domestic cats kill up to 4 billion birds and 22 billion small mammals every year. These deaths exceed other man-made causes of wildlife mortality like accidental poisoning and habitat destruction and pose an imminent threat to the health and diversity of wildlife. Scientists have developed a gene therapy contraceptive for cats that could reduce these deaths. One solution is to rein in cat fertility—the treatment is easy to administer and lasts a lifetime.

Photograph by Madeleine Hordinski

Photo by Matthieu Paley @paleyphoto | Shadman Ali  is one of the many Sufi believers who undertake on foot a 180-kilometer (112 mi) annual pilgrimage under extreme heat across the desert and mountains of southern Pakistan. He keeps pigeons back home and took one of them on the road, which surprised me. “My pigeon will be blessed by the act of pilgrimage, as much as me,” he says. Head over to National Geographic's YouTube channel to watch a short doc titled “Lahooti,” focusing on the journey of these pilgrims. For more insights into our world, follow along @paleyphoto.

On Tuesday evening, New York City had some of the worst air quality in the world. The pollution was the result of Canadian wildfire smoke dispersing and placing millions of people under air quality alerts. Chronic exposure to wildfire smoke could have serious effects on our health—from our lungs to our kidneys, liver, brain, and heart. Head to the link in bio to learn what steps you can take to protect yourself.

Photograph By Seth Wenig /AP Photo

Photo by @joelsartore | Meet Teiku, a two-month-old jaguar cub that calls @zoodomrd, in the Dominican Republic, home. Jaguars are most similar in appearance to leopards, but there’s nothing you can confuse them with in the wild since no other big cats live in South America. The most distinctive feature of the jaguar is the shape of their spots, which resemble a certain sweet-smelling flower—the rose. To see more species featured in the Photo Ark, follow me @joelsartore. #PhotoArk

Photo by @daviddoubilet | A vulnerable sea turtle hatchling hides from predators within a dense floating forest of sargassum seaweed off Cozumel, Mexico. This living canopy is critical nursery habitat for marine life, but when it washes onto shore in mass quantities it can become a deadly blanket, smothering turtle and seabird nests and turning away beach-bound tourists. Scientists indicate 2023 will be an unprecedented year, with vast amounts of seaweed accumulations in the "sargassum belt" of the North Atlantic carried by currents to the beaches of the Caribbean, southern U.S., and Mexico. The tangled labyrinth that's an oasis at sea is a costly environmental and economic consequence when it lands. Follow @DavidDoubilet to submerge into planet ocean. #WorldOceansDay

Photo by @acacia.johnson | Pilot and flight instructor Heidi Reuss, 87, sits in her Taylorcraft airplane in Anchorage, Alaska. Since much of the vast terrain in Alaska is inaccessible by road, flying small planes is an important part of its culture and infrastructure. Reuss, well known in the state’s aviation community, has taught countless students to fly in her 60-year flight career.

“When I fly, I'm free,” says Reuss. “That's what I feel like. And if I fly the Taylorcraft—that’s my baby—it does what I want it to do. I don’t have to tell it what to do. It becomes part of your body. You think ‘turn,‘ and it turns.” Follow me at @acacia.johnson for more stories from Alaska and beyond.

Photo by Orsolya Haarberg @fjellheimengalleri | In Sweden's Padjelanta National Park, June is the month of long summer nights, golden late-evening light, and this intriguing pattern of a barren mountain landscape peeking through the melting snow.

Photo by Robbie Shone @shonephoto | I’m currently in Iceland, working on a story about life inhabiting newly formed, steaming-hot lava tubes. The expedition to the Fagradalsfjall volcano has been a success. Lead by National Geographic Explorer Francesco Sauro, the team has identified a new lava tube that's 350 meters (yards) long and accessible from at least five entrances. This is one of the youngest caves on Earth. The conduit is still very hot, with temperatures varying between 50 to  300 degrees Celsius (120 to 575 degrees F). Scientists have sampled dozens of metastable minerals, and microbiologists are working to find the first bacteria that colonize these extreme environments. Stay tuned, as there’ll be more to come. @insidenatgeo

Few sights induce nostalgia like the flickering glow of fireflies at night. These beloved, bioluminescent insects (also known as lightning bugs) are in trouble. Their populations are declining around the world as the threats against them pile up. Learn what you can do to ensure that fireflies continue to light up our backyards for generations to come at the link in bio.

Photograph by @davidliittschwager, Nat Geo Image Collection

Photo by @noralorek | Mary Emba learned to embroider by copying the designs she saw on fabrics as a tailor in South Sudan. When civil war forced her to flee to Uganda alongside thousands of other refugees, she took only her children. Now she’s starting life over in Bidibidi refugee camp, where she works with the @milayaproject, a nonprofit organization that emerged out of a National Geographic article I photographed with writer @ninastrochlic. The Milaya Project features women who make ornately embroidered bedsheets called milayas. 

For decades, war in South Sudan has forced refugees back and forth between their homes and Uganda. Bidibidi, with more than 250,000 people, is now one of the world's largest refugee settlements. For more on life there, go to the link in bio.

Photo by Muhammed Muheisen @mmuheisen | A display at the Tulip Experience Amsterdam in Noordwijkerhout, Netherlands. The image is part of a story I’ve been working on for some years now about the country's flower season. For more photos and videos from different parts of the world, follow me @mmuheisen.

As climate change drives an increase in wildfires, we’re seeing more smoke lofted into the upper atmosphere each fire season. We’re likely to continue seeing it increase in severity, frequency, and longevity as the planet warms. Here are a few tips on how to reduce exposure to harmful air once it reaches a town near you:

1. Monitor local AQI forecasts
2. Wear a NIOSH-approved N95 or better mask outdoors
3. Invest in a better air filter
4. Create your own air filtration system
5. Take care of your eyes
6. Stock up on supplies well before summer, peak fire season
7. Consider getting out of town

Read the full story for free by creating an account at the link in bio.

Photograph by Jake Price

Photo by @beverlyjoubert | Full bellies … and full of mischief. These muddy young cubs have a long way to go before they can lay claim to a kill of their own, so posing atop one will have to do for now. Botswana’s Okavango Delta certainly holds the promise of rich hunting grounds for these future apex predators—if we humans can safeguard this fragile and unique landscape. As one of the most biodiverse places in Africa, the ecological value of this wetland wilderness is truly immense. To see more of my work, follow me @beverlyjoubert.

Photo by @martinedstrom | Nylon nets are commonly used—and frequently replaced—on the Ganges, one of the world’s largest inland fisheries. When lost or discarded in the river, the nets can entangle turtles, otters, and endangered river dolphins. Over time, they break down into microplastics. Photographed along the Ganges River during the 2019 @insidenatgeo "Plastic: Sea to Source" expedition in India. Follow @martinedstrom for more stories on plastic and its impact on our planet.

Photo by @jasperdoest | King penguins are one of the two species of penguins that inhabit the sub-Antarctic island of South Georgia. They are known for their distinctive orange ear patches and bright yellow and orange coloring on their necks and chests. Using a long shutter speed, I captured this scene of densely packed individuals walking side by side, in an attempt to showcase the remarkable abundance of wildlife for which South Georgia is renowned. 

South Georgia's unique environmental conditions make it a prime breeding location for king penguins, drawing in thousands of pairs annually. The waters around the island teem with krill and small fish, essential food sources for the penguins and their chicks. Follow @jasperdoest for more images of the wonders of nature

Photo by @rubensalgadoescudero | Workers use solar lamps to collect newly baked bricks in Saipur, India. The power source allows them to work in cooler evening temperatures and relatively safer conditions. Over the last decade, India has made an aggressive push to provide electricity access for its citizens, with over 99% having grid access in 2019. That number, however, is expected to drop sharply once the impact of the pandemic can be studied. 

This image is part of my Solar Portraits series, which focuses on electricity access around the world and the impact of solar power in different communities. Follow me on @rubensalgadoescudero to see the world through my lens.

Photo by @javier_aznar_photography | A treehopper (Cyphonia sp.) feeds on the sap of a plant in the Ecuadorian rainforest, its back covered by hairs that make it look like a rock star. Though their function remains unknown, the tiny hairs can help camouflage the insects in the trees they inhabit. The hairs may also be sensitive, capable of receiving unknown stimuli possibly to sense the surroundings. Treehoppers haven’t been studied as closely as their relatives, the leafhopper or cicada, which has led to significant gaps in our knowledge of these bugs. If you want to read more about these little creatures and their many disguises, check out my story “Inside the world of treehoppers, mini-marvels of the rainforest” in the link in bio. Follow @javier_aznar_photography to learn more about the weirdest and smallest animals.

Read more at the link in bio.

Rising temperatures are making severe storms more frequent globally, but outdated infrastructures and decades of policy decisions that largely ignored the climate crisis make Rome particularly vulnerable. A newly created Office for the Climate is scrambling for a solution.

Photograph by Christian Minelli, NurPhoto/Getty Images

Photo by @tasneemalsultan | During a festival in Ha'il, a city in northwestern Saudi Arabia, Um Ahmed was selling coffee and tea to visitors. After hearing her story, I decided to include her in my ongoing series, Saudi Tales of Love. As I travel across the country, I'm always looking to find stories of women and their relationship to love, marriage, and loss. She was married at 15. It was a loveless marriage and she disliked her husband. “I found him a second wife who was more suited to him," she told me. "And knew he would later divorce me and let me raise my children alone. He followed my plan." She's now in her 60s and describes as herself as the "happiest mother of educated, successful children.”

Photo by @brianskerry | Two harp seal pups meet on the pack ice in Canada’s Gulf of St. Lawrence, touching noses as they sniff each other. Pups are generally born in this region during February and need to spend about two weeks nursing from their mothers before heading off on their own. But the decline of sea ice over the past decade has created a serious situation for these animals, and pup mortality rates have increased substantially. If the climate continues to warm and sea ice disappears, the future is uncertain for this species

Photo by Luján Agusti @lujanag | Juan “Juancho” Bronzovich is a member of a generations-old gaucho family in Tierra del Fuego, Argentina. He's a great connoisseur of country life and horses, which is why he also participates in the family business. He holds a rebenque, a horse whip typical to the region. Follow me @lujanag to learn more about life and traditions in Patagonia.

This caption was updated to correctly identify the tool in his hand.

Photo by @dina_litovsky | Mexico City is one of my favorite cities in the world. The densely populated metropolis, with over 21 million residents, is a cultural and artistic epicenter. I love walking its leafy avenues and numerous parks, which reveal an array of vignettes and glimpses into the lives of the people living in the capital. For more images, follow me @dina_litovsky.

Read more at the link in bio.

Cancer, aging, and severe COVID-19 have all been linked to damage from inflammation. Scientists are flipping their focus to find new drugs that may revolutionize treatments.

Photograph by Zephyr, Science Source

Photo by @kianahayeri | In 2021 students from Afghanistan's Daikundi Province walk to the campus of the only public university in the region, which sits on a mountaintop outside the city of Nili. Those who can't afford to take a minivan or motorbike walk for one to two hours daily to reach the school.

In December, the Taliban banned women (seen here) from attending private and public universities in Afghanistan, sparking despair among young people in the country. The ban further restricted women's education—girls had been excluded from secondary schools in September 2021, a month after the Taliban returned to power.

Read more at the link in bio.

Scientists recently discovered that female American crocodiles can produce offspring without males—a phenomenon known as facultative parthenogenesis, or “virgin birth." This ability appears to be an ancient trait shared between crocodilians, birds, and dinosaurs (yes, “Jurassic Park" was right).

Photograph by @DavidDoubilet, Nat Geo Image Collection.

Photo by Nat Geo Explorer in Residence @enricsala | Cocos Island, off Costa Rica, is a key stop for green turtles moving across the eastern tropical Pacific. They are often bycatch in tuna fisheries, but the expanded 54,000-square-kilometer Cocos Island National Park provides some refuge to this threatened species. This photo was taken during a Pristine Seas expedition in October 2009. Supported by the National Geographic Society, Pristine Seas works to protect the world's oceans by creating or expanding marine protected areas. #WorldSeaTurtleDay @natgeopristineseas @insidenatgeo

Photo by @daviddoubilet | A critically endangered hawksbill sea turtle soars through the sea in Kimbe Bay, Papua New Guinea. This curious turtle swam with us all day on several dives, peering over our shoulders. During our dive breaks, she'd wait at the surface until we rolled in. We all submerged together. I've photographed hundreds of sea turtles around the world, but diving with this one was magical—and leaving was hard. If all goes right in her world, she could live 50+ years. But if she approaches the wrong fisherman, her curiosity could be her demise. I often think of her and the joy I felt that day. Follow @daviddoubilet to submerge into planet ocean. #WorldSeaTurtleDay

Read more at the link in bio.

Are organic fruits and vegetables richer in nutrients than their conventional cousins? The short answer is yes—but the long answer is more complex than you might expect. Regulations for organic food put out by the U.S. Department of Agriculture don’t focus on the health benefits. Instead, the emphasis is on how organic produce is grown, largely by protecting soil through the use of composts and animal manures and eschewing synthetic chemicals.

Photograph by @beckythale, National Geographic

Photo by @timlaman | The ocean is full of truly alien creatures. This is the aptly named flamboyant cuttlefish, just about 3 cm (an inch) long. I photographed it on a night dive in Triton Bay, West Papa, Indonesia. It's the only one of these rare little guys I've ever encountered in hundreds of dives on Indonesia's amazingly diverse coral reefs.

Photo by @magnuswennman | Yvette Tetteh, 30, is a Ghanaian-British entrepreneur, athlete, and activist who swam about 450 kilometers (300 mi) of Ghana's Volta River to bring attention to water pollution. She swam 4 to 6 hours each day over a month as part of what she calls the Agbetsi Living Water Swim project, which focuses on textile waste in the country.

The expedition built on research into the environmental impact of textiles flowing through Ghana, one of the largest importers of secondhand clothing in the world. The Or Foundation estimates that weekly Ghana sees 15 million items of used clothing or cast-off inventory from the EU, the U.K., and the U.S. entering Accra's Kantamanto Market, where 30,000 traders sort through their purchased bales for items they can re-sell or upcycle. But today on average 40% of every clothing bale is deemed too cheap or poor quality to re-use—a trend tracking the rise of fast fashion—and it's discarded and sent to landfills. The waste has reached a tipping point; it eventually ends up on the shores of waterways, often washed down by rains, bringing with it an enormous environmental toll as well as upheaval for the local garment industry.

Mosquitoes use a variety of cues to home in on their targets. Head to the link in bio to learn what odors they’re drawn to, what scientists recommend to keep them away—and how a future personalized repellant might work.

Micrograph by Dr. Tony Brain, Science Photo Library
Photo by Muhammed Muheisen @mmuheisen | The sun sets over a canal in Amsterdam. For more photos and videos from different parts of the world, follow me @mmuheisen.

Photo by @davidliittschwager | Newborn seahorses emerge from a male’s pouch, where a female deposited her eggs for incubation. This pot-bellied seahorse father may give birth to hundreds of young. Photographed at Seahorse World in Tasmania, Australia. For more on this story, go to the link in bio. #FathersDay

Photo by Matthieu Paley @paleyphoto | We sat around the fire after a simple breakfast of chai and chapatis. Daula Sain then prepared himself for another long day‘s walk on a Sufi pilgrimage across the Baluchistan mountains in Pakistan. He stood so elegantly in front of me, playing with his scarf—it was one of these flowing moments that are a gift to the photographer. Head over to National Geographic's YouTube channel to watch a short documentary, “Lahooti,” focused on the journey of these pilgrims. For more insights into our world, follow along @paleyphoto.

Photo by @ronan_donovan | The silverback mountain gorilla is the protector of his family. While the gorillas can weigh 400 pounds (175 kg), they can also be some of the most gentle apes with their young—often playing or snuggling with babies and keeping an eye out for them. This silverback from "Pablo's family" group, in Rwanda's Volcanoes National Park, is acting as a warm backrest during a foggy day for a young gorilla. #FathersDay

Photo by @laurakmorton | During last year’s Juneteenth Parade in Gettysburg, Pennsylvania, participants paused at sites along the route that remain historically significant to the city's Black community. One of the stops was St. Paul's A.M.E. Zion Church, the city's oldest congregation of Black community members, which dates to 1838. Gettysburg itself is known as the site of the American Civil War’s deadliest battle. I photographed the parade while working on a project about American celebrations. For more photographs of people and places, follow along @laurakmorton. #Juneteenth

Photo by @paoloverzone | At the turn of the 19th century, scientists in Europe still debated the existence of meteorites. Then, in 1803, one exploded in the sky and rained about 3,000 stones on L’Aigle, France. Some of the stones are displayed at the Natural History Museum Vienna, along with a report from a scientist who investigated and declared the event “the most astonishing phenomenon ever observed by man.” Read more about the discovery and early use of meteorites in the June 2023 magazine or at the link in bio. Follow @paoloverzone for more images and stories.

After appearing in Norwegian waters, this beluga whale initially made headlines for his possible profession as a Russian spy—he was clearly tame and wearing a camera harness manufactured in Vladimir Putin’s hometown of St. Petersburg. 

Now, after years of friendly appearances, the suspected former spy whale is on the move again. Head to the link in bio to learn why conservationists say that’s bad news and why the beluga with a knack for making headlines is still in danger.

Photograph By Rich German

Photo by @beverlyjoubert | Lions need space. Space to carve out territories, sidestep conflict, find new hunting grounds, and maintain the genetic flow that powers healthy populations. Among other threats, habitat fragmentation and destruction have played a major role in the decline of these most iconic of the big cats—globally, their numbers have dropped by around 43% in just the past two decades. This is why conservation efforts must focus not just on preserving existing habitats—like the lion stronghold of Botswana’s Okavango Delta—but also on reconnecting fragmented landscapes, to create mosaics of interconnected wild spaces where these predators can roam and thrive.

The Oceangate submersible Titan has been missing near the Titanic wreck site in the North Atlantic since early Sunday morning. Their last communication was roughly 100 minutes after their descent. Several unique factors play into the ongoing rescue efforts for the five-passenger submersible. Head to the link in bio for more on what we know.

Photograph by OceanGate Expeditions

Photo by @martinedstrom | “I don’t hate wolves. I believe they have a right to exist just like any other animal. But people don’t understand what they are doing to our reindeer herds and how much this impacts the Sami community,” says Evelina Solsten, who’s standing beside her tamed reindeer Daemies on ancestral land in Jämtland in western Sweden. Evelina is Sami, the Indigenous people who’ve roamed the region for millennia, and her family has lived off reindeer-keeping for generations. When Daemies was just six months old, a wolf attack separated her from the rest of her herd, and she had to be taken in by Evelina or she wouldn’t have survived. They have been friends ever since. This photograph is from an ongoing project about the Sami and predators. Follow @martinedstrom for more as the story develops.

Photo by Robbie Shone @shonephoto | Revelers celebrate Sonnwendfeuer, or the summer solstice, atop Nordkette mountain near Innsbruck, Austria. For this centuries-old tradition in the Tyrol region, participants light bonfires and hold torches along its granite peaks.

Photo by Robin Hammond @hammond_robin | In many countries around the world June is Pride month. It's a time for LGBTQI+ people to celebrate and be celebrated by their communities. But life for many continues to be hard. When I met Julian, he was homeless. Growing up in a Mormon family, Julian was surrounded by gender stereotypes. He says, “I realized the most authentic part of myself was a boy.” Like so many transgender people, Julian has faced discrimination and homelessness. Despite it all, he is inspired by a Mormon principle to “hope to endure all things.” As with many of those I photographed for @whereloveisillegal, Julian chose not to reveal his identity. For a lot of participants in this project, being identified as gay, lesbian, or trans can result in rejection, hate, and violence. Up to a third of LGBTQI+ youth in America have reported experiencing homelessness or housing instability at some point in their lives, according to a survey from the Trevor Project. The Pride movement is built on a tradition of protest, outrage, and a hunger for equality. Follow me for more.

In an interview with National Geographic, the Explorers Club president explains why special underwater robots may be needed to recover Titan without damaging its fragile hull—but requests to bring the equipment to the search area are caught in a bureaucratic snafu. Read the full story for free by creating an account at the link in bio.

Photograph by OceanGate Expeditions

Photo by @joelsartore | Meet King Max, a king vulture I photographed at the Gladys Porter Zoo in Brownsville, Texas. Hatched in 2006, this handsome fellow was hand-reared by a care team, and in 2018 moved to Belize to act as an ambassador for his wild counterparts. Found in Central and South America, these birds face a number of challenges that have led to declines in their population. The zoo participates in the king vulture species survival plan, along with a number of other zoos, to maintain a healthy captive population of the birds, ensuring the species will survive in the event the wild population cannot sustain itself. To see more species featured in the Photo Ark, follow me @joelsartore. #PhotoArk @gladysporterzoo

Photo by @hannahreyesmorales | Talap Zamanbol, aged 14 at the time, poses for a portrait with her eagle in Mongolia. She is part of a generation of nomads keeping an ancient tradition alive in a world being altered by technology. Zamanbol learned how to hunt with eagles from her  grandfather, whose eagle she inherited after he died. When teaching her to hunt, he always uttering the words, ‘My granddaughter will someday be an eagle huntress.’ Out of custom and love, the birds are eventually released back into the wild. Zamanbol was 13 when she let her first eagle go, the one she'd inherited from her grandfather. Her family slaughtered a sheep for the occasion. She then tied a white ribbon around the bird’s leg, went up to the mountains, and bid the eagle farewell. “I was sad,” Zamanbol said, “but I wanted her to be free.”

Follow me @hannahreyesmorales for more stories from Asia and beyond.

Photo by @stevewinterphoto | Finding tigers can be a test of patience, but the reward of being in the presence of this mystical creature makes all the hours of driving and waiting disappear—and being one with nature is all that remains. As we drove around India's Bandhavgarh Tiger Reserve, we listened for the telltale alarm calls from the deer or monkeys. Then the silence was broken. With a piercing call from a sambar—two of them fly over us and into the forest—we see a tiger walking in the distance and settling into a blanket of bamboo leaves.

The two people in the world who have spent the most time exploring and documenting the Titanic are Nat Geo Explorers at Large James Cameron and Bob Ballard. In an exclusive interview, the deep-sea explorers shared their reactions to the Titan tragedy. Read more at the link in bio.

Photograph by OceanGate Expeditions
Photo by @ismailferdous | In the heart of New York City, an enchanting scene on Orchard Beach, in the Bronx borough, captures the essence of summertime. For more photos follow me @ismailferdous.

Photo by @daviddoubilet | Indonesian marine scientist Nesha Ichida prepares to release a juvenile zebra shark named Kathlyn into a patrolled marine protected area in Wayag Lagoon, Raja Ampat Islands. Zebra sharks used to thrive here before overfishing wiped out the species.

ReShark, a growing global conservation coalition, is putting sharks back into the sea. The network of aquariums it partners with provides zebra shark eggs that are shipped by air and sea to two nurseries in Raja Ampat. The embryos grow and emerge from their eggs as baby sharks called pups. When they’re able to fend for themselves and grow large enough to fend off predators, they’re released into their future to rebuild the population. Read more about this story, “A Wild Plan,” in National Geographic’s July issue or at the link in bio. And follow @daviddoubilet to explore the planet’s oceans.

In the summer of 2014, the ALS Ice Bucket Challenge quite literally drenched the internet, quickly becoming what is now considered the largest social media movement in medical history. The viral challenge's success continues to be felt today with new gene discoveries, more treatment options, and improved care—researchers say they're closer than ever to finding a cure for the disease. Learn more at the link in bio.

Photograph by Chang W. Lee, The New York Times/Redux

Photo by @mattiasklumofficial | The king of bites! With a mind-boggling 3,700 pounds per square inch of bite force, crocodiles deliver a stronger crunch than lions. They simply leave the competition in the dust. This Nile crocodile, photographed in Selous, Tanzania, will eventually measure more than four meters (14 ft) long. Relative to their enormous size, it's no wonder their large and powerful jaws are among the world's deadliest traps. Visit me @mattiasklumofficial for more images.

Photo by @jasperdoest | At the Balaju Bridge in Kathmandu, 52-year-old Rupak Darshan visits daily to feed the crows and stray dogs. Having faced a life of hardship, including job loss and sexual abuse incidents that left him HIV-positive, Darshan finds solace and comfort in this place. “I understand the plight of the dogs as only a person who has faced such difficulties can truly know how it feels,” he says. Amid the chaos of Nepal’s capital city, Darshan and the dogs find peace together: “These dogs are my only family.” Follow me @jasperdoest for more on the relationship between humankind and nature

Warmer springs and longer summers mean a longer tick season. Several U.S. health officials are already warning of a particularly bad year for ticks. Learn how to keep them away, what to do if you find a tick on you, how to identify a tick bite, and more at the link in bio.

Photograph by Roman Willi, Nature Picture Library

Photo by @kiliiiyuyan | I’m on assignment in Greenland, where narwhals come when the sea ice retreats to feed and give birth to their calves deep in fjords. The light was golden around midnight during the 24-hour daylight of polar summer. 

Narwhals have been hunted by the Inughuit here for millennia, and today hunters continue the tradition within a quota management system designed to ensure the narwhal population remains healthy. The region’s wildlife is prolific due to both excellent management and an open-water area fed by currents and upwelling known as the North Water Polynya. The polynya creates an incredible habitat for narwhals and walruses as well as the polar bears and people that depend on them.  Follow me @kiliiiyuyan for more from the Arctic and beyond.

Photo by @laurakmorton | An annual summer tradition, firemen’s carnivals can be found in small towns across the United States, where rural communities often rely on a volunteer firefighting force. They must fundraise to purchase firefighting equipment, and the carnivals are a major contributor. In 2021 I photographed the Walkersville Volunteer Fire Company carnival in Walkersville, Maryland, while working on a project about American celebrations. Carnival attendees walk through the midway right before a thunderstorm passed over. For more photographs of people and places, follow along @laurakmorton.

Curly hair may have originally served as an evolutionary advantage for growing bigger human brains. A recent study—involving a mannequin wearing wigs in a wind tunnel—reveals how. Learn more at the link in bio.

Photograph by @beckythale, Nat Geo Image Collection

Photo by @andrea_frazzetta | While working on a travel story, I arrived in Panama's San Blas Islands on a small biplane with a bunch of tourists. The plane lands on a tiny runway on an islet in the middle of the ocean. From there, small boats depart for other islets scattered throughout this enchanted archipelago off the coast of Panama that is administered by the Kuna people.

I spent a couple of days on one of these islets, staying in a hut, sleeping in a hammock, and eating fish. In the evenings, I would grab my tripod and make the five-minute walk around the island, looking for the best frame to capture the beauty of the blue hour. Sometimes life is sweet like that.
Follow @andrea_frazzetta for more images and stories.

Photo by @amivitale | Philip, a Samburu guide, greets a reticulated giraffe in the Namunyak Wildlife Conservancy in northern Kenya. The community here has been deeply involved in preserving the diversity of its wildlife. The conservancy helps the Samburu combine their knowledge with modern science to more sustainably manage their rangeland. Across Africa, giraffe populations dropped nearly 40 percent over three decades, and the reticulated giraffe, one of the four species, numbers fewer than 16,000. While the decline is thought to be caused by habitat loss and poaching, including animals killed by snares, scientists are now pursuing major studies to understand why giraffes are disappearing and what can be done about it. It will take strong partnerships among local community members like Philip, scientists, and all of us. @sararafoundation @r.e.s.c.u.e

40 years ago, Sally Ride became the first American woman in space. Throughout her life, she was known as a brilliant physicist, loyal crew member, and passionate science education advocate. When Ride died in 2012, her obituary revealed that she was a member of the LGBTQ community: having a 27-year partnership with Tam O’Shaughnessy. This revelation added another first to her lengthy list of historic accomplishments by being the first known queer astronaut.

See Ride’s boundary-breaking life in photos by Mackenzie Calle (@mackenzie.calle) at the link in bio.

Photo by @javier_aznar_photography | An Ecuadorian hillstar (Oreotrochilus chimborazo) naps while perched on a Chuquiragua, one of the flowers they feed on. Each night this species of hummingbird enters a state of torpor, a kind of temporary hibernation in which its heart rate and vital functions dramatically slow to help it withstand the cold of the high Andes. Follow @javier_aznar_photography for more wildlife photos.

Photo by Matthieu Paley @paleyphoto | Haider Ali is a Sufi pilgrim I encountered during our 200-kilometer walk across Pakistan’s Baluchistan Province. He bathes after a long day of trekking in extreme heat. All freshened up, we sit under a tree. Haider explains his mission: “My ultimate challenge is to kill off my desires. I must control my eyes, my mouth, and my ego. There is nothing without sacrifice.” Head over to National Geographic's YouTube channel to watch a short documentary, “Lahooti,” focusing on the journey of these pilgrims. For more insights into our world, follow along @paleyphoto.

Photo by @paoloverzone | Wahib Anton, a conservator at the Egyptian Museum in Cairo, cleans the second of three nesting coffins that held Tutankhamun’s mummy. This second coffin was made of embellished gilded wood clad with inlaid vitreous paste and decorated with a rishi, or feathered, pattern. For more than a century, the Egyptian Museum has been renowned for its immense collection of ancient Egyptian artifacts, a staggering assemblage of more than 120,000 items. Some of those were held in storage, however. But with the opening of the new Grand Egyptian Museum nearby, many of those artifacts, including nearly all of the 5,000 objects discovered in King Tut’s tomb, will be on display for the first time, in two exhibition halls devoted entirely to Egypt’s most famous pharaohs. Read more about the new museum at the link in bio. Follow @paoloverzone for more images and stories.

Photo by @jasperdoest | The killer whale (orca) is found in all the world's oceans, and although it's considered a single species, research by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration in Antarctic waters has identified four distinct forms of killer whales, known as types A, B, C, and D. Through satellite tagging, NOAA will study the movements of the whales. Tissue samples are also being collected to compare dietary signals, contaminant loads, and genetic differences. A photo database will also help in identification and to estimate population sizes and residency patterns. This research is being conducted in collaboration with the National Geographic Society and Lindblad Expeditions. Follow @jasperdoest for more images of the wonders of nature. @insidenatgeo @noaafisheries

Peru is currently experiencing one of the worst dengue outbreaks recorded with more than 170,000 Peruvians suffering from the mosquito-borne virus and more than 225 dead. The outbreak is driven in part by unusually wet conditions caused by the climate phenomenon known as El Niño. While scientists believe the impact of El Niño cycles are increasingly exacerbated by climate change, archaeological evidence shows the climate phenomenon has been severely affecting the region for more than a thousand years, with past societies battling its effects with practical on-the-ground engineering as well as spiritual appeals to the gods—appeals that have included acts of ritual child sacrifice unprecedented in world history. Read more at the link in bio.

Photograph by Robert Clark (@robertclarkphoto), Nat Geo Image Collection

Photo by @BrianSkerry | A great white shark seems to be smiling as he swims with a school of jacks in the waters of South Australia.

The new National Geographic documentary film "Return of the White Shark," produced by me, alongside Adam Geiger and Colette Beaudry (@sealightpictures), debuts this weekend. It focuses on the great white sharks around Cape Cod, Massachusetts, which in recent years has become a hub of white shark activity. The film explores shark behavior and the cutting-edge research being conducted to better understand these animals and increase public safety.

"Return of the White Shark" premieres as part of Sharkfest on @disneyplus and @hulu on July 2 and National Geographic Channel (@natgeotv) on July 3 at 9 p.m. ET

Photo by Robbie Shone @shonephoto | On the upper flanks of Iceland's Fagradalsfjall volcano, the area in this lava tube had cooled enough so that it was possible for a team enter without the cumbersome protective suits and full breathing apparatus. However, the harmful toxic gases remained, and the researchers had to wear masks. Time was tight, and it was still a matter of urgency as temperatures rose to 50°C (120°F) in the deeper parts. Microbiologist Martina Cappelletti and speleologist Bogdan Onac take samples of microorganisms before sending them straight down to the base camp tent, just off the lava field, and analyzed. Their research goal is to find traces of microbial colonization within these new lava tube structures.

Photo by @enricsala | Cocos Island National Park in Costa Rica is a shark haven. Hammerheads (seen here in 2009) aggregate by the thousands—divers can observe schools of 100 to 200 sharks. The park was vastly expanded by the Costa Rican government in 2021, providing a refuge not only for the shallow habitats around the island but also to seamount chains used in their annual migrations. Cocos and a few other protected islands in the eastern tropical Pacific function as stepping stones in the migration of sharks (and other endangered species). But their numbers have been declining steadily: outside of the few areas that are fully protected from fishing, sharks are being slaughtered. Industrial fishing targets sharks directly for the Asian shark fin market and indirectly as bycatch in tuna fisheries. And even small-scale fishers target juvenile hammerhead sharks, which are born in coastal mangroves. The future of sharks depends solely on us.

Enric Sala is Explorer in Residence at the National Geographic Society and founder of its Pristine Seas initiative. @insidenatgeo @natgeopristineseas

Photo by @estherhorvath | In April I had the opportunity to visit the Eureka Weather Station, a small research base with eight staff on Ellesmere Island, in the Canadian territory of Nunavut. Eureka was founded in 1947 as the first official high Arctic weather station in Canada. Weather balloons, like the one seen here, are launched twice a day (11:15 a.m. and 11:15 p.m. GMT) to collect data such as wind speed and direction, temperature, pressure, and relative humidity up to an altitude of about 35 kilometers (20 mi). Follow me @estherhorvath for more polar science stories.

The gut microbiome is made up of all the microbiota that live in our intestinal tracts. These minuscule organisms help the body break down carbohydrates, proteins, and sugars into useful nutrients and process fiber in the colon. More complex relationships between gut microbiota and health exist too—for example, numerous studies have shown that the excess or lack of certain bacteria in the gut have a strong correlation to the onset of diabetes. There’s also a lot of emerging research on another complex element of the gut microbiome—its relationship to the brain, known as the “gut-brain axis."

Knowing it's crucial to various aspects of our physical well-being, how do you maintain a healthy gut microbiome (or re-balance it after the stomach flu or a few too many slices of cake)? Experts recommend eating foods high in fiber, incorporating fermented foods, and keeping sugar intake low. Learn more about your gut and ways to keep it healthy at the link in bio.

Colorized micrograph by Martin Oeggerli, Nat Geo Image Collection

Photo by @nadiashiracohen | Approaching Chile's Glaciar de los Témpanos, we sailed past electric blue icebergs and dodged almost transparent bergy bits. Every few minutes a loud boom echoed in the cove as chunks of the magnificent mass of ice calved into the fjord. All but two of Patagonia's glaciers are rapidly retreating due to warming temperatures. It's estimated that in as little as two decades Témpanos may no longer exist— and the land beneath it may will surge upward, no longer burdened by the weight of the ice. To see more of my work and my trip around the world by sailboat, follow me @nadiashiracohen.

Photo by @timlaman | A lesser bird-of-paradise male creates an explosion of plumes, as he gives a shake during his courtship display high in the rainforest canopy of West Papua, Indonesia.  Birds-of-paradise are perhaps the most iconic species of the rainforests of Papua, which are still more than 80 percent intact and of incredible global importance for their biodiversity and carbon storage. Follow @timlaman as I document the biodiversity of the world’s second biggest island.

Photo by Muhammed Muheisen @mmuheisen | A pleasure cruise makes its way along one of Amsterdam’s canals in summer, shortly before the sun sets. The city’s famous canals go back to the Middle Ages, when they were built primarily for defense and water management; later, during the late 16th and 17th centuries, they played a major part in Amsterdam’s commercial growth and expansion. Reflecting a mercantile spirit, many of the buildings along the canals were designed for mixed use: at once a residence, storage unit, and place of business. For more photos and videos from different parts of the world, follow me @mmuheisen.

Photo by @beverlyjoubert | Almost within reach! Watching a cheetah pursue its prey across the plains of the Masai Mara in Kenya, you can clearly appreciate the design that makes this cat the champion of the high-speed chase: the long limbs, the sleek, lightweight build, the extreme maneuverability that allows it to dodge and weave as its prey makes a desperate escape. Yet no meal is ever guaranteed … and with so much energy expended on every hunt, each missed opportunity is a potentially costly setback.

Photo by @nicholesobecki | Maasai Teresia Mwae waits for tea to be made at her friend's home near the alkaline Lake Natron, Tanzania, said to be one of the most inhospitable places on Earth. The water's extremely high salt content is poisonous to most animals and birds; many calcify if they die in the lake. The water temperature can reach a scalding 140 deg F (60 deg C). Inside the friend's house we can laze comfortably, but at midday the lake shimmers along this sun-scorched border with Kenya. For Teresia and other Maasai, this place is just called home, and bomas like this one dot the other-worldly landscape. To learn more about the remarkable world we share, follow along @nicholesobecki.

Photo by @amivitale | Two panda cubs wrestle and frolic. These adorable creatures are a testament to what can happen when we work together and value nature and our environment. 

For years the breeding secrets of pandas baffled scientists. When China first established a panda breeding program, it was not successful. Pandas were thought to be a species without a sex drive. 

Scientists have finally cracked the puzzle of captive breeding and have started reintroducing pandas to the wild. The trick? To create in captivity the conditions that appeal to the particulars of this picky animal. Scent, it turns out, is critically important to pandas, as is male competition. Males will carefully scent different parts of their body and nearby enclosures to broadcast their odor. Female pandas are in estrus just once a year, for 24 to 72 hours, so timing is critical.

The journey covering the rewilding of these endearing animals for National Geographic turned out to be one of the most unimaginable explorations I've ever had. Learn more by following @amivitale. @vital.impacts

Photo by @kiliiiyuyan | One of the things most people don’t know about me is that I love swing dancing and the exuberance of it all. Recently, I had the chance to go swing dancing at Sagebrush, a honky-tonk in Austin, Texas, with a welcome-all vibe. Folks were dressed to impress—cowboys boots and all—and spent the evening swing dancing, two-stepping, and more to live music from singer-songwriter Summer Dean. To capture the joyful energy of the place, I made a series of long exposures that resulted in the whirling of dancers around locals Billy Baca and Jace Romero. Baca is a well-known local tattoo artist who loves to two-step and embodies the city’s colorful, careening soul. | From outdoor adventures to big-city skylines, there are a million different trips to @traveltex, but the only one that matters is yours. Get your own trip to Texas.

Photo by @javier_aznar_photography | I spotted this tiny spider outside my home in Madrid. With the help of the sun illuminating it from behind, I highlighted the intricate silk web. Follow @javier_aznar_photography for more wildlife photography.

Photo by @paoloverzone | The Hoba meteorite outside of Grootfontein, Namibia, named after the farm where it was found, is the largest known in the world. Estimated to weigh more than 67 tons, it remains where it landed less than 80,000 years ago, according to radioactive dating. The meteorite is now surrounded by a tiered viewing area. The story of how early cultures used metal from meteorites appears in the June 2023 magazine and is available to read in the link in bio. Follow @paoloverzone for more images and stories.

It wasn’t long ago that swimmers splashed and surfers paddled along the beaches of Cape Cod with little thought that a great white shark might be on the hunt just feet away. But today, that reality is settling in among the popular seashore towns as white sharks return to an area they disappeared from decades ago for one simple reason: Their favorite prey, the gray seal, is back on the menu. Hunted nearly to extinction, the seal population began rebounding with the passage of the U.S. Marine Mammal Protection Act in 1972.

So, just how many white sharks are out there? That number has been hard to come by, as counting the elusive and wide-ranging predators is complicated. But researchers with the Atlantic White Shark Conservancy finally have an answer, based on an innovative combination of acoustic tracking, photographic identification, and statistical modeling. The bombshell: Some 800 sharks—and possibly up to 900—swam the waters of Cape Cod between 2015 and 2018. The findings are striking not only because of the number of sharks, but the fact that they’re concentrated along just 560 miles of protected coastline.

Read more about white sharks in Cape Cod and what scientists are doing to reduce the likelihood of shark-human encounters at the link in bio.

Photograph by Brian J. Skerry (@brianskerry), Nat Geo Image Collection

Photo by Matthieu Paley @paleyphoto | Archaeologists investigate the desert near AlUla in Saudi Arabia. Here, on the rubble-strewn plains of Harrat Uwayrid, Lauren Swift and her colleagues look at structures and tombs from the Neolithic era that probably date to more than 8,000 years ago. Under a scorching sun, Swift handed me a tiny piece of stone. "This is perhaps from an old necklace," she said. For me, witnessing this work was simply a kid’s dream come true! | Experience the extraordinary monuments and ancient history in the vast desert of #AlUla.

Al Ma’wa sanctuary in Jordan offers a second chance for animals rescued from mismanaged zoos and war zones, or confiscated from smugglers. As of April 2023, more than 2,280 animals had been rescued and offered a permanent home at the sanctuary. Our photographer Muhammed Muheisen (@mmuheisen) has visited the sanctuary regularly since 2018 documenting these creatures’ lives. His work has historically focused on people caught in the middle of chaos, on human misery and destruction—but now he's turning his lens on the animals who were also victims of conflict. Read about their stories and rare happy endings at the link in bio.

Photograph by Muhammed Muheisen (@mmuheisen)

Photo by Keith Ladzinski @ladzinski | A large bolt of lightning arcs across a highway in central New Mexico. Illuminating the sky, it let us know we were heading in the right direction as we attempted to outpace this cell.

Photo by Robbie Shone @shonephoto | Scientists race against time in their search for life inside lava tubes formed by Iceland's Fagradalsfjall volcano. Though formed two years ago, the lava tubes are still new and extremely hot, so researchers must wear cumbersome heatproof suits and airtight masks for protection. Working swiftly as their oxygen tank dwindles, they take samples for microbial studies. Similar to an astronaut’s mission, it's a search for life in extreme environments. @laventaexploringteam

A conservation effort has returned bison to the Amskapi Pikuni (Blackfeet Nation) tribal lands more than a century after the animal was nearly slaughtered to extinction.

As colonizers moved west, millions of buffalo were killed and brought to the edge of extinction. Millions more Native peoples were murdered, displaced, and forced to assimilate. By the end of the 19th century, only 300 buffalo were left in the wild and Native populations dropped to less than 300,000. Now, after more than 150 years, iinnii (buffalo) are returning to their homeland to roam free. Read the full story at the link in bio.

Photograph by Louise Johns (@e.l.johns), National Geographic Society (@insidenatgeo)

Photo by @jasperdoest | Gray seals (Halichoerus grypus) mate during the pupping season in winter. The hormonal changes in both male and female seals trigger mating. Once the nursing period is over, the females mate with a dominant male. Older males (around 10 years old) will compete with other males for “beach power,” often facing off against those just reaching maturity and possibly preventing them from mating that season. Not all males participate, though, as some may still mate depending on the size of the colony and other environmental factors. Follow @jasperdoest for more images of the wonders of nature.

Photo by @joelsartore | These remarkable-looking creatures are endangered golden snub-nosed monkeys I photographed at Ocean Park Hong Kong. This species, living in the montane forests of southwestern China where snow can last for up to four months every winter, can withstand the coldest average temperatures of any nonhuman primate in the world. Though it hasn’t been confirmed through research, some scientists believe the peculiar shape of their nose, especially the flaps of skin above their high-arching nostrils, aids in protecting against frostbite. To see more species featured in the Photo Ark, follow me, @joelsartore. @hkoceanpark

Across the U.S., heat waves have become longer, hotter, and more frequent in recent decades. For those living in humid areas, high humidity coupled with high temperatures poses an increased danger—making it harder for sweat to evaporate and cool the body.

So how do you protect yourself and your home? A few tips include: avoiding strenuous activity during the hottest parts of the day, drinking plenty of water (and not waiting until you're thirsty to do so), keeping your blinds drawn, using window reflectors, and limiting the use of heat-emitting appliances like ovens and stoves. Head to the link in bio for more.

Photograph by Tyrone Turner, Nat Geo Image Collection
Photo by @brianskerry | An adult female harp seal gives a “harp seal kiss” (sniffing her pup to make sure it’s hers before feeding) in Canada’s Gulf of St. Lawrence.

Many products on the market promise to keep away mosquitoes, ticks, and other bothersome bugs. But which products best protect against them? Not all repellents are created equal, and some don’t work at all. The repellent you might want to use depends on where you live, how long you’ll be outdoors, and which bugs you’re trying to repel.

DEET and permethrin are EPA-approved repellents, have a relatively low environmental toxicity, and are safe for humans in accepted doses. Other products such as citronella candles, essential oils, zappers, and ultrasonic devices may be EPA-certified but are less effective. Head to the link in bio to learn more.

Photograph By Felipe Dana/AP Photo

Photo by @amivitale | Ntipiyon Nonguta and her son Bernard, 1, relax with neighbors as they make beaded belts for the Loisaba Community Trust in Ewaso, a village on Kenya's Laikipia Plateau. These women are part of a community surrounding the Loisaba Conservancy. They're supported and given access to markets for their goods, and revenue from ecotourism is reinvested into Ewaso and other villages. Follow @amivitale for more stories of our interconnected world. @vital.impacts

Photo by @jasperdoest | The mystery of why the Calabria region in Italy has so many centenarians may be explained by fasting, according to Valter Longo, a biochemist from the University of Southern California. Longo theorizes that during times of poverty, people in Calabria often ate very little, typically just pasta with olive oil and legumes. To test if a diet that mimics fasting can reset the body’s metabolism, Longo is recruiting 500 people with health problems, such as obesity, from the region. Every three months, participants will consume a combination of nut-based or chocolate-crisp bars, spearmint or hibiscus tea, an algal oil capsule, vegetable soup, a multivitamin and mineral supplement, almond-and-kale crackers, olives, and a glycerol drink for five days—only enough to stave off hunger. “We are hoping to demonstrate that this changes the health of most people,” Longo says. Read more at the link in bio. Follow me @jasperdoest for more images about the science of longevity.

Photo by Orsolya Haarberg @fjellheimengalleri | Heavy wind sweeps freshly fallen snow between tracks left by wild reindeers in Norway’s Forollhogna National Park. The result: these amazing sculptures carved amid a wintry landscape. This image is part of my exhibition “REiN—Inspired by Nordic Nature,” on view in Vågå, Norway, this summer. Please follow @fjellheimengalleri for more images from the Scandinavian mountains.

In May 1845 a British explorer and naval officer, Sir John Franklin, took up the quest to find a route between the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans through Arctic waters. With orders from the British Admiralty, Franklin and a crew of 133 sailed out from the Thames. The crew was young, tough, and seasoned. Both ships were specially equipped for polar service and carried more than three years’ worth of food and drink. Despite these preparations, the expedition failed—becoming one of the grimmest chapters in the history of Arctic exploration. Read how researchers aim to shed light on its mysterious fate at the link in bio.

Photograph by Thierry Boyer, Parks Canada

Photo by @enricsala | Whitetip reef sharks gather around Roca Partida, in Mexico's Revillagigedo National Park, about 400 km (250 miles) south of the Baja peninsula. This is the largest fully protected marine area in North America, with 150,000 square km (58,000 square miles)—an area larger than Greece—under strict protection. The national park provides a refuge for whitetip reef sharks and other shark species, such as whale sharks, hammerheads, and Galapagos sharks. National Geographic Pristine Seas conducted an expedition to the Revillagigedo Islands and provided scientific research that contributed to the creation of the park, where sharks are so abundant that they can exert their ecological role at the top of the food chain.
