Their presence is vital for the health of the entire ecosystem—in contrast to the false perception of them as dangerous creatures. #SharkAwarenessDay

Enric Sala is an Explorer in Residence at the National Geographic Society and founder of its Pristine Seas initiative. @insidenatgeo @natgeopristineseas

In Gabon's Loango National Park, researchers observed a sight rarely seen in nature: chimpanzees applying insects to their injuries. The behavior—a unique demonstration of potentially advanced cultural activity—suggests that the primate species may have developed longstanding health-related behaviors that are shared among members of tight-knit groups. See the photos of this rare behavior and learn more at the the link in bio.

Photograph by Roland Hilgartner

Photo by @joelsartore | Happy World Chimpanzee Day from Ruben, a three-month-old baby chimp at Zoo Tampa. Though you can’t tell from this photo, his adoptive human "mom" was holding him from the waist down to keep him relaxed and hamming it up during our brief photo shoot. He was being hand raised by zoo staff after being rejected by his biological mother, and had largely the same needs as a human baby—including constant attention, being held, and talked to. It’s no wonder: along with bonobos, chimps are our closest living relatives, sharing 98.7 percent of our genetic blueprint. To see more species featured in the Photo Ark follow me @joelsartore. @zootampa #WorldChimpanzeeDay

Read more at the link in bio.

The Sonoran Desert toad is increasingly being caught by poachers, for recreation and profit, for what the toads carry in their bodies—5-MeO-DMT, a powerful psychotropic compound. The allure of the toad for its psychoactive properties is complicated because 5-MeO-DMT is currently being studied as a possible treatment for depression and anxiety. As the popularity of 5-MeO-DMT rises, the question now is about the ethics of animal use—especially when there is an alternative synthetic version of the drug. Read more at the link in bio.

Photograph of a Sonoran desert toad, Incilius alvarius, taken at the Tulsa Zoo by @joelsartore, Photo Ark

Photo by Matthieu Paley @paleyphoto | Near the eastern end of the Wakhan corridor, a panhandle region of Afghanistan, roads dwindle to footpaths, where a girl twists the tail of the family cow to hurry it toward their home. I was following along with Paul Salopek as he headed into the distant Pamir Mountains on his unique storytelling odyssey across the Earth. His 21,000-mile (34,000 km) walk following the path of human migration out of Africa began in 2013. For more on the Out of Eden project, go to @outofedenwalk and the link in bio. For more insights into our world, follow me @paleyphoto. #outofedenwalk

Comment which spider you think is the black widow and read the full story at the link in bio for the answer.

The world of bugs is filled with lookalike species! False widow spiders resemble their infamous cousins, black widow spiders—but pack a much less potent bite. Like black widows, these species have markings on their abdomen, though not as bright red or as distinctive as the black widow’s classic hourglass shape. The false widow is just one example of how nature has evolved lookalikes that can make it tough for people to tell one bug apart from another.

Composite of three photos. From left: Danut Vieru, Stephanie Phillips, Olimbek Shirinov, Getty Images (all)

Photo by @jasperdoest | Elephant 126, as she's known, travels through the bustling streets of Kishangarh, India, but few seem to take notice. After the elephant was captured, she was subject to months of physical and mental abuse in order to be trained to perform at weddings—she's en route to one here. Though India's 1972 Wildlife Protection Act prohibits the renting of Asian elephants for commercial activities, the animal is still seen as a status symbol and these practices persist. Follow me @jasperdoest for more on the relationship between humankind and nature.

Photo by @acacia.johnson | A musk ox roams a beach near Nome, Alaska. These arctic ungulates, survivors from the Pleistocene, were reintroduced to Alaska (via Greenland) in 1930 after the species was overhunted. Musk oxen are now a common sight near Nome. Follow me at @acacia.johnson for stories from Alaska and beyond.

Photo by @amivitale | A keeper does an evening check on Najin and Fatu at Ol Pejeta Conservancy in northern Kenya. Najin and Fatu are the last two northern white rhinos on the planet, and they're cared for 24 hours a day, seven days a week, by devoted keepers. These men spend more time with these rhinos than they do their own families. The bonds are deep, and the keepers have a profound understanding of just how precious these last northern white rhinos are. 

I've recently launched the short film “Remembering Sudan,” which documents the incredible work of Zacharia Mutai and all of the keepers and rangers who sacrifice so much to protect these creatures, including Sudan, the sole northern white rhino male. He passed away in 2018. The keepers have a profound commitment and a heavy responsibility knowing the rhinos are the last of their kind. 

Learn more at https://on.natgeo.com/43qXEhm and by following @amivitale, @olpejeta, @biorescue_project, @safariparkdvurkralove, and @vital.impacts.

Photo by @nadiashiracohen | Tyrone Washington holds his three-month-old daughter, Ritcheousness, just outside the motel room he shares with his family in northern Orlando. The family's car was rear-ended by a bus, sending Tyrone to the hospital for emergency brain surgery. He was unable to work, and the family quickly found themselves homeless. With the help of a local organization, they've been able to stay in a motel until they get back on their feet. The American motel—a concept originally intended to stimulate business travel and tourism across the country—has over the years become home to many who are unable to come up with high deposits to rent apartments, or have been evicted or foreclosed on. Florida has a large percentage of the country's homeless families, who often find temporary refuge in the motels that line its tourist strips.  To see more of my work, please follow @nadiashiracohen.

Photo by @beverlyjoubert |There’s plenty of perching room at this oxpecker gathering, in Kenya’s Chyulu Hills. An avian entourage of this size can become a nuisance, but giraffes get benefits in exchange for their tolerance. The birds offer a grooming service that helps to keep ticks and other pesky parasites under control. They’ve also been observed using their sharp beaks for some dental cleaning, picking out bits of food from the giraffes' teeth. Everywhere you look in the natural world, there are fascinating examples of adaptation and interdependence. To see more of my work, follow me @beverlyjoubert.

Read more at the link in bio.

Despite a plethora of products designed to keep birds off buildings, they're sending a clear message: Nice try.

While birds are a common urban neighbor, city residents don’t always appreciate the droppings and nesting materials our feathered friends leave behind. To keep birds off human infrastructure, light displays, netting, and even sharp metal spikes were designed. However, a new study shows that not only are some birds unbothered by long strips of barbs—they’re actually ripping the skewers off buildings and using them to build armored nurseries for their chicks.

Photograph by Auke Florian Hiemstra

Photo by @enricsala | A silky shark is seen off the coast of Gabon in 2012. I was on a research and filming expedition, in collaboration with the Waitt Foundation and the Wildlife Conservation Society, to help formulate the creation of marine protected areas. Shortly after, Gabon designated marine reserves that protected 28% of its waters, providing a safe haven for sharks and other marine life.

Enric Sala is an Explorer in Residence at the National Geographic Society and founder of its Pristine Seas initiative. @insidenatgeo @natgeopristineseas

Photo by Charlie Hamilton James @chamiltonjames | In the Indigenous Awã community of Juriti, in the Brazilian state of Maranhão, I photographed Ayhua with a black bearded saki monkey. Young monkeys such as this one cling to the hair of their hosts—a common sight as Awã women go about daily life. The Awã have a strong connection to the animals in the forests where the communities reside, particularly monkeys but also coatis and peccaries. For more go to the link in bio.

Although birth control pills on the market today are safer than when they were first introduced, there are still questions about how they work and their side effects—particularly as the FDA recently approved one version to be sold without a prescription. Here are a few common questions (and answers) about the pill:

1. Besides preventing pregnancy, how might the pill help me? All birth control pills can help make periods lighter and less painful, and lower your risk of ectopic pregnancy.

2. Will I gain weight on the pill? Studies have not found that the pill leads to significant weight gain. (The ring, patch, and intrauterine devices also aren’t associated with weight gain.) It’s tricky to blame the pill for weight gain because many factors like diet and stress can contribute.

3. Does the pill increase my chances of developing blood clots? About 1 in 3,000 women taking the pill will develop a blood clot, according to the National Blood Clot Alliance. Although this is one of the most significant risks associated with the pill, it’s still extremely rare, experts say.

Learn more about what’s true and what’s not at the link in bio.

Photograph by Emmanuel Pierrot, Agence VU/Redux

Photo by @jenguyton | In the heart of Costa Rica, I found myself traversing the emerald realm of Monteverde on a National Geographic expedition. A spectral creature emerged from the fog-shrouded foliage: the elusive, resplendent quetzal, an avatar of freedom in Maya and Aztec lore, its dazzling plumage a symbol of wealth and divinity. For a moment, the male struck a pose as we balanced precariously on a hanging bridge. In the mating season, males grow twin tail streamers up to three feet long. After I took this photo, he all but disappeared—the tips of his feathers still poking out—into his nest hole inside a hollow tree, where the males and females take turns incubating the eggs. Sadly, the continued existence of these beautiful birds is in jeopardy, as deforestation ravages their habitat. @natgeoexpeditions

Come on Barbie, let’s go ... back in history.

The natural world has long been painted with every permutation of pink, whether embedded deep in ancient rock, sported by shrimp-hungry flamingoes, or lining the shores of Bermuda’s pink-sand beaches. Yet the color carries a lot of cultural baggage. Learn more about the color's surprising history at the link in bio.

Photograph by @beckythale

Photo by Muhammed Muheisen @mmuheisen | Subway and train lines converge at New York's Grand Central Terminal, built in 1913 and one of the city's most visited sights. For more photos and videos from different parts of the world, follow me @mmuheisen.

Photo by @javier_aznar_photography | A dazzling pair of jewel weevils (Eurhinus sp.) mate on a tendril on the slopes of the Tungurahua volcano in Ecuador. After mating, the female often uses its long rostrum to bore a hole into a plant, laying eggs inside so the larvae will hatch surrounded by food to eat. Follow @javier_aznar_photography to learn more about our natural world.

Photo by @joelsartore | Alaska's North Slope has a reputation for harboring clouds of fearless mosquitoes. I learned this the hard way while on assignment there for National Geographic in 2006.

Desperate after three days without taking a single good photo, I decided to turn the camera on myself. I took off my shoes and socks in a scenic place and let the mosquitos eat me alive for 20 or so minutes. They piled on so thick they made a crackling sound. Later, my feet itched so badly that I scratched them raw for three hours straight.

There were two silver linings to this experiment: This image became one of the most talked about photos of my career, and I was given a gift certificate for a pedicure from the magazine's director of photography. I still don’t think my feet looked that bad.

Read more at the link in bio.

One hundred and twenty-five million years ago, a badger-like mammal attacked a plant-eating dinosaur three times its size—moments before a volcanic debris flow buried them both. The result is an exquisitely preserved fossil from northeastern China which shows that sometimes, the mammals bit back.

Photograph by Gang Han

Photo by @danwintersphoto | David Blaine in Rio De Janeiro, Brazil, July 23, 2023. Just a few months after he dislocated his shoulder in a nine story fall in front of a live audience in Las Vegas, a recovering David Blaine fulfills a decades-long dream of jumping off a bridge engulfed in flames as part of an episode of his new @natgeotv series “Beyond Belief with David Blaine” coming in 2024. In the series, David scours the world in search of extraordinary people—magicians, shamans, fakirs, and performers—who push themselves beyond what the world of medicine and science sees as possible. Brimming with thrill seekers and adventurists, and a vast array of extreme natural landscapes, David chose Rio de Janeiro for this extreme performance, a city full of dynamic energy and a daredevil spirit, as the place to make the jump. He connected with a champion high diver and worked with fire experts to prepare. It was fascinating to cover every aspect of this event and see all that it required to make sure it was successful. David has a true determination and a rare singular focus that surely is what allows him to be in a class of his own in pulling off these daring feats. Follow me @danwintersphoto for more adventures. #BeyondBeliefWithDavidBlaine

Photo by @tasneemalsultan | The Nabataean civilization thrived from the 4th century B.C.E. to the 2nd century C.E. Their mastery of rock-cut architecture—similar to Petra—left a captivating legacy in Hail, Saudi Arabia. Petroglyphs on the rocks also offer glimpses into the brilliance of Nabataean art.

Photo by Matthieu Paley @paleyphoto | I met Bakhik Gul, a young herder, on one of my walks across Afghanistan’s Wakhan corridor in 2005. I explained in the Wakhi language that I was a foreigner walking with my wife and our donkey, and we were alone and on our way to Pakistan, crossing over the Pamir peaks and into the Karakoram Mountains. She was unimpressed, and soon said goodbye as she rounded up her cows. Years later, while photographing along the 24,000-mile (39,000 km) route of Paul Salopek's Out of Eden walk, I passed her village again. I found her parents and gave them a print of this image. I learned she had married and moved to a village across the river, but there was no bridge to reach it. See the full story at the link in bio and follow @paleyphoto and @outofedenwalk for more.

Photo by @amivitale | Young pandas relax at China's Dujiangyan Panda Center. Among the shiest and rarest animals in the world, the giant panda spends about two-thirds of its day feeding and the remainder resting.

By breeding and releasing pandas, augmenting existing populations and protecting habitat, China is on its way to successfully saving its most famous ambassador. Learn more by reading my story at the link in bio and by following @amivitale. @vital.impacts

Read more at the link in bio.

Iceland’s volcanic peninsula has been dormant for centuries, but a new era of volcanic activity could be on the horizon. Earlier this month on July 4, the Fagradalsfjall Volcano announced its approach when southwest Iceland was rocked by more than 2,000 earthquakes in just 24 hours. Not long after, seismic activity dropped off as magma rose to shallow depths and ultimately gave way to oozing molten rock on July 10. This eruption is the peninsula’s third in a row, following on from similar lava-spewing eruptions in 2021 and 2022—and it’s unlikely to be the last. Experts say the tectonic shifts behind the recent eruptions and earthquakes are a long time coming.

Photograph by Mike Mezeul II Photography

Photo by Orsolya Haarberg @fjellheimengalleri | The spiked top of Nautgardstinden in Norway's Jotunheimen National Park emerges from retreating clouds. Fresh snow covers the landscape after the previous night's storm. This image is part of my exhibition, “Inspired by Nordic Nature,” on view in Vågå, Norway, this summer. Please follow @fjellheimengalleri for more images from Scandinavia.

Photo by @rubensalgadoescudero | Jacob Dove Basker aka Jake the Rapper, 51, originally is from New York City, but Germany has been home for 30 years. He's one of Berlin’s legendary DJs and producers, as well as a father of two children with his wife. In 2021, Berlin became the first city in the world to officially recognize nightclubs as cultural institutions. As such, the selected venues benefit from tax breaks and protection from displacement. Previously, only theaters, opera houses, museums, and concert halls held this status. 

In Berlin Jake has made a name for himself not only in the music scene but also as an articulate voice in the community he cherishes for its equalizing power. "Here everyone’s equal and everyone has a right to be there. The guy who’s cleaning the toilet can still be the DJ," he says. "There’s no elite group or bottle service. The door can never cost 50 euro. It’ll never be that way because it goes against the basic principles they [club scene] have." Follow me on @rubensalgadoescudero to see the world through my lens.

Read the full story at the link in bio.

In 1847, British explorer Sir John Franklin and his crew disappeared while searching for the fabled Northwest Passage. A National Geographic team sought to find evidence of their fate—but not without obstacles of their own. The team sailed from the Atlantic into a mazelike network of channels toward the other side of the continent, off the coast of Alaska. Along the way, their boat became trapped in a labyrinth of ice floes, and with winter approaching, they—much like the ill-fated Franklin expedition—risked being stranded in the Arctic.

Photograph by @renan_ozturk

Read more at the link in bio.

By analyzing samples taken during a record-setting swim from Hawaii to California, scientists have discovered the Great Pacific Garbage Patch—the biggest cluster of floating marine debris in the world—is teeming with life. Creatures that float near the surface, such as blue sea dragons and by-the-wind sailor jellies, mixed in with the waste in much greater quantities than previously realized.
The abundance of life suggests that efforts to entrap the garbage in these gyres could do untold damage. According to study senior author and marine biologist Rebecca Helm, "dragging massive fishing nets on the surface might have a massive impact on the life there. It might create a much larger problem than the problem we already have with the plastic." Instead, efforts should focus on keeping plastic from entering the ocean in the first place, she notes.

Photograph By Denis Riek

Photo by Dina Litovsky @dina_litovsky | One of my favorite things about travel is experiencing new cultures. On a recent trip to Fort Worth, Texas, I had the chance to meet Jose, a drover and member of the Fort Worth Herd who demonstrated cattle roping for me. Jose’s roping techniques were beautiful to watch and looked like dance moves. The Fort Worth Herd oversees one of the city’s oldest and most unique traditions: a twice-daily longhorn cattle drive along East Exchange Avenue in the Stockyards National Historic District. The events commemorate a time in the 1800s when drovers herded cattle along the Chisholm Trail. Between drives, members of the Herd educate visitors on what life was like for drovers on the trail. | From outdoor adventures to big-city skylines, there are a million different trips to @traveltex, but the only one that matters is yours. Get your own trip to Texas.

Photo by @martinedstrom | At first light, Buddhist nuns walk the streets of Nyaung-U, in Myanmar (Burma). They're out for the monastic morning ritual called pindapata—meaning "alms"—during which they collect food from community members.

Read the full story at the link in bio.

Death Valley holds the record for hottest air temperature ever recorded, a whopping 134°F (about 56°C) in 1913. But it wasn’t named after its scorching summer temps—it actually got its name from a winter disaster in 1849. The few settlers who made it out alive assigned the haunting moniker.

Photograph by Raul Touzon, Nat Geo Image Collection

Photo by @amivitale | One of the first baby orphaned elephants at Reteti Elephant Sanctuary learns how to use his trunk. Because baby elephants do not need to use their trunks while they're still drinking milk from their mother, it takes time and experimentation to get the hang of using it. Much like human babies, who come to discover their hands and feet, young elephants seem to discover their trunks as they get older. Reteti is a community-owned elephant sanctuary in northern Kenya. The elephants are rescued, rehabilitated, and sent back to the wild when they're old enough to survive on their own. This oasis where orphans grow up and learn to be wild is a story as much about the elephants as it is about the remarkable people who have committed themselves to protecting them. @r.e.s.c.u.e #WorldNatureConservationDay

Read the full story at the link in bio.

Two newly discovered objects are the source of pulses of radio waves that have arrived every 21 minutes for at least 33 years. They look like neutron stars—the dense stellar cores left behind after massive stars explode in supernovae—but they have other characteristics that astronomers can’t explain. They may even represent a new type of stellar object, unlike anything seen before.

Illustration by ICRAR

Photo by @stevenwinterphoto | It took 24 days to capture this image of a mother Bengal tiger with her cub in Bandhavgarh Tiger Reserve in India as part of a story for Nat Geo. India’s Project Tiger, launched in 1973 by then prime minister Indira Gandhi, has brought Bengal tigers back from the brink: They now number about 3,000. But today—International Tiger Day—it’s important to remember that tigers are the most endangered big cats. Four other subspecies—Sumatran, Siberian, Malay, and Indochinese—are in a precarious situation, with only a few hundred of each remaining in the wild. A sixth subspecies, the South China tiger, exists only in captivity. The good news: With protection and enough habitat, food, and water, tigers bounce back. A tigress can produce up to 15 cubs in her lifetime. Poaching for the black-market Asian trade and disappearing habitat pose the greatest threats to tigers. But as India’s efforts have shown us, we can save these magnificent animals. #InternationalTigerDay

Photo by @timlaman | Sunrise at Pantai Batu Rumah. This remote beach on the north coast of West Papua, Indonesia, is one of the key sites for sea turtle nesting, especially the endangered leatherback. Visit @timlaman for more from my filming expedition.

Photo by @beverlyjoubert | Kenya is home to one of the largest populations of rhinos in Africa, and photographing these iconic animals always brings a sense of wonder—they stand among some of the last representatives of our planet’s once abundant bestiary of megafauna. With their distinctive front horns that can grow to an average of 90cm (or almost 3ft) in length—and in the case of this individual, astonishingly longer—white rhinos and their relatives epitomize the grandeur and uniqueness of the Earth’s wildlife heritage. As demand for rhino horn continues to decimate Africa's populations, can we protect them so that future generations can also marvel at these majestic creatures in the wild? To see more of my work, follow me @beverlyjoubert.

Photo by @joelsartore | Red-flanked duikers like this one at the Los Angeles Zoo are one of the smallest species of antelope, measuring in at less than 15 inches tall and weighing no more than 31 pounds. Aside from their size, this species can be identified by the large preorbital glands on their snout, which form bulges in their cheeks. These glands produce a secretion that has multiple uses, including marking territory claimed by a single antelope or a mated pair. To see more species featured in the Photo Ark, follow me @joelsartore. @lazoo

Photo by @jenguyton | Immersed in the verdant labyrinth of Costa Rica, we explored the Monteverde cloud forest on a National Geographic expedition, where we encountered a palm pit viper (Bothriechis lateralis). This captivating contradiction of beauty and menace lives high in the canopy, which was visible to us from the unique vantage of a hanging bridge. The snake curled onto a branch, languid yet lethal, perhaps readying itself for the hunt. These vipers are sit-and-wait predators; using their prehensile tail as an anchor against a potentially deadly plunge to the forest floor, the vipers will strike at unlucky birds, lizards, or rodents that pass by. @natgeoexpeditions. #NatGeoExpeditions

Photo by Robbie Shone @shonephoto | Emerging from the intense heat of a steaming hot lava tube, three intrepid scientists are relieved to reach the surface, having just explored one of Earth’s youngest caves. This 350-meter-long (1,150-ft-long) lava tube, which has five entrances, formed during the eruption of the Fagradalsfjall volcano in Iceland only two years ago. For the team’s microbiologists, it is important to sample now, while the cave is still relatively untouched. They are searching for signs of life in this hot, hostile environment, as it could provide clues as to extraterrestrial life beneath the surface of our planetary neighbors. @laventaexploringteam

Photo by @martinedstrom | A family of elephants strolls through South Luangwa National Park in Zambia. I had been on the lookout for lions, but this scene was too stunning to miss. Follow @martinedstrom for more about the 360 video project on lions, streaming on National Geographic's Youtube channel.

Photo by Orsolya Haarberg @fjellheimengalleri | On Store Smørstabbtinden mountain in Norway’s Jotunheimen National Park, light snow falls as two skiers watch over a sublime winter landscape. Please follow @fjellheimengalleri for more images from Scandinavia.

Read the full story at the link in bio.

There are 156 known species of glass frogs living throughout the neotropics. These tiny tree dwellers are stellar fathers and masters of camouflage—and recent research is revealing even more surprises.

Photograph by Jaime Culebras

Photo by @franslanting | Tinted orange by the sun, a soaring dune is the backdrop for the hulks of camel thorn trees in Namibia's Namib-Naukluft Park. When this scene was published in the June 2011 issue as part of the feature story "Africa's Super Park," many thought it was a painting instead of a photograph. Others thought it had been altered in Photoshop. Nope. The photo shows sculptural tree skeletons on a clay pan backed by a sand dune—dotted with white grasses—glowing with early morning light. The magic moment came when the sun had illuminated the dune right down to the bottom while the clay pan was still in the shade. As a photographer I paint with light, and I look for unusual light that draws viewers into a scene. Follow me @franslanting for more images from the natural world. To read a blog post about the photograph, go to the link in bio.

Read the full story at the link in bio.

Decades’ worth of research links physical activity and exercise with positive changes in the brain in a variety of contexts. Imaging studies confirmed that the volume of the hippocampus—a region of the brain important in learning and memory—is larger in individuals who are more aerobically fit compared to their sedentary peers. Now scientists are learning how muscles in motion can improve cognition and shield against diseases like Alzheimer's, paving the way for new treatments.

Photograph by Jonathan Mehring, Nat Geo Image Collection

Photo by Matthieu Paley @paleyphoto | In the heart of AlUla, Saudi Arabia, local horse rider Majed Salem returns from an outing in the oasis, passing some of the two million date palms that provide shelter and life in the desert. The oasis and surrounding area were home to ancient cities such as Dadan and Hegra, part of the Nabataean kingdom, which included the city of Petra in present-day Jordan. | Experience the extraordinary monuments and ancient history in the vast desert of #AlUla.

Photo by @gerdludwig | It's Barbie's hot pink world, and we're just living in it. Despite a modern backlash against pink, love for the color has come rushing back. Here, in 2013, an interactive installation in central Berlin temporarily brought Barbie's dollhouse to life—pink high-heel fountain and all.

This year, Greta Gerwig's Barbie movie has played a significant role in fueling the rise of the mesmerizing "Barbiecore" aesthetic, inspiring enthusiasts to envelop their living spaces and wardrobes in a plethora of pink shades. Learn more about the surprising history of the color pink at the link in bio.

Read more at the link in bio.

From before the rise of Athens to the height of the Roman Empire, one of the most sought-after products in the Mediterranean world was a golden-flowered plant called silphion. It cured diseases and made food tasty, but Emperor Nero allegedly consumed the last stalk. Since the Middle Ages, botanical explorers inspired by ancient accounts of this miracle plant have sought it on three continents, and always in vain. Many historians view its disappearance as the first recorded extinction of any species, plant or animal. But is silphion truly extinct? Thanks to a lucky encounter almost 40 years ago—and decades of subsequent research—a professor at Istanbul University suspects it's not.

Photograph by Alice Zoo

Photo by @estherhorvath | This is the northernmost area of the planet—in Greenland—seen in a view from the Alfred Wegener Institute's Polar 6 research aircraft, which is surveying sea ice thickness in the Arctic Ocean. Follow @estherhorvath for more polar stories.

Photo by @joelsartore | A mandrill and her infant sit for an intimate portrait at the Gladys Porter Zoo in Brownsville, Texas. Mandrills usually give birth to just one baby, which is born with the ability to immediately open its eyes and cling tightly to mom’s belly. At just two months old, infants will begin to lose their baby hair, as their adult coat starts to grow in. They will stay close to their mothers until she gives birth to her next baby, at which point she will push older offspring away and turn her full attention toward caring for her newborn. To see more species featured in the Photo Ark, follow me @joelsartore. @gladysporterzoo

Photo by Mattias Klum @mattiasklumofficial | Camouflaged stalker! Allow me to introduce the true heavyweight viper of the planet: Bitis gabonica, most commonly known as the Gaboon viper, found in the rainforests and savannas of sub-Saharan Africa. This well-camouflaged beauty is not only the world's heaviest viper; it also has the longest fangs of all, up to 2 inches (5 cm), and on top of that, the highest venom yield of any venomous snake.

Scientists like my friend Zoltan Takacs study the genetic and molecular setup by collecting venom and DNA samples from these highly venomous vipers and their prey and predators. They are hopeful that the Gaboon viper may soon combat diseases. This will not affect the snakes in the wild at all, since snakes are released right after the examination and sampling. Gaboon vipers have a reputation for being slow moving and pretty cool around people. They usually hunt by ambush, often spending long periods motionless, waiting patiently for suitable prey to pass by. 

I took this picture in the Republic of the Congo. Follow @mattiasklumofficial for more pictures and films from my work on endangered ecosystems around the world.

Photo by Keith Ladzinski @ladzinski | Sunset, painting the skies of a thunderstorm in waves of color over the Texas Panhandle. During the spring and summer, it's common to see giant cells passing through this region, creating powerful and beautiful weather events such as this one. 
To see more images of storm chasing, please visit @ladzinski.

Read more at the link in bio.

For nearly four centuries until around A.D. 1600, a community of Icelanders on the west coast buried their dead on the tiny island of Haffjarðarey. Centuries later, waves and rising sea levels began to expose bones eroding from the island cemetery. Archaeologists excavating this ancient cemetery in 1945 found only bodies—a Harvard University-sponsored scientific expedition showed up earlier and removed the skulls.

Today, the missing crania sit in cardboard boxes on steel storage shelves in a Harvard museum basement. There’s interest by researchers in both Iceland and the U.S. to reunite the skulls with the rest of their bodies that are located at the National Museum of Iceland in Reykjavik. It’s not only good science, archaeologists argue, but also the morally and ethically right thing to do.

Photograph by Ívar Brynjólfsson, National Museum of Iceland

Photo by @dina_litovsky | Shuffleboard is the most popular game among Amish and Mennonite vacationers when they visit Pinecraft Park, a community park in Pinecraft, a small neighborhood in Sarasota, Florida. For many decades, Amish and Mennonite families from around the United States have been taking winter vacations in Pinecraft. The strict rules of Anabaptist life are temporarily relaxed while hard work is replaced by leisure and recreational activities, including group sports. For more photos, follow me @dina_litovsky.

Photo by Muhammed Muheisen @mmuheisen | Traumatized and neglected animals rescued from mismanaged zoos, confiscated from smugglers, and saved from war zones find a second chance at Al Ma'wa for Nature and Wildlife, a wildlife sanctuary in Jordan. 

Seen here is Yerga, a 10-year-old African lion that has lived with his four siblings at Al Ma’wa for a decade. He was rescued when he was just four days old. This image is part of my story "Unlikely Refugees," published in the August 2023 issue of National Geographic magazine. Read the full story at the link in bio. For more photos and videos from different parts of the world, follow me @mmuheisen. @almawa.jordan

Read more at the link in bio.

Mounting evidence shows that more young adults are experiencing heart problems compared to decades past, and that worsening lifestyle habits—namely, poor diet and lack of exercise—are to blame. And some research suggests that COVID infections are adding insult to injury. Perhaps the most alarming trend is that, despite declines among older adults, the proportion of heart attacks among younger adults is increasing across the globe—which many doctors who spoke to National Geographic consider a public health emergency. Young adults are loosely defined as those between 20 to 50 years old.

Cardiac arrest is not the same as a heart attack—but "the really important thing for young individuals to know is that cardiovascular disease, for the most part, can be prevented if you take the right steps," says Ron Blankstein, senior preventive cardiologist at Brigham and Women's Hospital and professor of medicine at Harvard Medical School in Boston. The AHA recommends following key measures that can improve and maintain your cardiovascular health. These include a healthy diet, regular physical activity, no tobacco smoking, and sufficient sleep, as well as managing your weight, cholesterol, blood sugar, and blood pressure.

Angiogram image by Science Source

Photo by @beverlyjoubert | Etched against a Kenyan sunset, the silhouette of a giraffe is one of those quintessential sights that captures the immense and unmistakable natural beauty of Africa. It is hard to imagine this continent without the presence of these graceful creatures. And yet the future of Africa’s giraffe species is increasingly uncertain, and their alarming decline has been called a silent extinction. There are now fewer giraffes than elephants or gorillas. Perhaps because they seem so very ubiquitous, their plight has not received the same level of attention as the continent’s other vulnerable species. If we want to preserve the iconic sight of these long-necked giants etched against African skies, we need to do more to raise awareness and support their conversation. To see more of my work, follow me @beverlyjoubert. For a related story about a bold plan to save the giraffe, tap the link in bio.

Read more at the link in bio.

The designation of the land as a national monument, confirmed to National Geographic this week by the White House, will prevent new uranium mines and protect historically significant tribal lands. The decision by @potus is the culmination of a lobbying effort by a dozen tribes who have historical ties to the site and advocated for its monument status. It will be called Baaj Nwaavio I’tah Kukveni Grand Canyon National Monument—the Ancestral Footprints of the Grand Canyon National Monument.

The site encompasses natural habitat for the critically endangered California condor and an important watershed for the Colorado River, which provides water to 40 million Americans. It’s also habitat for desert bighorn sheep, and birds including the threatened western yellow-billowed cuckoo and the endangered southwestern willow flycatcher.

Photograph by Pete McBride @pedromcbride

Read more at the link in bio.

Having a glass of wine or other "nightcap" before bed has long been thought of as a way to help someone sleep, but a look at the evidence suggests otherwise. Even a small amount of alcohol can make sleep worse by elevating your heart rate and interfering with REM sleep, for example. Drinking alcohol is also linked to a higher risk of sleep apnea, in general, and to more severe snoring and obstructive sleep apnea in those who already have these health problems.

Photograph by Sarah Muenzenmayer, Nat Geo Image Collection

Photo by @martinedstrom | A lone paddler travels on the Huallaga River, part of Peru's Amazon Basin. A few years ago, I had the privilege of documenting the daily life of a few families in this area. Scenes like this weren't extraordinary to them—but they were to me. Follow @martinedstrom for more on the story.

Photo by @franslanting | During a recent voyage to Norway's Svalbard archipelago, high in the Arctic, the temperature was more than 60 degrees F (15 C) for days on end. It's the fastest warming place on Earth. That's bad news for the polar bears here and for people, no matter where you live. Follow me @franlanting for more images and stories about our changing planet.

Learn more at the link in bio.

A significant new study—the first of its kind—shows that the nutrients found in walnuts, seeds, and certain types of seafood can reduce inflammation caused by aging, and improve declining lung function. Obtaining omega-3s, either through food sources or supplements, is vital—especially because most people aren't getting nearly enough.

Photography by Erika Larsen @erikalarsen888

Photo by Keith Ladzinski @ladzinski | Each year about three million tourists visit Munich, the capital of Bavaria, to take in the sights. The central square of Marienplatz has been a prominent gathering point since the 12th century. Today it's a hub of festivity and food and the occasional giant panda sighting—and a great place for a photographer.

Photo by @joelsartore | When they’re born, coyote puppies are blind and limp-eared. It isn’t until they are around 10 days old that their eyes open and their ears begin to stand erect. Pups like these at Nebraska Wildlife Rehab won’t finish growing until they're between 9 and 12 months old, at which point males will venture off on their own, while females will remain with their parents and form the basis of the pack. To see more species featured in the Photo Ark follow me @joelsartore.  @newildliferehab #PhotoArk

Read more at the link in bio.

When King Henry VIII's wife Anne Boleyn was executed in 1536, her Book of Hours went missing for centuries. A recent discovery reveals a string of women who secured the book for decades after her death.

Photograph courtesy of Hever Castle & Gardens

Photo by @javier_aznar_photography | A dead pine (Pynus silvestris) seems to lie in repose in Sierra de Guadarrama National Park, located outside Madrid. Its intricate branches now house species such as the red ant (Formica rufa). The beauty of these trees makes this forest a magical place. Follow @javier_aznar_photography for more wildlife photography.

Photo by @amivitale | Today is World Elephant Day! A world without elephants would impact us all. Elephants are our ecosystem "engineers” because they shape habitats in a multitude of ways. They're huge mobile composting units. They create water sources in dry landscapes by digging wells with their tusks. They move seeds across vast landscapes. They clear paths through dense vegetation that ultimately benefit other animals and people.

The Reteti Elephant Sanctuary in northern Kenya is changing the lives of both elephants and people. This extraordinary group does so much to rescue, rehabilitate, and rewild elephant calves that are orphaned as a result of drought, human-wildlife conflict, natural mortality, and in rare cases, poaching. Here, Mary Lengees comforts one of the calves. Lengees and most of the team at Reteti were recruited from the local community and are deeply devoted to caring for these animals. They have done so much through hope, resilience, and imagination. Follow @amivitale to learn more about what we're doing to support elephants. @r.e.s.c.u.e @vital.impacts #WorldElephantDay

Photo by Aaron Huey @argonautphoto | The alpha female of the Iron Creek wolf pack breaks a trail through fresh snow, followed by her male partner and their kin in Alaska's Denali National Park. Today is International Wolf Day, a moment to remind ourselves how these apex predators shape ecosystems, regulate prey populations, and help uphold the intricate balance and the wild spirit of places like Denali. Their presence supports many other wildlife, from the scavengers feasting on the remains of their hunts to the plants flourishing due to balanced herbivore numbers. I watched this pack over the course of three days as they devoured a moose, and then I was lucky enough to catch them as they left that site, crossing this large, unbroken field. In other parts of the park with less snow, it was harder to see the wolves in the patchy brown and green of the trees. This shot was the result of a little luck, but mostly relentless searching for the right pack in the right photo conditions. The payoff was worth the time put in! For more glimpses into the wild lives of Denali's wolves, follow @argonautphoto. #InternationalWolfDay

Photo by @rubensalgadoescudero | Thomas Benedix is one-half of the DJ duo Pan-Pot. Here, in August 2021, he streamed a performance from his living room, with his wife and two children dancing along. Pan-Pot usually plays in front of festival crowds exceeding 20,000 fans. With the pandemic, the team, along with all musicians, adapted to meet their audience.

Photo by Matthieu Paley @paleyphoto | Kyrgyz children play in the wide expanses of the Pamir mountains in northeastern Afghanistan. The country's Kyrgyz nomads live in one of the most remote high-altitude landscapes on Earth. Much of it lies above 14,000 feet (4,267 meters), and temperatures can fall below freezing 340 days a year.

Photo by @estherhorvath | Dennis Kærgård Larsen, a soldier at Station Nord, Greenland's northernmost research and military base, trains the station's two dogs, Obelix and Dirk, for sledding. Work in this place is solitary, and the dogs are companions to those posted at the remote site for long periods. As a photographer covering Arctic stories, I found one of the most beautiful things was interacting and bonding with these local dogs. Please follow @estherhorvath for more polar stories.

Photo by Robbie Shone @shonephoto | We have just returned home from exploring some of the most northern caves on Earth for science. We have a lot to digest as we prepare to unveil our discoveries. In the meantime, here is a photograph, taken on this trip, from a typical arid valley from the vast Wulff Land peninsula, located right in the middle of the north of Greenland. Stay tuned as there’s a lot more to come from a very, very remote part of our planet. @greenland_caves

Photo by @nicholesobecki | Driving through a drought-stricken area of western Somaliland, I came across a group of women washing their clothes in a roadside puddle—the only water they could find. We spoke for a while of the challenges they faced, the animals they’d lost in the drought, and the wells that had dried up. Somalia has long been a place of extremes, but climate and environmental changes are compounding those problems and leading to the end of a way of life. As the women turned to walk home, I took this image of one of them in a field of cacti. The colors of her scarf melded into the vegetation and sky, and I was reminded of how intimate the ties are between people’s lives and the land. What we call our voice is profoundly shaped by the stories we see, hear, and internalize every day. They’re how we give shape to the world beyond our own limited experience. Stories can help guide our choices, and change us—sometimes radically. I hope images like these can reenforce our connection to the natural world and break down the false pride in our separateness that enables harmful behaviors toward our shared planet and one another. 

Read more about how women are coping with climate change in the Horn of Africa in the link in bio. For photography that reveals remarkable world we share, follow along @nicholesobecki.

Leading up to World Photography Day on August 19, we’re celebrating photography by sharing impactful stories told through the lenses of National Geographic Photographers. #WorldPhotographyDay

Read the full story at the link in bio.

Bears know when it’s trash day, coyotes learned to look both ways before crossing the street, and raccoons can untie bungee cords. As more scientists study the creatures right under our noses, a consistent message is emerging: Many species are adapting to urban life in unprecedented ways. It’s a phenomenon happening in urban areas around the world. The more we understand the animals living in our midst, ecologists say, the better we can get along with these urban newcomers.

Photograph by Corey Arnold  @arni_coraldo

Photo by @sofia_jaramillo5 | Filmmaker and photographer Jr Rodriguez casts during the golden hour in the Teton River near Driggs, Idaho, while filming Wading for Change. The movie was recently selected by the National Geographic Short Film Showcase and premieres on National Geographic's YouTube page August 16. In Texas, where Jr grew up, he started fishing without fancy gear or vast landscapes as his backdrop. His love for the outdoors was solidified during family outings and alongside his Latinx community. The film shows how passion for the outdoors can blossom through community, regardless of economic status, location, or skin color. Follow @sofia_jaramillo5 for more conservation images from around the world.

Photo by @maggiesteber | Robb and Alesia Stubblefield hug daughter Katie, a few months after her face transplant in Cleveland. Katie attempted suicide when she was 18 years old after a heartbreak. She put the barrel of a rifle below her chin and pulled the trigger, destroying the front of her face and damaging her vision. When I met Katie and her family, she had gone through multiple surgeries for several years. Her parents quit their teaching jobs to care for her. Every day was spent at doctor’s offices.

Katie was always in pain. Her parents were always at her side to fight for her to receive the best treatments. Cleveland Clinic was paying for all of Katie’s medical care, as she was the youngest face-transplant candidate it had seen. Working with her might move the science of face transplants forward. Only National Geographic magazine would give us three years to work with such a fragile story in order to make honest, intimate, and informative photographs.

Finally a face became available for Katie. A young woman her age went into a coma from a drug overdose. Her grandmother donated her granddaughter’s face to Katie. It was a chance for Katie and her parents to move forward. Over time, watching Robb and Alesia so closely, I thought of them as eagles, their wings spread flying over the nest of their young one, protecting and encouraging her, and believing this day would come. They were warriors for their daughter. I hoped this photograph would show their love, faith, grief, determination, and strength that comes from the deepest devotion. Read the full story in the link in bio.

Leading up to World Photography Day on August 19, we’re celebrating photography by sharing impactful stories told through the lenses of National Geographic photographers. #WorldPhotographyDay

Photo by Orsolya Haarberg @fjellheimengalleri | After spending a cold night at 2,100 meters (6,900 ft) above sea level, my friend Signe Kvarberg and I woke up in our bivy bags surrounded by thick fog on Mount Loftet in Norway. It was magical to see the clouds open up in the higher regions and make “waves” around the snow-covered Smørstabbtindane in the early morning hours. The group of mountains is part of Jotunheimen National Park. This image is part of my exhibition “REiN—Inspired by Nordic Nature,” on view in Vågå, Norway, this summer. Please follow @fjellheimengalleri for more images from the Scandinavian mountains.

Learn more at the link in bio.

Some of the most important—and most endangered—tidal flats are found surrounding the Yellow Sea along the shores of China and the western side of the Korean peninsula. For decades, people have transformed them into industrial sites and farms, squeezing them into smaller areas and pushing some species to the brink of extinction. But as science increasingly shows how wetlands like these benefit wildlife and help fight climate change, South Korean scientists and conservationists are gaining momentum in their effort to save and restore what’s left—becoming a blueprint for tidal flat conservation and ecotourism.

Photograph by National Geographic Explorer Youngrae Kim @raeraekim

Photo by Karine Aigner @kaigner | Few words can describe what it’s like to be on a platform high in the rainforest canopy, 80 feet (25 m) away from but at eye level with one of the world's most powerful raptors. Each morning before daylight I'd climb the tower’s narrow staircase, 90 feet (27.5 m) into the tree canopy. I’d set up my gear, take in the symphony of a slowly awakening rainforest, and spend the day, rain, shine, wind or hail (yes, HAIL!), atop the tower watching something most never lay eyes on: a harpy eagle family. For three days, mom, dad, and a tiny two-week-old chick went about their business of living. The air was sweltering, bees were interested in my lunch, sent up by pulley, and rains blasted through with little warning. As the tower swayed and the weather roiled, I made image after image. Harpia harpyja is one of the largest eagles—with a wingspan of 6.5 feet (some 2 m), rear talons up to 4 inches (10 cm) long, and a weight of 9-20 pounds (4-9kg). The female is twice the size of the male. This eagle is an elusive hunter, with legs as thick as human wrists. It feeds on sloths, howler monkeys, armadillos, baby deer, even peccaries. Not for a second was I scared … only blown away with respect for one of the most amazing raptors I’ve been privileged to spend time with. An eagle pair spends two years raising just one chick. The species is threatened by habitat loss and other human-related activity. Read about Brazilian researcher Everton Miranda's efforts to help save this eagle from extinction in the October 2020 issue. Follow @kaigner for more wildlife stories.

Leading up to World Photography Day on August 19, we're celebrating photography by sharing impactful stories told through the lenses of National Geographic photographers. See more photos at the link in bio. #WorldPhotographyDay

Photo by @joelsartore | The International Wolf Center in Ely, Minnesota, had a "study pack" of wolves in an outdoor enclosure. Researchers could observe their behavior year round, and tourists would stop by to see if they could get a glimpse.

I asked what the wolves ate. One of the biologists said the roads department would bring road-killed deer up a couple times a week. They'd throw the entire carcass in, then let the wolves tear it up and devour it just as they would in the wild. I thought this might make a good opportunity for a remotely operated camera. I called it "The Carcasscam."

I was there for a week, which gave me two opportunities to embed a small, radio-triggered camera next to the carcass. The NG Photo Engineering Lab created a heavy plexiglass sphere with a lens port, into which the camera was placed. The device was wide enough so a wolf couldn’t get its jaws around it and crush it. The bottom of the sphere had a tripod mount so the rig could be screwed into a sheet of plywood that we placed the deer on.

The first time I tried it, all I got were pictures of the wolves’ furry throats as they ate the deer from the back side of the camera.

Two or three days later, when the second deer was brought into the pen, I moved the deer and camera to the opposite side, with lots of open plywood behind the camera. I figured the wolves would not want to walk on a hard, strange surface like that, and I was right. This time they approached to eat facing the camera, with their paws never leaving the snow. 

This photo was made at the moment the alpha wolf, a female, was snarling at pack mates to stay away until she'd eaten. The blurry area on her throat was where she'd licked the lens port, trying to figure out what it was before tearing into her meal.

Today is World Photography Day! We're celebrating photography by sharing impactful stories told through the lenses of National Geographic photographers. See more photos at the link in bio. #WorldPhotographyDay

Photo by Keith Ladzinski @ladzinski | On the exposed plains of Tornado Alley—a vertical swath of the central United States that's prone to the storms—one can get caught in the crosshairs of harsh weather throughout much of the year. A small herd of horses restlessly dances under the dark clouds of a supercell storm over southern New Mexico. It wasn't long before heavy rain and hail began to fall, and with nowhere to run, the only option was to simply take what nature brings.

Photo by @timlaman | The reefs within Indonesia's Raja Ampat archipelago are the richest in the world in coral and fish species. Here's a lush example of underwater life—a photographic gift when two groupers passed through in perfectly complementary positions to balance the scene. With incredibly diverse reefs, one rarely lacks for subject matter, but creating a readable image out of the "chaos" can be a challenge. When a scene liike this comes together, it's very satisfying. You can see more of my underwater imagery from Raja Ampat @timlaman.

Photo by Luján Agusti @lujanag | In Argentina's Tierra del Fuego, I was on assignment to document the long-established Baqueanos family, who work the land, raise cattle, and love horses. People in the Tierra del Fuego often have a deep bond with the land they live on. It's a harsh and unforgiving territory, but it's also a place of great beauty and abundance. The Baqueanos have learned to live in harmony with it, and their horses are their essential partners.

A gaucho (cowboy) knows the cycles of the animals and the land like few others do. Spending time with Alvino “El Chino” Velázquez was surprising and enriching. This portrait was taken at the end of yerra, an annual event in which the foals are branded and the needs of each of the horses are attended to. It's always done in December, when the days are long and there are only a few hours of darkness. At this late time of night, the horses had returned to their forest home and all was quiet. Read more at the link in bio and follow me at @lujanag to learn more about my homeland of Tierra del Fuego.

Read more at the link in bio.

Alpha-gal is a sugar molecule that might just cause you to become allergic to meat. The molecule is spread from the Lone Star tick bite, named for the single star-shaped spot marking on its back. Alpha-gal syndrome was originally found primarily in the southeastern U.S.—but as the climate has warmed, ticks have begun to spread farther north.

Photograph by @joelsartore

Photo by @beverlyjoubert | Wildlife migrations resonate with us humans on a profound level. They are a reminder of the tenacity of life and the remarkable adaptability and resilience of nature. Africa is the stage for some of the planet’s most iconic migratory spectacles, and it is hard to imagine the continent without them. At this time of year, the grasslands of Kenya’s Masai Mara fill with the bellowing of vast herds of wildebeest on their famed cyclical trek, in search of lush grazing grounds. The significance of extraordinary journeys like this one goes far beyond just their visual splendor. Migrations are critical to the delicate balance of ecosystems, stitching habitats together and infusing vitality into landscapes. With threats like climate change and ever expanding development now placing so many migrations at risk, we have a shared responsibility to protect them. To see more of my work, follow me @beverlyjoubert.

Photo by @chrisburkard | I find landscapes inspiring but also our interaction with them beautiful and worthy of documentation. On a cold night in 2015, Stellisee, a lake in Zermatt, Switzerland, seemed like the perfect place to capture the Milky Way juxtaposed with a single viewer. A notable lack of wind allowed for a reflection to emerge, providing the moment I was looking for—and one I hoped others would imagine themselves in when seeing the photo.

Read more at the link in bio.

Whoever put Bocksten Man in the murky water could have been trying to hide their crimes, perhaps hoping the evidence would disintegrate in the depths. But a peat bog’s natural chemistry can slow the decay of human remains—allowing archaeologists to put a face to the mysterious man in the bog.

Photograph by Charlotta Sandelin/Halland Museum of Cultural History

Discover more at the link in bio.

The night sky is so vast; where do you start? Finding your way through the sky begins with a few dominant constellations, containing everything from star clusters and nebulae to obscure galaxies. Learning how to spot them will turn you into a star gazer.

Photograph by @babaktafreshi

Photo by @nicholesobecki | This April 2020 image features Daniel Owino, a musician who goes by the name Futwax, and his four-year-old son, Julian Austin, as they performed his ballad “Have you sanitized?” As fear of the COVID-19 virus began to grow, Futwax, who lives in the Kibera area of Nairobi, Kenya, decided he could help though his music. “We have to be our own solution," he says. 

I’m grateful to have been able to call Nairobi home for the last 12 years, and to have the opportunity to document this difficult moment for the city and world through the eyes of people like Daniel. To learn more about the remarkable world we share, follow along @nicholesobecki.

The Netherlands lacks almost every resource long thought to be necessary for large-scale agriculture. So how has this small, densely populated country become the world’s number two exporter of food as measured by value? Find out at the link in bio.

Photograph by Luca Locatelli @lucalocatelliphoto

Photo by @robertclarkphoto | For a story on the evolution of dog breeds, editor Kurt Mutchler and I decided to set up a photo studio at the Hotel Pennsylvania, across from New York's Madison Square Garden—site of the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show. The hotel has been used as the "bedroom" for the show for decades. 

I approached the portrait sessions with the dogs just as I would with people. A little tilt of the head, a small gesture, or a look in the eye are what makes a picture interesting to me. I was struck by the face and body language of Denzil, a Douge de Bordeaux aka French mastiff, a breed that originated as a war dog and later guarded French hunting estates. Though no longer used as guard dogs, they remain protective of their families and are often seen looking out the window on alert. The dog is now recognized for its face and accompanying slobber—remember the movie Turner & Hooch? For more on the process of selective breeding that has transformed the gray wolf into an almost unlimited number of variations, go to the link in bio. #InternationalDogDay

Photo by @amivitale | Rimland Lemojong, a Samburu elephant keeper, sits with Kinya, a two-week-old elephant that was orphaned after falling into a water well in northern Kenya. A team from the Reteti Elephant Sanctuary waited close to 36 hours for her mother to return. She never came back, so the team rushed the infant to the sanctuary to care for her. Reteti is Africa's first community-owned elephant sanctuary, where orphans learn to be wild so that one day they can rejoin their herds. Read the full story at the link in bio and follow @amivitale to learn more about the conservation work happening there. @r.e.s.c.u.e

Photo by @iantehphotography | I love this vibrant scene of subantarctic moorland and Magellanic beech trees set against the sea, their gnarly, bare branches sculpted by the constant furious winds. I took this photo on my last day on Hornos Island, at the tip of South America. The expedition team and I had endured climatic mood swings, from icy gales and rain to brilliant sunshine—often in 20-minute cycles. The team was exhausted, hungry, and jubilant. We had, after all, found the world’s southernmost tree.

I decided to explore the scenery we had trudged past in previous days as I followed the team on its primary mission. Now with the relief that we had accomplished what we had set out to do, I felt free to hunt for other creative possibilities. Some of the landscape on Cape Horn reminds me of Cornwall in England, except brighter and more saturated with color. You’d expect a pleasant stroll through these technicolor meadows, but the trees are sometimes hidden in creeks, making the ground appear flat until it’s too late. As I enjoyed the last moments of walking toward the lighthouse to catch my ride home, I plunged into the ground. My arms splayed, a gesture of surprise that saved me from dropping any further through the brush-camouflaged aperture and into the running water below my dangling feet. Grabbing at the surrounding vegetation, I crawled out gingerly. Half an hour later, with the island’s parting gift to me in my camera, I was relieved, grateful, and happy in a Zodiac riding out with the last of the team to our wooden boat, the Oveja Negra. Read the full story at the link in bio, and follow me @iantehphotography to see more images and stories from around the world.

Read more at the link in bio.

What does climate change sound like? Visitors to Chile's legendary glaciers can hear the answer: The majestic silence of Patagonia's vast ice fields is increasingly shattered by the sound of cracking ice.

Photograph by @tamaramerino_photography

Photo by Charlie Hamilton James @chamiltonjames | I was in Tanzania’s Serengeti National Park shooting a story on vultures and knew I needed an image that classically represented both the beauty and the grotesque. Photographing the vultures as they frenzied over a carcass was chaotic and fast, and I found it hard to really grasp the essence of who the birds were and what was going on. One evening while going through my day’s photos at camp, I noticed a drop of blood falling from a vulture’s beak. The image was bad, but I saw something in it. Over the next three weeks, I focused my attention on capturing a drop of blood and eventually, after tens of thousands of images, got this split second. I often find that the early stages of a shoot are about learning; the rest is about refining.

Photo by Prasenjeet Yadav @prasen.yadav | These fascinating living root bridges, known locally as jingkieng jri, are found in the foothills of the Himalaya, in India's Meghalaya state. The bridges are a force of nature and human ingenuity, and I was humbled to learn about the intertwined root structures from people whose ancestors crafted them about 200 years ago. For a magazine story, we wanted to show them in a new way. After brainstorming with fellow photographer and lighting inspiration  @anandavarma, we decided to make nighttime portraits, using artificial lighting to isolate the big green bridges from their never-ending rainforest background. With the massive size of these Ficus elastica trees, the project was tricky. But after weeks of trying, the resulting images were close to what we had in mind: to make them look like they're right out of Lord of the Rings. Follow me @prasen.yadav for more photos from India.

Read more at the link in bio.

Power struggles? Drought? Overpopulation? The Maya collapse has been studied by countless scholars, who have developed fascinating theories to solve the mystery of what happened. The remains of Maya architecture in the jungle provide intriguing insights into the speed of the collapse.

Photograph by Alfredo Matus/Alamy/ACI

Photo by @franslanting | Emperor penguins are in serious trouble. Unlike penguins that gather on solid ground to raise their young, emperors are totally dependent on sea ice. Their chicks are born in late winter when the ice is thick, and they are ready to go to sea in late summer. But now Antarctica’s sea ice is melting more rapidly. Last year, many thousands of young emperor chicks died because the ice literally melted from under their feet, and they drowned before they were ready to swim. 
 
I spent a month camping on sea ice next to an emperor colony and marveled at the penguins' ability to deal with extreme cold. But they are not adapted to the other extreme: warmth. As our planet heats up, we are as vulnerable as emperors, but only we have the power to influence their future—and our own. 

Follow me @franslanting for more stories from the front lines of a changing planet.

Photo by @spencerlowell_ | This is Curi, a robot made by the brilliant minds at Georgia Tech's Socially Intelligent Machines Lab in Atlanta, Georgia. Socially intelligent robots are poised to grasp emotions and social cues, unlocking doors across health care, education, and customer service realms. It's a tantalizing glimpse into a future where machines like Curi might elevate our lives through empathy and unparalleled support but also sparks contemplation about the delicate balance between innovation and the authenticity of human connection. Read the full story at the link in bio.

Photo by @bertiegregory | Who can tell me what animal this extraordinary eye belongs to? I’ll follow up with the answer along with fun facts about the animal tomorrow!

Captured for #AnimalsUpClose, coming to @disneyplus September 13.

Learn more at the link in bio.

As Washington State cougars target wolves, scientists are grappling to understand this unusual behavior—although some neighboring states have five times as many wolves, Washington is documenting far more of these kills. “Everyone always assumes wolves have the upper hand,” says one scientist. “But that’s not always the case.”

Photograph by Bob Gibbons/Alamy

Photo by @amytoensing | I was invited to a Bedouin wedding while traveling in the Sinai peninsula in Egypt in 2008 and was fortunate to end up in a private area with the bride and her family. Music was playing, and the girls in this image were so excited to dance for the bride. I love how photography freezes moments that might otherwise be overlooked or unknown—a magical time machine that gives us a chance to consider our world a little deeper over and over again.

Known as the greatest manuscript discovery of modern times, the Dead Sea Scrolls gave us a glimpse into Jewish life at the time of Jesus. So what insights do they provide on how his teachings took shape? Find out at the link in bio.

Photograph by @paoloverzone

Photo by Ivan Kashinsky @ivankphoto | Girls play outside in La Puente, California, after a Mass for their first Communion. This image was made on assignment with National Geographic Explorer Karla Gachet @kchete77 and published in the feature “How Latinos Are Shaping America’s Future.” Read the full story at the link in bio.

Photo by Daniella Zalcman @dzalcman | This photo is the result of a happy accident in the wake of failure. I had traveled to the Havasupai reservation—a fairly hard-to-reach Native community at the bottom of the Grand Canyon—hoping to speak with the tribal council about an ongoing project tied to survivors of the Indian Boarding School system in the U.S. After a few hours, the council confirmed they couldn't fit me in on the agenda for that day but suggested I hike to Havasu Falls before I left. Two miles down the road, I came across this scene—one of the most beautiful landscapes I've ever seen. To read an installment of the project, go to the link in bio.

Learn more at the link in bio.

When it comes to the hierarchy of healthy eating patterns, the Mediterranean diet consistently comes out on top. It’s easy to follow, is balanced and flexible, and helps prevent chronic diseases that shorten lives.

Photograph by Jad Davenport, Nat Geo Image Collection

Photo by Prasenjeet Yadav @prasen.yadav | This image was taken a few years ago on a steep cliff overlooking two small villages in India’s remote Spiti Valley, but it can be traced directly back to a photograph taken some 50 years ago. In 1970 pioneering wildlife biologist George Schaller snapped the first recorded photo of a snow leopard in the wild, and for nearly two decades afterward, it would remain the only known image of the so-called ghost cats that prowl the Roof of the World. 

In 2018 Prasenjeet was funded by the National Geographic Society to photograph snow leopards in his native India. By that time, camera traps had helped to bring the creatures into a somewhat better view, but they still remained highly elusive. He spent months with local researchers exploring high-altitude gorges and icy ridgelines in subfreezing temperatures, scouting for just the right spots to set up his camera traps. “I had to discover how to think like a snow leopard,” Prasenjeet says. This camera trap image was taken close to a high pasture where ibex and blue sheep, the cats' favored prey, graze. “This was one of my first pictures,” he says. “You think the cat looks startled? You should’ve seen my face when I opened the camera trap and found this image.” 

Text by Peter Gwin, who wrote the article accompanying Yadav’s images of snow leopards. To read the story, go to the link in bio.

Photo by @chrisburkard | If you watch raw lava emanate from a volcanic fissure, then listen to the cracking and popping as it settles to cool—it's almost impossible not to feel a connection with the eruption. During my assignment to document the Meradalir volcano, I focused on capturing the scale of this natural phenomenon, trying to communicate the feeling of standing at the foot of a new eruption within the mossy hills of the Reykjanes Peninsula. 

An unforgettable series of events led to this image being selected to live among the National Geographic's Photos of the Year for 2022. Follow me for more.

Photo by @kiliiiyuyan | I’m on assignment on the Ningaloo Reef, in the sparkling waters off Western Australia. This was one of those times when I was actually doing what my friends think I do all the time: swimming with whale sharks and diving with gorgeous lionfish over red coral. This is a fringing reef with nutrients from an offshore upwelling, which attracts everything up to Ningaloo’s charismatic big three: humpbacks, whale sharks, and manta rays. Thanks to protections from UNESCO and a dedicated local community, 45,000 humpbacks migrate through each year, and you can be in the water as they cruise by or—for the adventurous—feel small swimming next to a whale shark. 
 Follow me, @kiliiiyuyan, for more beyond the sea.

Read more at the link in bio.

From immune system disorders to breast cancer, alcohol-related complications in women are rising as the gender gap in drinking narrows. Federal guidelines recommend that women who want to drink consume no more than one serving a day. But from a health perspective, less—or none—is a better target.

Photograph by Artur Widak, NurPhoto/Getty Images

Photo by @thomaspeschak | Presented by @Rolex | Today is Amazon Day! To celebrate, I'm sharing this image of snowy Nevado Auzangate. Fringed in clouds against the star-studded night sky, Nevado Auzangate, at 20,940 feet the highest mountain in the Andes of southern Peru, looms large above a waterfall. Glacial melt is an important freshwater source for many ecosystems downstream, so to protect the ecological functioning of the Amazon Basin, it's not enough to focus on the majestic lowland rivers. Major upstream headwater regions, including those situated high in the Andes, need to be an integral part of any conservation strategy. Read more at the link in bio. #AmazonDay | This expedition was supported by Rolex and its Perpetual Planet Initiative, which is partnering with the National Geographic Society on science-based expeditions to explore, study, and document change in the planet's most unique regions #PerpetualPlanet

Photo by @brianfinke | I started documenting New York City "bike life" in the summer of 2020, and though the sport is almost year-round, I found that the long days and hot light of summer complement bike life's spirit of freedom and play and exploration.
 
In this image, bikers Emmanuel De La Rosa and Albert Acosta surf on their bikes while riding over the RFK Bridge. You can’t see it here, but there are no rails at that point of the bridge—and we were very high up.
 
Bike life is a community that borders on a movement: artistic, social, and expressive. The scene is composed predominantly of young adults and teens from diverse backgrounds and genders from all around the city who, through bike tricks—wheelies, swerving, dancing, and surfing—express a sort of creative language and personal style.
 
Gatherings happen regularly as "rideouts," where from 10 to 1,500 bikers ride en masse, weaving through the city for 10 to 35 miles, all while mesmerizing bystanders with a parade of stunts and choreographed and freestyle compositions. Bike life’s circulating message—“We’re outside”—speaks to a certain vibe of freedom and positivity, staying true, and celebrating and lifting up one another's individual styles, not only on the bike but also in the world, in being.

Learn more at the link in bio.

The astonishing discovery of four swords from nearly 2,000 years ago evokes ancient rebellions—and offers unprecedented opportunity for scientific investigation. These artifacts made of metal or organic materials like wood and leather rarely survive centuries of exposure to the elements—but the unique microclimate of what is now known as the Cave of Swords has preserved the iron blades intact with their sheaths, guards, and handles.

Photograph by @paoloverzone

Read more at the link in bio.

The name itself is both alarming and self-explanatory: the death cap mushroom. Unlike an edible mushroom—which they can be hard to distinguish from—death caps can cause extreme damage to the liver and kidneys, or in some cases, death. In fact, they're responsible for 90 percent of the mushroom-related fatalities that occur every year.

Photograph By Yves Lanceau/Nature Picture Library

Photo by @joelsartore | This fiery-colored bird is a crimson topaz hummingbird I photographed while visiting Weltvogelpark, a bird park in Walsrode, Germany. Found in the rainforests of northeastern South America, this hummingbird species uses its bright colors to mark and defend territory, with males flashing their feathers toward potential intruders. The species is predominantly solitary, and a male's territory includes his mate and their chicks—no other males or mated pairs from the same species are allowed. To see more species featured in the Photo Ark, follow me @joelsartore. @weltvogelpark #PhotoArk

Read more at the link in bio.

Until now, the earliest architectural evidence found in and around the tomb complex dated to the Crusader period, making it no older than 1,000 years.

While it is archaeologically impossible to say that the tomb is the burial site of Jesus of Nazareth, new dating results put the original construction of today’s tomb complex securely in the time of Constantine, Rome’s first Christian emperor.

Photograph by Oded Balilty, AP for National Geographic

Photo by @amytoensing | A curious hand checks out the tiger’s tongue on the carousel during the last weekend of the New York State Fair in Syracuse, where more than 900,000 attended this year over its 13-day run. The country’s first state fair was held in Syracuse in September 1841. Today there are about 2,000 county and state fairs nationwide.

Photo by @thomaspeschak | Mozambique's Niassa Special Reserve upends the myth of Africa’s pro­tected areas as Edens untouched by human presence. For thou­sands of years people here have gathered food from the land and coexisted with wildlife. They weren’t displaced when the reserve was created, and some now help maintain this conservation wilderness, with its braided rivers and jutting granite inselbergs. 

I spent three months photographing the relationship between people and wildlife in this remote corner of Africa. Niassa is one of the most fascinating places on the planet. I had the privilege of witnessing a nocturnal honey harvest by firelight in a giant baobab tree and had close encounters with dozens of baboons at a sacred ceremonial site. Read the full story at the link in bio.

Photo by @brentstirton | Kaudulla, Sri Lanka: Sri Lanka is an agricultural nation, with a great deal of crops planted in former elephant habitats and, in many cases, very close to national parks. I returned a few times to this area where elephants would cross out of the park to raid crops or visit an ill-conceived garbage dump. I wanted something at night because that felt more surreptitious and cunning. These elephants are smart and know exactly what they are doing, and I wanted a different-looking image that maybe had a little of that. My dominant thought was that I was running out of light; the sun had gone down, and the moon was rising. I needed it to be late and to have the blue tone, but I also needed to freeze the elephant as it stepped over the electric fence. Fortunately, cameras are amazing these days, and we can work in conditions like this. I was on a 400mm lens lying flat on the ground with a tarp over me, handholding and trying not to breathe. I’m sure this elephant knew I was there, but he got tired of waiting and eventually stepped over in just the right place.
