The magazine story talked about the pressure elephants are under from habitat loss as human development expands. This picture felt as if it could be part of that conversation. Read the full story at the link in bio.

Learn more at the link in bio.

Fifteen different periodical cicada groups, or “broods,” live in forests across the eastern U.S., emerging in 13- to 17-year cycles. In 2024, two of these groups will emerge simultaneously for the first time in 221 years—an event rarer than Halley’s comet. However, some of these cicadas have made an appearance a year early.

Photograph by @beckythale

Photo by @javier_aznar_photography | On a trail in Ecuador's Chocó rainforest, a hog-nosed pit viper (Porthidium nasutum) blends in among the dry leaves, waiting for prey to pass by. Follow @javier_aznar_photography for more.

This is a sample of the alkaline earth metal magnesium. But you can't consume it in this form. For magnesium to be absorbed, it must be consumed in forms bonded to other substances. The essential mineral is important for the body—but it doesn’t work miracles. Learn more about what the experts have to say about magnesium’s powers at the link in bio.

Photograph by Science Photo Library

Photo by Mattias Klum @mattiasklumofficial | After many weeks and quite a logistical nightmare, I managed to photograph this charming female kinkajou in the rainforest canopy in Panama for @natgeo. Kinkajous are not super rare but are very hard to find and photograph. This one is holding onto a balsa flower filled with nectar mixed with rainwater. Silently and hardly moving so as not to frighten off the animals, Lars-Magnus Ejdeholm, my amazing assistant at the time, and I looked for them with our night-vision binoculars. If they showed up, we would be ready with cameras and large flash systems. Lars-Magnus sat in the fork of one branch, and I sat in another, both of us secured with climbing ropes. Kinkajous are sensitive to sound and movement, so we had to be up in the trees several hours before sunset. Some nights the animals turned up, other nights it was silent and dark and the assignment felt pretty hopeless. It was difficult to get any closer to the animals. But after a few weeks it seemed that they were becoming habituated to our presence. Certain animals got used to the camera flash and the weak light from Lars-Magnus’s flashlight. They came closer and stayed longer. On a couple of occasions, everything fell into place. The shy kinkajous finally dared to drink nectar just an arm’s length from the camera. Follow @mattiasklumofficial for more pictures, films, and conservation stories from around the world.

A spotless giraffe, pictured in Namibia, was seen and photographed for the first time in the wild just weeks after the unusual condition was seen in a newborn giraffe at a U.S. zoo. Is it more common than scientists thought? Find out at the link in bio.

Photograph By Eckart Demasius and Giraffe Conservation Foundation

Photo by @beverlyjoubert | It's impossible to spend time in the company of elephants without gaining an appreciation for their extraordinary intelligence. And research continues to reveal more about their remarkable capabilities. Though we tend to consider personal names as uniquely human, emerging research suggests that elephants may have their own version of individual-specific calls. As I observed this herd on the march across a dusty plain in Kenya, it was easy to imagine how individual "names" could play a role in maintaining contact and facilitating communication over vast distances. It all adds another intriguing dimension to our understanding of these socially complex animals. To see more of my work, follow me @beverlyjoubert.
Photo by @rubensalgadoescudero | A man helps his blind brother while swimming on a beach in Elmina, Ghana. Follow me @rubensalgadoescudero to see the world through my lens.

Photo by Robert Clark @robertclarkphoto | Several years ago, I was assigned a story for National Geographic magazine on the evolution of dog breeds. Photo Editor Kurt Mutchler and I worked with the Hotel Pennsylvania, the "bedroom" for all the dogs that are in New York City for the Westminster Dog Show. The approach was to set up a studio in one of the hotel's dozens of ballrooms. We roamed around the lobby and hallways to look for dogs to come and have their portraits made. Leo was a wonderful Afghan to work with. At his studio appointment, everything was going well. Leo was like a professional model, beautiful and well behaved, as are a lot of show dogs. We were only a few minutes into the shoot when the door to the ballroom-studio was opened, and Leo saw an opportunity. I will never forget how fast he was as he headed out the door. The funny thing is that every Afghan I have photographed has taken the opportunity to run. I should have known better. It is just in their nature. That worked well with the title of the story, "How to Build a Dog," and the idea that dogs have been transformed from a common ancestor, the gray wolf, into what man needs: a guard dog, a hunting partner, a guide dog, or a best friend. Read more at the link in bio.

Discover more at the link in bio.

The 2021 volcanic blast in the Canary Islands entombed more than 2,800 buildings in lava and ash. Crystallized bits of lava from the eruption contain details about what made La Palma’s first eruption in 50 years so powerful and destructive—and possible clues for scientists to help predict what types of eruptions will happen in the future.

Photograph by Arturo Rodríguez

Photo by @kiliiiyuyan | I'm on assignment on the Ningaloo Reef, in the sparkling waters off Western Australia. It's one of those times when I'm actually doing what my friends think I do all the time: swimming with whale sharks and diving over reefs of red coral and giant fish. This is a fringing reef with nutrients from an offshore upwelling, which attracts everything up to Ningaloo's charismatic big three: humpbacks, whale sharks, and manta rays. Thanks to protections from UNESCO and a dedicated local community, 45,000 humpbacks migrate through each year, and you can be in the water as they cruise by or—for the adventurous—feel small swimming next to a whale shark.
Follow me, @kiliiiyuyan, for more beyond the sea.

Photo by Christopher Gregory Rivera @cgregoryphoto | Ian Pagán Roig, the founder of a family farm in the northern mountains surrounding the town of Toa Alta, Puerto Rico, sees his role as a farmer as fundamentally political. For him, Puerto Rico is a place where feeding oneself from the land is a revolutionary act.

After Spain ceded Puerto Rico to the United States, in 1898, the newly imposed U.S. government transformed the island’s agricultural landscape, favoring large U.S. corporations and collapsing the local farming industry. Today Pagán Roig is part of a sustainable agriculture movement that’s helping a new generation of farmers restore plots of land to supplement food imports. His farm produces for markets but also hosts an education program, the Josco Bravo Project, that over the past nine years has minted 500 new farmers. Read more about the history and culture of the world’s oldest colony at the link in bio. And follow @cgregoryphoto for more stories about Puerto Rico and beyond. 

This is one of eight stories from The Past Is Present project, a collaboration with @forfreedoms.

Photo by @joelsartore | Meet Spock, a Hanuman langur at the Zagreb, Croatia, zoo. Its common name derives from the Hindu god Lord Hanuman, and the species indeed is considered sacred by many Hindus. Because they are held in high regard, these langurs are usually left undisturbed in their home ranges. However, that habitat is diminishing due to activities like slash-and-burn agriculture, grazing, and open-pit mining, forcing these primates into more direct competition for resources—which could ultimately lead to conflict and the persecution of the species. To see more species featured in the Photo Ark, follow me @joelsartore. @zagrebzoo #PhotoArk

Though they died thousands of years ago, hundreds of bodies excavated in East Asia’s Tarim Basin are extremely well-preserved. But the mummies’ seemingly perfect state of preservation wasn’t their only surprise—their ancient DNA has yielded surprising insights.

Photograph by Wenying Li, Xinjiang Institute of Cultural Relics and Archaeology

Photo by @javier_aznar_photography | At first glance, it might appear to be a human ear, but in fact this is the aperture of a snail's shell, as seen in Yasuni National Park in Ecuador, one of the most biodiverse places on Earth. Follow @javier_aznar_photography for more photos from rainforest.

Read more at the link in bio.

There’s a difference between acute stress and more prolonged, chronic stress, but both can affect your health and well-being in the short and long term. Knowing how they both look and feel can help you better overcome them when they strike.

Photograph by @brianfinke

Photo by @jasperdoest | The baby forest elephant trots between its parents in Lopé National Park, Gabon, along one of many paths that generations of the animals have cut through the rainforest. Elephants pass on the knowledge of what to forage, where to find the food, and, in the case of fruit, when it’s likely to be ripe. Elephants are picky eaters and they are particularly fond of saplings, young trees, and plants that first grow in newly opened gaps in the forest. They feed by breaking stems and branches, pulling down lianas, uprooting whole plants, and stripping leaves off twigs. This “elephant disturbance”—all that messy eating—is important as it results in forests having fewer, larger trees, which allows these woodlands to store more carbon, making the elephants true ecosystem engineers. Read more about Gabon's elephants at the link in bio. #ElephantAppreciationDay

Northern white rhinos once roamed much of Africa, but widespread poaching and habitat loss has brought them to the razor's edge of extinction. Now, scientists are racing to save them by teaming up with a company known for attempting to resurrect the woolly mammoth. Learn more about the efforts—and the controversial approach—to save them at the link in bio. #WorldRhinoDay

Photograph by @amivitale

Photo by @beverlyjoubert | Ivory burns are a complex and often contentious conservation issue. Since the first public destruction of stockpiled ivory took place in Kenya in 1989, many others have been conducted around the globe. Though controversial, these events do send a strong and highly visible message against elephant poaching and the ivory trade. With more than 100,000 elephants killed illegally a year, the future of elephants still hangs in the balance. 

Photographing the historic and record-setting burn in Kenya in April 2016 was a profoundly moving experience. The confiscated ivory at this burn represented 10,000 elephants. By destroying stockpiled ivory on such a massive scale, Kenya took a stance against the plunder of its wildlife and demonstrated its refusal to reduce these magnificent creatures to mere commodities. With the red intensity of the flames against a smoke-darkened sky, the scene felt like bearing witness to a kind of mourning ritual, releasing the spirit of these animals—a return of thousands of tusks to the earth. To see more of my work, follow me @beverlyjoubert. #ElephantConservation #ElephantAppreciationDay

Photo by @dina_litovsky | New York City at twilight is a majestic sight, especially when seen from above. I photographed this image at the Edge, a viewing platform in Hudson Yards. For more images, follow me @dina_litovsky.

If Julius Caesar knew how often people are thinking about Rome (and him) today, could he have demanded another triumph?

Caesar received four triumphs, city-wide parties that were the highest honor a Roman could receive. He was the only one honored with four, one for each of his victorious campaigns. Learn more about how Rome celebrated Caesar at the link in bio.

Photograph by Songquan Deng/Getty Images

Photo by @orsolyahaarberg | See that area that looks like white carpet in this aerial image of a mixed forest in Rondane, Norway? It’s a thick layer of lichen called Cladonia sp., which covers where the ground is most exposed. The Cladonia species do not tolerate thick snow cover, so they grow in places snow is blown away by wind in the winter. Nearby are autumn-yellow mountain birch (Betula pubescens) and Scots pine (Pinus sylvestris). #FirstDayOfFall

Photo by Aaron Huey @argonautphoto | A lone palm tree stands charred after the 2008 Freeway Complex fire, which destroyed 314 residences in Anaheim Hills and Yorba Linda, California. It was just one of the many unprecedented wildfires in the state during a period of accelerating climate change, red-flag days, and extreme weather in all forms. This week leaders in the state named those they believe to be driving these conditions in a lawsuit: the five biggest oil companies in the world. The suit alleges that the companies deceived the public for the past 50 years about the deadly impact of fossil fuels on our planet and the resulting damage that has cost California taxpayers billions of dollars in health and environmental tolls. While an uneventful California wildfire season this year was a welcome respite, record-breaking rainfall and floods made headlines instead. The decades ahead look to be filled with more extreme phenomena. For an ongoing series on the climate crisis, please visit me @argonautphoto.

Photo by Luján Agusti @lujanag | I was on assignment to document the Baqueanos, a long-established family who work the land and raise cattle in Argentina's Tierra del Fuego. The story spoke to the deep bond that many people in Tierra del Fuego have with the landscape. Harsh and unforgiving, the territory is also a place of great beauty and abundance. The Baqueanos family have learned to live in harmony with it, with horses as their essential partners.

Aurelia is part of the family—a calm, curious child who loves the outdoors. As she rode her horse, I was struck by the way they seemed to be in sync, two parts of a whole. This photo is more than just a portrait; it's a reminder of the power of the human-animal bond. It's also a testament to the resilience of the people who have learned to thrive here. 

Portraiture is a dialogue with the photographer: a moment when two people meet and something special, almost magical, happens. Follow me at @lujanag to learn more about my homeland, Tierra del Fuego.

See more at the link in bio.

Images from a new telescope in Hawaii and clues from spacecraft orbiting the sun could not only help us understand how stars work—they could help us predict solar activity that threatens Earth.

Photograph by NSO/AURA/NSF

Photo by @amytoensing | Monhegan Island, Maine, 1999: American artist Jamie Wyeth works on a painting of island resident Kyle Murdock with his sign offering various items for sale to tourists—among them, a tour of his Dead Cat Museum, a collection of mummified cats Kyle found under a house on the island. Wyeth, who owns a summer home on Monhegan, has painted the island and its residents for decades, including a series on the children of the island.

This image is from my first story for National Geographic magazine, about Monhegan, a small island 10 miles off the coast of Maine. Two miles long and half a mile wide, the island overflows with tourists in the summer, but the year-round population is only about 60 to 70. The islanders’ de facto fishing territory became the Monhegan Lobster Conservation Area in 1996 with a limited season starting in October. The island’s windswept landscape, quirky community, and dramatic cliffs have inspired artists Robert Henri, George Bellows, Rockwell Kent, Edward Hopper, Lynne Mapp Drexler, and three generations of Wyeths, to name a few. 

Visit @amytoensing to see more images from this series of archive posts.

Photo by @acacia.johnson | A Pacific walrus rests on the shore of Round Island in Alaska’s Walrus Islands State Game Sanctuary. The particular sheen of these marine mammals, glowing slightly from the island’s dark and weather-smoothed rocks, remains one of the most otherworldly—and thought-provoking—wildlife encounters of my photography career. 

Walruses are a keystone species, meaning they help shore up the entire biotic community they live in. When they forage on the seafloor, they churn up vast quantities of nutrient-rich sediment, providing food not just for smaller organisms but all the way up to seabirds, larger fish, seals, and even polar bears farther north. But despite their vital role in the ecosystem, they often fall low on the priority list for conservation. Read more about the walruses of Round Island in the link in bio.

Follow me at @acacia.johnson for more stories from the natural world and beyond.

Photo by Ian Teh @iantehphotography | After our arrival to Cape Horn, Chilean naval officer Andrés Morales and his family met us near its shores—the only living souls on this island. Visitors here are rare, barring the occasional passing cruise ship or, at this particular time, adventurous scientists, a writer, and me—as we set off to explore the island away from the shelter of this outpost. 

In the coming days, Morales would keep us abreast of conditions by radio on an island notorious for its gales and unpredictable weather. Before setting off, I asked to take a family portrait outside during a lull in the gusts buffeting their cozy home. Admittedly I was hoping for an opportunity to catch them in the elements. They were kind and generous, willing to spend time with me as I placed them at a spot that showed the vastness and isolation of where they were. Within minutes, the winds picked up, ruffling their gracious poses to produce an image of a windswept family trying desperately to look at my camera. 

I had hoped to capture a sense of the place they were in—an isolated island at the bottom of the world. Cape Horn delivered. Later we hiked through gales and sheet rain, slipping on penguin guano before plummeting to our necks in prickly shrubs. All this in search of the world’s southernmost tree.

Follow me on @iantehphotography to see more images and stories from around the world.

These northern U.S. communities may not be completely immune to a warming world, but they are well-placed to meet the needs of an influx of climate migrants as deadly wildfires, record heat, and damaging hurricanes increasingly affect day-to-day life in the southern and western parts of the U.S. 

Learn more about what makes these cities “climate havens” at the link in bio.

Photo by Angelo Merendino, Corbis/Getty Images

Discover more at the link in bio.

Pompeii still has many secrets to uncover as much of the ancient city remains unexcavated—but after several landslides and collapses, preservation may be the focus of future archaeological efforts.

Photograph by David Hiser

Photo by Matthieu Paley @paleyphoto | I met with Stephen Paul shortly before sunrise to go fly-fishing for salmon in the river of his childhood. 

“You can call me Eggeun,” he says. “This is my Indigenous Mi’kmaq name.” 

Eggeun is an independent guide who focuses on Indigenous tourism. We were at the Metepenagiag Heritage Park in New Brunswick, Canada, which is dedicated to preserving, showcasing, and reviving Mik’maq culture, tradition, and language. Eggeun was touching in his honesty and has a soft-spoken manner. 

“Language is the first step to preserving knowledge,” he says. “Our people have lived, fished, and hunted here since time immemorial. No one can take that away from us. In the ‘70s, when I grew up, we were beaten by our teachers when we spoke our language. Now we have Indigenous schools teaching our mother tongue to the new generation. I am a hopeful man!” 

We went foraging for wild rosebuds, and all the while Eggeun explained his deep respect for the Elders and how he looks to them for information about Mi'kmaq heritage. 

“We also talk to other First Nation people in Canada and beyond to exchange cultural information and fill gaps in our knowledge. So much has been lost. Now we stand proud, regaining that knowledge.” | Embrace Canada's rich cultures, vast landscapes, and heartwarming interactions from coast to coast @explorecanada

Photo by Aaron Huey @argonautphoto | A young grizzly bear in Alaska’s Denali National Park stands against a backdrop of bright fall colors, feasting on blueberries to fatten up for a long winter hibernation. The taiga where this bear roams turns into a stunning canvas of reds and oranges each September, thanks to a unique mix of dwarf birch, willows, and blueberry bushes. Lasting only from late August to October, Denali’s autumn is brief but unforgettable, especially for photographers! For more scenes from this extraordinary landscape, follow @argonautphoto.

Learn more at the link in bio.

In true feline form, cats took their time deciding whether to jump into humans’ laps. In a comprehensive study from 2017 on the spread of domesticated cats, DNA analysis suggests that cats lived for thousands of years alongside humans before they were domesticated

Photograph by @joelsartore

Photo by @orsolyahaarberg | A friend and I were determined to trek on skis to the mountaintop despite a strong gale and low visibility on this day in early April in Jotunheimen, Norway. We were pleasantly surprised by the brief moments of stillness and a short period of good visibility. The sun found its way through the cloud cover every so often and magically lit up parts of the landscape. We were spurred on to reach our goal, the top of Veslfjelltinden. After finding the right position, I had just enough time to grab my camera and capture adjacent peaks as a gust of wind and a beam of sunlight came into the scene. Follow me @orsolyahaarberg for more images from the Scandinavian mountains.

Photo by @beverlyjoubert | Much like other lion range states, Kenya grapples with a host of threats to its lion population. Yet the country’s vast wilderness areas remain critical strongholds for these most social of the big cats. The trials and tribulations of lion life that play out against this iconic backdrop have long been a source of inspiration for so many storytellers. From intricate family dynamics to fierce struggles for survival, it is easy to be captivated by lions. Our hope is that we can channel this enduring fascination into tangible action. It is urgently needed to ensure lions and their stories endure. To see more of my work, follow me @beverlyjoubert.

If you answered "yes," then you may have a trypophobia—the fear of small holes and one of the Internet's most talked about phobias that you may not have heard of by name. Learn about a new study offering one theory for why trypophobia causes some people so much disgust at the link in bio.

Photograph by George Grall, Nat Geo Image Collection

Photo by @amytoensing | A relocated lynx, released near Colorado’s Weminuche Wilderness, begins his new life. Trucks, airplanes, and a snowmobile brought this male from Canada to a holding facility where he adjusted to the higher altitude and ate a high-protein diet to bolster him for hunting in unfamiliar territory. 

After decades of trapping, poisoning, and loss of habitat from human development, the lynx disappeared from the Colorado landscape by the 1970s. Colorado Parks and Wildlife (CPW) managed a seven-year program, starting in 1999, to bring the cats back—trapping them in Canada and releasing them in Colorado. There were lots of ups and downs, but in the end, it was named a success. Today CPW estimates that there are 150 to 250 lynx living in Colorado. The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service continues to list the cat as threatened in the lower 48 under the Endangered Species Act. According to the National Wildlife Federation, the lynx’s biggest threat today is habitat destruction and fragmentation. Visit @amytoensing to see more images.

Photo by Keith Ladzinski @ladzinski | The ultravibrant greater blue-eared starling shimmers in the midday sun at South Africa's Kruger National Park. Iridescence is a phenomenon characterized by a change in color when viewed from different angles, caused by diffracted or a scattering of light waves. It's common among a wide variety of bird species, but for this particular bird, it's brilliant.

Lean more at the link in bio.

Feel like you're not catching enough ZZZ's? You're not alone. More than a third of adults struggle with getting enough sleep—with women suffering more than men. Insufficient sleep is already linked to numerous health issues, but new research suggests it has serious implications on the ability to learn and focus.

Photograph by Becky Hale @beckythale

Photo by Sofia Jaramillo @sofia_jaramillo5 | Dropping temperatures and golden leaves in Wyoming's Tetons mean fall is here. As the nights get longer and cooler, the biological processes in leaves change as well. When plants grow in the spring, leaves appear green because of the chlorophyll that’s continually produced. With decreasing daylight at the end of summer, chlorophyll production slows and eventually stops, and red and orange pigments—carotenoids and anthocyanin—are revealed. 

For more images from the Tetons and around the world, follow @sofia_jaramillo5.

Photo by @kiliiiyuyan | I’m on assignment on the Ningaloo Reef, in the sparkling waters off western Australia. This was one of those times where I was actually doing what my friends think I do all the time—hanging out with humpback whales and diving with gorgeous lionfish over red coral. The Ningaloo Reef is a fringing reef, meaning that it fans out from shore. Nutrients from an offshore upwelling attract all manner of species up to the reef's charismatic big three: humpbacks, whale sharks, and manta rays. Thanks to protections by UNESCO and a dedicated local community, 45,000 humpbacks have their babies and migrate through each year. Follow me @kiliiiyuyan for more.

Photo by Jeff Kerby @jtkerby | The western limit of Greenland’s Røhss Fjord. Humans rarely visit this beautiful corner of Northeast Greenland National Park, but the region is home to thousands of musk oxen and healthy populations of polar bears and Arctic foxes. This is also one of many valleys where meltwater from the Greenland ice sheet leaves land and enters the sea. For the past several summers, I’ve joined oceanographers from Aarhus University and the Flanders Marine Institute while they installed sensors to measure conditions in these fjords. These sensors provide critical insights about when and how much fresh water is entering the oceans, even when nobody is around to see it. For more from northeast Greenland, follow along at @jtkerby.

In 2021, Dogxim was found struck by a car and taken to veterinarians for treatment. Her caregivers initially thought she was a dog, but soon noticed her behaviors, such as climbing bushes and preferring to eat rats over kibble, seemed more like a fox. Learn more about the world's first known dog-fox hybrid at the link in bio.

Photograph by Flávia Ferrari

Photo by @spencerlowell_ | The Allen Telescope Array in Hat Creek, California, is an assembly of 42 individual 6-meter parabolic dishes that collectively operate as a singular radio telescope. In this image, Jon Richards, a senior software engineer for SETI (the Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligence Institute), is servicing one of the antenna dishes. This unique design enables the ATA to simultaneously scan broad portions of the sky across a wide frequency range of 1 to 10 GHz, making it a pivotal SETI instrument. By detecting potential signals from advanced extraterrestrial civilizations, collaborating with global telescopes, and adapting flexibly to different observation needs, the ATA stands as a cornerstone in humanity's quest to uncover signs of life beyond Earth. #WorldSpaceWeek

Photo by @martinedstrom | A walrus and her cub balance on ice in Norway's Svalbard archipelago. Thanks to a thick layer of protective fat, walruses can sleep comfortably on snow and ice in temperatures that would demand the heaviest of sleeping bags for humans. Follow me @martinedstrom for more encounters from Svalbard.

The furry face of a bee, the rainbow hues of a flounder, the luminous beams of traffic lights—a photographer can highlight layers of complexity and detail that otherwise would not be visible to the human eye. See photographs that reveal invisible wonders of our world at the link in bio.

Photograph by Anand Varma

From Florida to California, space fans in the U.S. are making pilgrimages to a historic number of liftoffs. Head to the link in bio to learn where to see rocket launches and enjoy firsthand the golden age of American spaceflight. #WorldSpaceWeek

Photograph by LSP1982/iStock Unreleased

Photo by Becky Hale @beckythale | Watching Buzz Aldrin walk into the National Geographic studio in 2015 was a “pinch myself” moment. I distinctly remember thinking, He’s real. Like, a real actual person.

Aldrin occupies a special place in the national identity of the United States. He is more cultural icon than actual flesh-and-blood person and became a household name in 1969, when he was the pilot on the Apollo 11 mission with Neil Armstrong and walked on the moon. Yet here he was in the photo studio. And I was adjusting his collar.

Our days at National Geographic headquarters can be wild. One minute we’re photographing a cicada on a stick and the next moment Buzz Aldrin. #WorldSpaceWeek

Discover more at the link in bio.

The mixture of gasses measured in exoplanet K2-18 b suggests it may have a global ocean beneath a hydrogen-rich atmosphere—and astronomers even spotted a tantalizing, though unconfirmed, sign of life. #WorldSpaceWeek

Illustration by NASA, CSA, ESA, J. Olmsted (STScI), Science: N. Madhusudhan (Cambridge University)

Composite image of 15 sequential photos by Reuben Wu @reuben | The SpaceX Falcon Heavy rocket leaves Earth's orbit on February 6, 2018. During a late-night photo shoot for a series in the wilderness of northern Arizona, I noticed a fast-moving point of light in the sky behind this rock formation. Without knowing what it was (and slightly concerned), I kept pressing the shutter button until it expanded into a glowing white cloud. It was at that moment I realized I was witnessing a rocket launch.

Later I received confirmation that it was indeed the first demonstration flight of the Falcon Heavy that launched from Florida but left Earth's orbit somewhere over Arizona—a very serendipitous photobomb. For more photos, follow me @reuben #WorldSpaceWeek

It’s the most popular supplement on the market—but why do we need vitamin D and why is the advice on how to get it conflicting? Learn more about vitamin D and how to navigate confusing advice at the link in bio.

Photograph by Matthieu Paley @paleyphoto

Photo by @spencerlowell_ | When I learned of the space shuttle Endeavour's journey in 2012 through Los Angeles from LAX to the California Science Center, I was instantly inspired to create this image. I researched the route of the shuttle, selected the ideal day, and chartered a helicopter. To achieve the most parallel view, I stood on the struts of the helicopter as it banked. As a photographer with a love of science, this image resonates deeply with me, juxtaposing humanity's terrestrial existence with our cosmic aspirations. #WorldSpaceWeek

Learn more at the link in bio.

NASA’s Webb telescope is pulling back the curtain on the earliest galaxies, which are more numerous and brighter than expected—revealing a frenetic opening to the saga of space and time. #WorldSpaceWeek

Composite by ESA/WEBB, NASA, CSA, M. ZAMANI (ESA/WEBB), PDRS4ALL ERS TEAM

Uncover more at the link in bio.

Fashion designers and celebrities recently gathered in Paris for Fashion Week—but they weren’t the only ones making headlines. Bedbugs crawling through the cushioned crevices of the city flooded social media, fueling widespread concern due to the number of travelers that could return home with a bloodsucking hitchhiker in tow. The situation in Paris may not be an outbreak at all, but rather evidence of a longstanding issue and an example of what makes these critters so effective.

Photograph by Edwin Remsburg, VW Pics/ Getty Images

Photo by @katieorlinsky | The headwaters of the Gila River in the Gila Wilderness of southern New Mexico. The Gila is one of the longest still dam-free rivers of the American West. It's also one of the most endangered rivers in the United States, which is why activists and New Mexico’s senators are backing passage of the M.H. Dutch Salmon Greater Gila Wild and Scenic River Act. The bill would give the Gila River “wild and scenic river” designation and protect more than 440 miles of the Gila River watershed. 

This image is from National Geographic's June cover story, “Into the Wild: Life and Death in one of America’s Last Great Places.” Read the full story at the link in bio.

Photo by @brentstirton | I was working with bat hunters who had just harvested bats from a nearby island and were now on their way back across the powerful, fast-flowing Congo River, in the Republic of the Congo. I needed to see the bats and the men in the same environmental frame. At the same time, I was holding onto the side of the canoe with one hand and trying to remain steady with the other, attempting to keep my gear dry. My biggest concern was being able to see the tiny but key subject matter in the middle of a chaotic scene and capture a dynamic frame. I think that kind of informational but also aesthetic thinking is at the heart of a good National Geographic photo. This story was about wild meat, its sustainability, and the consequences of hunting and eating it. It was the peak of COVID-19, and these bats were proven reservoirs for several diseases that had jumped from animals to humans through consumption. Read the full story at the link in bio.

On October 14, a “ring of fire” solar eclipse will appear across the western United States, as well as in parts of Central and South America. This celestial phenomenon won’t occur in the continental U.S. again until 2039. Head to the link in bio to learn more and where you can experience it for yourself.

Photograph by Visual China Group, Getty Images

Head to the link in bio to learn what a new study has uncovered about this "global phenomenon."

Humpback whales are well known for their fascinating culture, and now researchers have shed light on yet another aspect of whale behavior: playing with kelp they find floating in the ocean—or "kelping."

Photograph By Shutterstock

Photo by @reuben | Today’s annular eclipse looms behind a hiker at the top of a pinnacle in Nevada's Schell Creek Range. An annular eclipse differs from a total eclipse in that the moon is slightly further away from Earth and doesn’t quite cover the sun's disk, creating a dramatic crescent and ring effect, rather than the total eclipse's visible corona amid full darkness. For more stories, follow me @reuben.

Read more at the link in bio.

Millions of people now live with the debilitating disorder, which can be triggered by viral illnesses. And although exercise is considered to be a first-line treatment for POTS, many say it has backfired.

Photograph by Magali Druscovich, Reuters/Redux

Photo by Sofia Jaramillo @sofia_jaramillo5 | Sheep graze outside of Ketchum, Idaho, during the Trailing of the Sheep Festival. The annual October event celebrates the state's Basque culture and history. While California may have a larger Basque population, Boise's community, estimated between 10,000-15,000, represents a greater concentration per capita in the United States. That number can swell to 25,000 during the festival, and the town knows how to host a party. Restaurants serve lamb chili, empanadas, and curry, to name a few dishes, while visitors watch performances by the Oinkari Basque Dancers, drink traditional ciders, and observe sheepherding. In the early 1800s, Basque immigrants were drawn here to find work as herders—and a path to citizenship. Their culture has permeated the region ever since. For more images from Idaho and around the world, follow @sofia_jaramillo5.

Photo by @joelsartore | With a back end that looks very much like an Oreo, this arachnid does not spin webs but instead burrows—using its hardened abdominal disc to plug the entry to its underground home. A member of the Cyclocosmia genus, these rare spiders are the smaller, less hairy cousins of tarantulas, and are often regarded as living fossils. To see more species featured in the Photo Ark follow me @joelsartore. #PhotoArk

Have you heard about #HauntedAppalachia? Legend has it the forest is full of cryptids and the paranormal—eerie stories set in the Appalachian Mountains are rampant on social media. So, why do people believe the supernatural creatures said to roam these forests are intimately tied to the landscape? Find out at the link in bio.

Photograph by @gerdludwig

Photo by @katieorlinsky | A view through the foliage of volcanic rock-lined canyons along Whitewater Creek at the northwest boundary of the Gila Wilderness, in southern New Mexico. The wilderness encompasses more than 870 square miles of rough country, including deserts, grasslands, piñon and pine forests, 10,000-foot mountains, and walls of slot canyons (seen here) created by one of the longest undammed rivers in the American West: the Gila. 

This image is from National Geographic's June cover story. Read the full story at the link in bio.

Comment below and find out at the link in bio.

Masters of disguise, they evolve to suit their surroundings. Some become more brown in arid habitats or green in tropical rainforests. Virtually invisible, most of them don't move much. They find a niche without competition for resources.

Photograph by Levon Biss

Read more at the link in bio.

After being excavated and fashioned into dinosaur dig kits, carved figurines, jewelry, and more for sale, "tens of thousands of pounds of dinosaur bones have lost virtually all scientific value.”

Photograph by Bureau of Land Management

Photo by @beverlyjoubert | The elephant … and the queleas. If there’s a bird capable of visually dwarfing an elephant, the red-billed quelea certainly qualifies. A single bird may be only the size of a sparrow, but queleas do not travel solo. Instead, they converge to form tightly synchronized flocks, sometimes millions-strong, that move over the landscape like swirling clouds. Such abundance can be destructive, and for farmers in many different parts of Africa, the birds pose a significant threat to cultivated crops. But here in Botswana’s famous Okavango Delta, it is the seeds of wild grasses that sustain them, and their aerial ballet makes for a captivating spectacle. To see more of my work, follow me @beverlyjoubert.

Zombies aren’t real—or are they? These masters of mind control manipulate their hosts from within, causing them to act in self-destructive ways that ultimately benefit the parasite. Read more at the link in bio—if you dare.

Photograph by Anand Varma, Nat Geo Image Collection

Photo by @jaimerojo | At the beginning of fall 2023, sea ice in Antarctica hit a record low. Ice-dependent species, like these Adelie penguins in Paulet Island, off the northeastern end of the Antarctic Peninsula, will face new hardships to feed and breed as the extent of sea ice cover shrinks. Their population is expected to drop drastically on a warmer planet. Follow @jaimerojo for more pictures and stories about the last wild places on Earth.

Photo by Muhammed Muheisen @mmuheisen | The fifth-century B.C. Parthenon temple is illuminated atop the ancient Acropolis, with the Saronic Gulf seen in the background, in Athens. For more photos and videos from different parts of the world, follow me @mmuheisen.

Learn more at the link in bio.

Protein is the nutritional craze of the moment, but it's difficult to separate the hype from reality. While it's a necessary part of any balanced diet, it's also possible to consume too much.

Photograph by Deb Lindsey, The Washington Post/Getty Images

Photo by @joelsartore | These two may look like domestic house cats, but they're actually a pair of Scottish wildcats that reside at Wildcat Haven in Scotland. Unlike most cats, the Scottish wildcat is a multihabitat hunter—a behavior that evolved in response to severe deforestation in its home range. This carnivore plays a key role in controlling the numbers of prey animals such as rabbits, rats, hares, and other small animals. Today, the biggest threat to the species is hybridization with feral cats. In an attempt to prevent that, Wildcat Haven has secured over 1,000 square miles (2,500 sq km) of safe habitat for the Scottish wildcat by humanely trapping feral cats, neutering them, and releasing them. With the support of the local community, this work has been helping the Scottish wildcat to thrive over the last decade and efforts will continue on for years to come. To see more species featured in the Photo Ark follow me @joelsartore. #PhotoArk

Photo by @javier_aznar_photography | Portrait of a wandering spider (of the Ctenidae family) feeding on a frog in Ecuador's Yasuni National Park. Learn about these mesmerizing animals in the March issue of the magazine or at the link in bio. Follow @javier_aznar_photography for more spiders and other small creatures.

Photo by @spencerlowell_ | At Plenty's indoor vertical farm in Compton, California, cutting-edge technology revolutionizes traditional farming. The system uses hydroponics and advanced robotics to cultivate crops in controlled environments for optimal growth. This method reduces water usage, maximizes yield, and challenges our understanding of agriculture's potential—giving us a window into the next chapter of food production.

Photo by @orsolyahaarberg | The last leaves hang weightless on trees deep in a misty beech forest in the Abruzzo region of Italy, signaling the imminent arrival of winter. These trees are bedecked with abundant lichens, a characteristic of old-growth forests.

Learn more at the link in bio.

There are many different types of dementia, and how it manifests depends on which part of the brain is damaged. Cognitive decline can stem from a multitude of processes, which poses a challenge to practitioners attempting to diagnose dementia.

Photograph by Massimo Brega, Science Photo Library

Photo by @chrisburkard | Sometimes you sacrifice a little comfort to capture a photo like this one: numb hands, little to no sleep, chapped skin from the frigid air. In this case, that all seemed to fade as we watched the northern lights dance above us in eastern Greenland, in 2017.

Photo by Keith Ladzinski @ladzinski | Eye to eye with a familiar bluet damselfly, perched on a cypress in the Florida Everglades. These little predators are key to the health of an ecosystem, voraciously hunting insects as well as being helpful pollinators. You can easily distinguish the females, like this one, by their distinct color patterns and hues.

The Åkernes mountain has one of the most hazardous rock fractures in the world that continues to grow every year. Part of the mountain will eventually slide into one of Norway’s deepest fjords, causing a rockslide larger than anything seen before, which could trigger one of the tallest tsunamis in history. Learn how villagers are preparing at the link in bio.

Photograph by Lucas Vallecillos, VWPics/Redux

Photo by @alessandro.cinque | With a National Geographic Society grant, I'm on a long-term project in the Andes to capture how Indigenous peoples coexist with the foreign mining companies around them. For years I focused on Peru, and now I've expanded the project to Bolivia and Ecuador.

This particular workday had not gone well, and I returned to town in search of a restaurant for dinner. Often when I've had a bad day, I just start taking pictures of everything around me. I was captivated by this empty street near the main market. The light and colors reminded me of the American painter Edward Hopper. Suddenly a woman appeared from a market door to my right. I hoped she would continue on her way, thus entering the frame. We didn't exchange a single word, but she gave me one of my favorite photos taken in Bolivia—and changed the mood of the day. To see more of my work, please follow @alessandro.cinque. @insidenatgeo

Photo by Muhammed Muheisen @mmuheisen | I captured this image in May while flying over flower fields in the Dutch province of Flevoland. The area’s expanse of tulip fields is among the largest in the Netherlands. For more photos and videos from different parts of the world, follow me @mmuheisen.

Learn more at the link in bio.

Buried on an Andean peak as a sacrifice to the Inca Gods, this young woman’s body naturally mummified over time. But at some point across the centuries, her face became exposed to the elements causing her features to slowly vanish. Now, archaeology and science have restored her gaze.

Photograph by Dagmara Socha

This cave is known as a gateway to the demon-filled underworld and the birthplace of the Samhain festival—the traditional roots of Halloween. Discover more about Oweynagat cave in Rathcroghan, Ireland, at the link in bio—if you dare.

Photograph by Ronan O'Connell

Photo by @rubensalgadoescudero | A monk prays at Kyaiktiyo Pagoda, also known as Golden Rock, the third most important Buddhist pilgrimage site in Myanmar. Standing at the top of Mount Kyaiktiyo, Golden Rock is a small temple built on a granite boulder. The boulder is covered with gold leaves, which devotees paste onto the surface before praying. 

I was supposed to go to Myanmar for one month in 2013. When I arrived, I immediately became enamored with the country and its people. I ended up staying for two and a half years. It is where I began my journey as a professional photographer.

Follow me @rubensalgadoescudero to see the world through my lens.

Photo by @stuartpalley | The 2017 Canyon fire burns around a home in Corona, California. With the arrival of fall, Southern California enters the peak time for its Santa Ana winds. The winds originate from high pressure over the Great Basin, a desert area encompassing six states. As wind is pulled toward the coast over and through the mountains, it leads to drier air and warms it through compressional heating. The end result: winds that can cause destructive wildfires. However, a wet winter, rainy summer, and likely upcoming El Niño pattern collectively could mute fire activity, leading to a reprieve for a state with record-setting wildfires in recent years. 

This week the state is seeing a fall heatwave, leading to temperatures 15-degrees above normal, a hopefully tranquil reminder of the destructive weather patterns than can wreak havoc with wildfires in the state.

Photo by @acacia.johnson | A young polar bear peers beneath the sea ice near Spitsbergen, in Norway's Svalbard archipelago. These marine mammals are capable of swimming long distances and depend on sea ice to hunt for food. This young bear appeared to be playing with the skin of a seal it had recently eaten, tossing it into the water then swimming down to bring it back to the surface. Follow me at @acacia.johnson for more stories from the Arctic and beyond.

Photo by @joelsartore | This 24-day-old slow loris I photographed at the Endangered Primate Rescue Center in Vietnam was named Captain Hook by his care team because of his missing hand. Loris species are unique among primates in part because of their looks, but more so because they are classified as a venomous mammal. Each individual has a patch filled with venom under its elbow. When a predator encounter occurs, the loris will coat its teeth by licking this spot in order to deliver a venom-laced bite. To see more species featured in the Photo Ark, follow me @joelsartore. #PhotoArk

Photo by Ivan Kashinsky @ivankphoto | The Castillo family attends the Annual Día de los Muertos Art and Music Festival in Whittier, California. Veronica, as Mexico’s cultural icon La Calavera Catrina, stands with her two boys, Aiden and Samson, who are dressed as characters from the film “Nacho Libre.“ 

Celebrated all over the world, El Día de los Muertos (the Day of the Dead) is a Mexican holiday in which people remember their ancestors. Many build altars, or ofrendas, to honor them, and ply them with items such as the deceased person’s favorite food. La Calavera Catrina originated from an etching by Mexican illustrator José Guadalupe Posada in the early 20th century. The etching satirizes the country’s elite just before the Mexican revolution. La Catrina is a popular costume tied to El Día de los Muertos and central to Mexican identity. 

This portrait was made on assignment for National Geographic in 2017, with National Geographic Explorer Karla Gatchet @kchete77, while working on the story “How Latinos Are Shaping America’s Future.” #ElDíaDeLosMuertos #DayOfTheDead

Vitamin C is essential to powering your immune system which is why people load up on the nutrient during cold and flu season. But is it worth it—and can you overdo it? Find out at the link in bio.

Photograph by @beckythale

Learn more at the link in bio.

We thought we knew the secrets of Europe's bog bodies. We didn't. Now, science is revealing new clues—and new mysteries—about these remarkably well-preserved bodies.

Photograph by @robertclarkphoto

Have you ever seen a Siamese cat change color? Learn more about the genetic mutation that causes them to do so—and leaves them vulnerable to certain health problems—at the link in bio.

Photograph by Willard Culver

Photo by @heidihanskoch| | It may seem wildly impractical, but flashy plumage—such as the long, shimmery tail feathers of the king bird of paradise—evolved to serve a key goal: attracting potential mates.

The coronavirus came, and we were looking for a “corona compliant” project that we could realize in our studio. As luck would have it, the project came to us. We got the offer to photograph two private feather collections and those of the National History Museum in Berlin.

For us, feathers are encounters with the irresistibly beautiful in nature. We wanted to present them as a sensuous experience, as poetic masterpieces of evolution. The most amazing feathers we were able to photograph were certainly those of the birds of paradise.

We used the method of focus stacking to get the greatest possible depth of field for this project. Every day was a feather day. Gradually our engagement with nature and technology developed into a kind of meditation. In the end, it took us more than two years.

Learn more about what flashy feathers reveal about the secret lives of birds at the link in bio.

Photo by @michaelgeorge | A dog stands on the edge of the Earth. Well, let me clarify. The dog is on the cliff’s edge at Cape Finisterre in Spain's Galicia region—which in Roman times was believed to be the end of the Earth, or at least the known world. Pilgrims who walk the Camino de Santiago will often continue their journey to this point, the true end of the road. In 2013, after walking my own pilgrimage, I did just that. As the sun set, a stray dog from town wandered out on the rocks as if it was looking to enjoy the view as well. My fellow travelers and I nicknamed him Perrogrino, a play on the Spanish words “perro” (dog) and “peregrino” (pilgrim).

Photo by @Justin.Jin | Asia’s third longest river, the Mekong, is one of the world’s most fabled waterways thanks to the cultures and landscapes it runs through. I shot this picture of passengers exiting a water taxi while traveling in Laos, by kayak and bus, with my wife and kids. In few places on Earth do so many—an estimated 70 million people—depend on one river for so much. But this unique ecosystem faces collapse from overfishing, unsustainable development, and poor agricultural practices. Dams exacerbate the problem by disrupting flow and fish breeding. Follow @justin.jin for more stories and images from around the world.
Photo by Keith Ladzinski @ladzinski | Juvenile chacma baboons playfully wrestle along the dusty bank of the Cubango River in the Okavango Delta, Botswana.
Photo by @javier_aznar_photography | Portrait of a juvenile eyelash viper in Ecuador's Chocó rainforest. Follow me @javier_aznar_photography to learn more about the last primary forest in Ecuador.

Photo by @beverlyjoubert | For a cheetah mother, rearing young is a feat of patience, resilience … and preparedness. Staying watchful and alert is how meals are found and threats from larger predators averted. Luckily, in the sprawling flatness of Kenya's Mara ecosystem, scanning the horizon for both takes just a little elevation. The ubiquitous termite mound offers the perfect perch when vigilance is required. Before very long, these two youngsters will grow to appreciate the usefulness of a lookout spot, too. For more of my work, follow me @beverlyjoubert.

Photo by @orsolyahaarberg | As the camera lens points toward the rising sun at Abruzzo, Lazio, and Molise National Park in Italy, a thin layer of morning dew gives white contour to the naked beech trees on this early November day.

Photo by @katieorlinsky | Writer Neil Shea and I have been living and breathing caribou for the past three years, and now our story, “Where Are All the Caribou?” is finally online. Check it out at the link in bio and in the December issue of National Geographic. 

The animals pictured here are part of Alaska’s Western Arctic herd, photographed deep within the Brooks Range outside the Nunamiut village of Anaktuvuk Pass. Two centuries ago, there were hundreds of thousands of caribou as far south as Maine, and in the Arctic, herds numbered close to 5 million. However, over the past 2 decades, Arctic caribou populations have been in shocking decline, dropping to roughly 2 million and falling. There hasn’t been a disappearance of so many large land mammals in such a short time since the American bison. No one knows exactly why, and it's considered to be one of the greatest wildlife mysteries on the continent.

What we do know for certain is that caribou decline is an enormous loss that threatens to put even more pressure on the fragile ecosystem of the Arctic, as well as on Indigenous communities across Alaska and Canada. They need caribou for food security, and they're also culturally and spiritually dependent on the animals, just as they have been for thousands of years.

This story was made possible because of these communities and the people who graciously shared their time and knowledge with us over the years. We thank the Nunamiut of Anaktuvuk Pass, Alaska, the Tlicho Tribe in the Northwest Territories of Canada, the Neets'aii Gwich'in community of Arctic Village, Alaska, the Inupiat village of Ambler, Alaska, and the West Moberly and Saulteau First Nations in British Columbia, Canada.

Working on this story, it’s become clear that if we want to save the caribou, we have to listen to the people who know them best.

When certain vitamins, minerals, or phytonutrients, are consumed together, they can have a more powerful effect on your health than when they’re eaten alone—a concept called nutrient synergy. Head to the link in bio for six dynamic nutrient combos that have synergistic effects.

Photograph by BDMcIntosh, Getty Images

Photo by Keith Ladzinski @ladzinski | The autumn season is always a bit wistful. Witnessing the fleeting beauty of changing leaves signifies shorter and colder days ahead. For deciduous trees and shrubs, this shedding is a process of preparation. The first act for these plants is to slow and eventually stop producing chlorophyll, the key ingredient that gives foliage its green color and helps absorb light for photosynthesis. Shedding is a safeguard against heavy snow that can cling to leaves and cause severe damage. I photographed this scene of vibrant red maple leaves in northern Illinois after the first snow of the season, a collision of autumn and winter.

Some 4.5 billion years ago, the solar system was a giant game of cosmic pinball. During those early ages, a Mars-size object called Theia smashed into Earth, and the debris coalesced into the moon. Now, a new study suggests that portions of Theia survived throughout Earth's history deep in our planet's mantle.

Head to the link in bio to learn more about how scientists believe the ghost of Theia sank into our planet.

Illustration by Hongping Deng, Hangzhou Sphere Studio

Photo by @jaimerojo | Predators are slowly returning to the forests of Sierra Gorda Biosphere Reserve in the state of Queretaro in northern Mexico. Much of the country has suffered a severe loss of wildlife, but in these mountains, just a hundred miles (160 km) from Mexico City, sustainable management and restoration efforts by Grupo Ecologico Sierra Gorda, a family-led grassroots conservation organization, have resulted in a thriving population of wildlife. This includes mountain lions, which had disappeared in the area because of retaliatory killings by landowners and cattle ranchers. This camera trap image of a mountain lion in the mist required more than four months of trial and error (and lots of fogged lenses). Follow @jaimerojo for more stories about conservation in Mexico and beyond.

Photo by Charlie Hamilton James @chamiltonjames | A male Andean cock-of-the-rock displays at a lek—a mating ground—in the cloud forest of Peru's Manu National Park. The aim is to attract a female with an often intricate display, demonstrating its prowess—a strategy some bird species use as part of their sexual selection. Male cock-of-the-rock display on low branches, with exaggerated head and neck movements and a strange call, often to each other, as they wait for a female to turn up and show interest.

Roman emperor Marcus Aurelius would never have hit snooze. Ben Franklin loved to sit in the nude. Love them or loathe them, morning rituals can set the tone for the rest of the day. For centuries, humans have been devising morning routines that inspire productivity and focus. Head to the link in bio for nuggets of wisdom from historical figures.

Photograph by Rogers Fund, 1906, The Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York

Photo by @joelsartore | Found in Southeast Asia, the paradise tree snake has a secret talent: it can fly! Now, it can’t fly in the traditional sense like bats and birds, but it can glide from one tree to the next, covering distances of more than 30 feet (10m). It does so by stretching its body into a flattened strip using its ribs and propelling itself forward. Photo taken at Singapore's Mandai Wildlife Reserve. To see more species featured in the Photo Ark follow me, @joelsartore. #PhotoArk

With landmark hotels opening, ambitious rewilding projects under way and new train routes making travel easier than ever, there’s a lot to choose from for your next trip. Head to the link in bio to find the 30 most exciting destinations chosen by National Geographic Traveller (UK) for 2024. @natgeotraveluk 

Photograph by izhairguns / Getty Images

Photo by @heidihanskoch | The flashy tail feathers of the Alexandrine parakeet not only help the bird take flight but also aid in balance and courtship. These birds, found in both South and Southeast Asia, are among the largest parakeets.

When the pandemic hit, my husband, Hans, and I we were looking for a project that we could realize in our studio. As luck would have it, it came to us. We got the offer to photograph two private feather collections and those of the National History Museum in Berlin.

For us, feathers are encounters with the irresistibly beautiful in nature. We wanted to present them as a sensual experience, as poetic masterpieces of evolution. The most amazing feathers we were able to photograph were certainly those of the birds of paradise.

For this project we used the method of focus stacking, in which similar photos with different focal planes are blended to achieve a more profound depth of field.

Every day was a feather day. Gradually our engagement with nature and technology developed into a kind of meditation. In the end, it took us more than two years. To see more from this project, head to the link in bio.

Photo by @macstonephoto | No, this isn't the moon. Insects, fungus, and bacteria play a role in breaking down organic material in the swamp. Anaerobic bacteria living in the water column and soil feed on minerals like sulphur, copper, and iron. The byproduct of breaking down these minerals can create a rainbow sheen or oil-like slick on the water surface. Sometimes these are mistaken for petroleum spills, but you can tell the difference: If disturbed, those from bacteria will break off into platelets and will not reform with one another. After sunset, while slogging through Beidler Forest in South Carolina, I saw this pattern on the water's surface. I aimed the camera at the reflections of trees and the oily sheen, resulting in an image that appears to be a moon rising over the swamp. For more images from swamps and wetlands, follow me @macstonephoto.

Photo by @joelsartore | Meet the mustached tamarin, a primate native to Brazil and Peru. While groups of mustached tamarins are highly territorial when they come in contact with one another, they are surprisingly willing to share territory with saddleback tamarins. Because of dietary differences, the two species do not compete for resources, allowing them to coexist and increase the odds of survival for both groups: The more individuals a group has, the greater the chances that someone will see or hear an approaching predator. 
This photo was taken at the Prague Zoo. To see more species featured in the Photo Ark, follow me, @joelsartore.

Photo by @mattiasklumofficial | Two baby elephants cuddle in front of my camera in Tanzania’s Selous Game Reserve. Young elephants spend a lot of time playing by chasing and pulling each other’s tails. They splash and spray with water and mud, and they often “trunk wrestle” and practice fighting in pushing-and-pulling competitions. Please follow @mattiasklumofficial for more images and conservation stories from my projects around the world.

Photo by Prasenjeet Yadav @prasen.yadav | The five-day Diwali festival of light is celebrated across India in the fall. The holiday's name is derived from the row (avali) of clay lamps (deepa) that Indians light outside their homes to symbolize the spiritual victory of light over darkness, good over evil, and knowledge over ignorance. 

On this auspicious occasion, I'm sharing a picture of light in darkness. A few years ago, I was in the Western Ghats when I captured this meteor during a time-lapse. The camera was set at a 15-second exposure for 999 frames, and this meteor showed up in one of the shots. The green hue comes from a meteor's metallic mix, ignited as the rock enters Earth's atmosphere. Follow me @prasen.yadav for more photos.

Learn more at the link in bio.

Cats have hundreds of distinct facial expressions, a discovery that turns on its head the popular belief that our pet felines are aloof and just not that into us. In fact, cats likely evolved these various expressions because of us.

Photograph by Blickwinkel/Alamy Stock Photo

Photo by @yamashitaphoto | Fall foliage at its peak in Vermont’s Northeast Kingdom: I was on assignment shooting a story on seasonal change in this remote area famous for its forests of sugar maples. It was an overcast day with occasional breaks in the clouds—my favorite kind of light—what I call in-and-out sunshine. I focused on a burst of light lasting only a few seconds to capture this quintessential Vermont landscape.

Photo by @macstonephoto | Let's set the record straight on one of the most maligned reptiles in the United States, the cottonmouth. They are feared and loathed by many, but these animals don't want anything to do with people. This scene might induce terror—and it's supposed to. Their namesake comes from a generous warning display of opening wide to signal their venomous bite. If you're close enough to see the white of their mouths, it's their way of politely asking you to back away. Also called a water moccasin, the snake is essential to wetland ecosystems, preying on rodents, fish, and even other snakes. I think they're beautiful, and I always get excited when I see one curled up on a log or along a trail. For more images from swamps and wetlands, follow @macstonephoto.

Photo by Keith Ladzinski @ladzinski | Sitting at the intersection of the Colorado Plateau, the Great Basin, and the Mojave Desert, Zion National Park is home to a diverse array of landscapes: sandstone cliffs, upheaval domes, and mazes of canyons. To see more photos of this beautiful place visit me @ladzinski.

Can one fuzzy berry ruin the bunch? Can you cut away a spotty piece of bread from the loaf? Sometimes, the decision to keep or toss moldy food isn’t so cut and dry. Head to the link in bio for an expert guide to best household practices to extend your food life and protect your gut.

Photograph by Jon Snedden, Camera Press/Redux

Photo by @mattiasklumofficial | A polar bear and her cubs take a well-deserved snooze after devouring a bearded seal. Polar bears nap almost anywhere and anytime, especially after feeding. The summer sun never really sets in the Svalbard region of Norway. However, light is softer and even more gorgeous at night. I usually choose to work the "night shift" since the polar bears (and other species) tend to be more active then—as do their prey. But day and night distinctions do not mean that much in the Arctic, which has 24 hours of daylight in summer and 24 hours of darkness during winter. Please follow me @mattiasklumofficial for more.

Photo by @beverlyjoubert | Kenya’s wilderness areas may be a stronghold for Africa’s lions, but no country on the continent remains untouched by the challenges facing these majestic predators. The statistics can often feel disheartening and overwhelming. According to some estimates, lion numbers have dropped by 43% over the past 21 years, and many of the remaining 62 wild lion populations are now precariously small. Yet it is also true that dedicated, determined conservation efforts really can make a difference. In certain parts of Africa, there have been encouraging successes in revitalizing populations, bringing these predators back to areas where they had long been absent. What is urgently needed is the restoration of natural landscapes and the creation of interconnected wildlife corridors, so that lions can regain the critical space they need to thrive. To see more of my work, follow me @beverlyjoubert.

Photo by @carltonward | Betty Osceola is a member of the Miccosukee Tribe of Indians of Florida, an airboat captain, and a powerful advocate for her Everglades home. As we mark Native American Heritage Month in November, I am grateful for her willingness to share her native lands with me and the world, including in her role as a lead character in the National Geographic film "Path of the Panther," now streaming on @disneyplus. The Seminole and Miccosukee are the last Native Americans living in Florida. 

Betty Osceola advocates for better and more equitable management of Everglades water. She is asking the Army Corps of Engineers to open all the floodgates along the Tamiami Trail—a 264-mile stretch of highway between Miami and Tampa—that are currently holding back water and drowning her ancestral lands. Roads, drainage canals, and development have been blocking and diverting the flow of Everglades water for the past century. The Tamiami Trail in particular has served as a dam blocking the water. South of the road, Everglades National Park has been deprived of water that once flowed seamlessly from the north, and north of the road, Miccosukee tribal lands have been drowning under too much water artificially held back by the road and by water management practices that have prioritized flood control for densely populated areas closer to the coast. During that time, 70 percent of the tree islands that Osceola and her people have historically relied upon and which have great cultural significance for the Miccosukee, have been lost. 

Through new Everglades restoration efforts, several miles of the Tamiami Trail have been elevated into bridges to help rebalance the flow of water. But more work is needed in the multiyear restoration plan, with continued investment from the U.S. and Florida governments, in order for water to flow more naturally and for the ecosystem to more fully recover. #NativeAmericanHeritageMonth

Learn more at the link in bio.

Around the world, rising waters, prolonged droughts, extreme weather, and higher temperatures could make regions unlivable. And yet some cities are set to emerge as havens from these extreme changes, and are proactively taking steps to prepare for the future.

Photograph by Andrew Moore, Nat Geo Image Collection

Known as the Cursed Amethyst, this jewel inspired the plot of Anthony Doerr’s bestselling novel, “All The Light We Cannot See.” But was the sapphire really cursed? That was the claim made by its former owner Edward Heron-Allen. In a letter entrusting the real-life gem to the Natural History Museum in London, the polymath and author called the stone “trebly accursed and stained with blood” and advised its future owners to cast it into the sea. Well, they didn’t—and to this day, the jewel retains a spooky reputation as a stone with the power to curse anyone who touches it. 

But is the “curse” real—or does it simply reveal a society grappling with guilt over its colonial past? Find out at the link in bio.

Photograph by The Natural History Museum, Alamy Stock Photo
Photo by @lynseyaddario | A pride of lions rests in the Masai Mara National Reserve in Kenya, November 17, 2023.

Photo by Karine Aigner @kaigner | The largest flying parrot in the world, the hyacinth macaw is found in three isolated places—central South America, Bolivia, and northern Paraguay—and measures three feet from the tip of its tail to the top of its head. These birds lay two to three eggs and can live up to 50 years in the wild, where they’re found at the edges of tropical woodlands and palm savannas. They form strong social bonds, and each and every one has its own individual personality traits. Comical and loud, they are the clowns of the forests; unfortunately, despite efforts to increase their numbers, the population is decreasing because of habitat destruction for hydroelectric dams and agriculture and the illegal pet trade.

Photo by @Justin.Jin | Baobabs can live for thousands of years. But they're critically threatened by climate change, habitat encroachment, and the loss of animal species that spread the trees' seeds. Several species of the baobab can only be found in Madagascar. I was there to shoot a story about conservation in the country, one of Earth’s most biodiverse regions, when I passed these majestic giants amid a setting sun. True to their reputation, they have impressively unusual branches, called “roots raised in the sky.” Just before the sun approached the horizon, I dived into a bush and shot this image. Follow @justin.jin for more stories and images from around the world.

Photo by @joelsartore | I am thrilled to introduce the 15,000th species to join the Photo Ark: the Miami tiger beetle. With its stunning, iridescent body, this tiny critter is as mighty as it is striking. The health of this species—a bioindicator—and its population can communicate vital information to researchers about the health of the pine rocklands ecosystem it belongs to, which is under threat from development pressure in southern Florida. 
Learn more about the Miami tiger beetle at the link in bio. To see more species featured in the Photo Ark, follow me, @joelsartore. #PhotoArk

Photo by @sofia_jaramillo5 | Clouds lift over Wyoming's Teton Range on a stormy day. For me, fall is a favorite time here, with brightly colored trees lighting up landscapes across the mountains and animals like elk migrating to their winter homes. For more images of the Tetons, follow @sofia_jaramillo5.

Inflammation diets have been trendy for a long time but new research is revealing exactly how your diet can affect the gut microbiome—and ultimately ward off chronic disease. Learn what foods you really need to eat to reduce inflammation at the link in bio.

Photograph by Maskot, Getty Images

Photo by Karine Aigner @kaigner | I was not there to photograph cats. I was lying out in the open—face down in the dirt, exposed to everything, fumbling around, and intently focused on, well, a bug. A wasp to be exact. And then there he was, as bobcats are, walking 10 feet to my right, with eyes on me. He knew I was there. He padded around, confident and sure. He stopped mere feet in front of me. The familiar tail switch, the look back, the pause—I knew what he was going to do. I looked down, changed some camera settings, and when I looked up again, this is what was in front of me. I had too much lens and no choices. He drank as the birds screamed, intruder! Then he got up, crossed to the bushes, turned back one last time. The tail twitched. He peed on the cactus, letting me know it was his, and then he was gone.

It never gets old. Never. Every individual is a different character, a different personality, a different cat.

Raise your hand if you’ll be seeking out auroras in 2024 ✋

Experts say we may see even more auroras this coming year in regions they’re not normally spotted. The sun is reaching the peak—called the “solar maximum”—of its roughly 11-year cycle in which solar activity will be greatest. Learn more at the link in bio.

Photograph by Ben Horton, Nat Geo Image Collection

Photo by Robbie Shone @shonephoto | Festive shoppers enjoy the Christmas markets in the Old Town of Innsbruck, Austria, set against the Alps. Next to the giant trimmed tree is the Golden Roof, a landmark structure built in 1500 for Emperor Maximilian I.

Photo by @lynseyaddario | Principal veterinary officer Michael Njoroge (at left) of the Masai Mara Mobile Veterinary Unit works with assistant veterinarian Felix Micheni to sedate and treat a wounded lion in the Masai Mara National Reserve in Kenya. The lion was in a fight with three other lions after he hunted buffalo in another pride's territory, which left him with injuries.

Photo by @macstonephoto | My first assignment for the magazine didn't start off well—I wasn't feeling well as I shot aerials out of a small plane over the Black River in North Carolina, and the next day we were grounded by dense fog. But on the third night, as my assistant, Zach Steinhauser, and I were making portraits of a bald cypress tree that took root in these sandy, tannic soils more than 2,600 years ago, I noticed streaking across the sky. It looked like a comet heading toward the moon. While screaming "What is that?!" I recomposed the frame and crossed my fingers. Completely bewildered and unsure of what we saw, we headed back to our tents to look up the news. Our minds were blown when we realized we had photographed the SpaceX Inspiration4, the first all-civilian flight into orbit—over one of the oldest cypress trees. As I always say, the swamp provides! For more, follow @macstonephoto.

Photo by Jennifer Hayes @jenniferhayesig | Dense coral gardens surround Kennedy Island in the Solomon Islands. In the early hours of August 2, 1945, Lieutenant John F. Kennedy and his crew were patrolling Blackett Strait when their boat, PT 109, was struck by the Japanese destroyer Amagiri. The attack ripped away part of PT 109, killing two crewmen but leaving enough floating wreckage for survivors to cling to throughout the moonless night. Kennedy, a powerful swimmer, led his men to cover on what was then known as Plum Pudding Island; they rested and hid there until their journey to Olasana Island and eventually their rescue, with the help of local coastwatchers. The island, since renamed to honor the young lieutenant who would later become a U.S. president, is visited by many. It is wonderful to see the corals expand and flourish around this small island steeped in World War II history. For more ocean stories, follow @jenniferhayesig.

Read more at the link in bio.

Interbreeding between animals of different lineages is widespread in nature. In the modern era of gene sequencing and genetic analysis, hybrid animals have new relevance and may hold clues that reveal some of the mysteries of evolution.

Photograph by @JoelSartore, National Geographic Photo Ark

Photo by @orsolyahaarberg | Old pine trees (Pinus sylvestris), a dead one and a living one, watching over the majestic Geirangerfjord in Norway. The sides of the fjord valley reach steep into the sea from the snow-covered mountaintops to the bare shoreline in winter. The Geirangerfjord, together with the Naerøyfjord, is the only natural site in Norway inscribed on the UNESCO World Heritage List. Please follow @orsolyahaarberg for more images from the Nordic countries.

During the past year, 165 photographers in the field returned with more than 2 million images. See our Pictures of the Year—a selection of our editors’ favorite images—at the link in bio. #NatGeoPOY23

Photograph by Alexander Semenov @narwhal_season

Photo by @joelsartore | Ever wonder how a lemur like this Von der Decken’s sifaka got its name? Local Malagasy people named it for its unique call, which echoes through Madagascar's forests and sounds like shif-auk. As herbivores, these primates spend their days foraging for flowers, leaves, fruit, and tree bark, and are known to consume nearly 100 plant species. They need the forest to survive, and the forests of Madagascar in turn depend on lemurs to help maintain the health and reproduction of many tree species. This is no easy feat. Forests within their range are already highly fragmented—cut down for charcoal production, then burned to provide pasture for livestock. Photo taken at Madagascar's Lemuria Land. To see more species featured in the Photo Ark follow me @joelsartore. #PhotoArk

Crowning a Granada hill, the Alhambra embodies the architectural golden age of Muslim rule on the Iberian Peninsula during the 14th century. We were given access to the remarkable fortress’s darkest recesses, where tourists aren’t allowed. Head to the link in bio to learn more about what we saw.

Photograph by José Manuel Navia

Photo by @nataliekeyssar | On a September afternoon in 2021, I observed pedestrians, commuters, vendors, students—and domino players—on the stretch of Roosevelt Avenue near Corona Plaza, in New York's Queens borough. 

Go to the link in bio for more on this street in one of the most diverse and vibrant communities in the world—where over 300 languages are spoken.

Read more at the link in bio.

Formed by megafloods, geologists were stumped by the strange landforms of eastern Washington State for decades. Then a high school teacher decided to investigate.
