Historical sources have overflowed with mentions of places like Tanis, Helike, and Roanoke, but archaeologists are still searching for their exact locations. The histories they’re piecing together are astonishing.

Photograph by Maria Maar, WestEnd 61, GMBH/ALAMY stock photo

Sky-watchers are in for a treat 🤩 2024 is filled with meteor showers, dazzling auroras, a total solar eclipse, comets, and more. Head to the link in bio to know which celestial marvels are worth circling on your calendar.

“Frozen shoulder” is a real condition causing stiffness and difficulty in raising the arm. It mostly affects women, striking peri- or post-menopausal women more commonly than anyone else. The painful affliction can last for years—but has long been ignored by medical researchers who doubted its existence. New treatments may finally promise a cure. Find out more at the link in bio.

Photograph by K H Fung, Science Photo Library

Sleep-deprived human parents know the value of a quick nap—but it turns out chinstrap penguins have us beat. When nesting, these Antarctic birds take four-second-long “microsleeps.” 😴

The hours of total sleep they rack up in a day may surprise you. Any guesses? Comment below and find the answer at the link in bio.

Photograph by @joelsartore

Photo by @lynseyaddario | The two surviving cheetahs from the Tano Bora coalition are spotted in Kenya's Masai Mara National Reserve. They belonged to what was once a coalition of five brothers. That number is rare; usually only one or two cheetah cubs survive their first year due to predators like lions.

Space-time breakthroughs. Virgin crocodile births. A promising candidate for alien life. Science offered a variety of fascinating discoveries in 2023. See our top picks at the link in bio.

Photograph by Kevin Langergraber, Arizona State University

Raccoons are cute, but feeding them is not 😬 

You may have seen viral videos of people feeding wild raccoons everything from marshmallows to hotdogs. While it may seem helpful, feeding wild raccoons may be ensuring their untimely deaths, experts say. Learn more at the link in bio.

Photograph by Corey Arnold @arni_coraldo

Photo by @joelsartore | Kagus like this duo are rare, flightless birds that call the forests of New Caledonia, a French overseas territory in the southwestern Pacific, home. Those wings may seem oversized for a bird that doesn’t fly, but they serve an important role. When a potential predator is nearby, parents will flap their fully opened wings on the ground, as if injured, to turn attention away from their chick. To see more species featured in the Photo Ark, follow me @joelsartore. #PhotoArk

From gene therapy to Alzheimer’s treatment, predicting pancreatic cancer to pioneering reproduction methods, there were many promising discoveries in 2023 that will influence health and medicine. Learn more at the link in bio.

Illustration by Michael Winding et al., 2023

Photo by @amivitale | In 2017 a tiny five-month-old elephant named Nadasoit captured hearts at Kenya's Reteti Elephant Sanctuary. Rescued from a hand-dug well at the tender age of two weeks, she was airlifted to Reteti due to pneumonia. Under the nurturing care of Shaba, a surrogate matriarch and fellow orphan, Nadasoit found a protector and mentor. Over time, she absorbed Shaba's wisdom, displaying remarkable traits and a nurturing spirit. Nadasoit formed a deep bond with another orphan, Loisaba, and their playful antics and intertwining trunks showcased their affection for each other. After three years of devoted care at Reteti, Nadasoit, Loisaba, and another orphan named Bawa were successfully reintroduced to the wild. Follow @amivitale for updates on the sanctuary.

A lost Maya city. A submerged temple in Italy. Remarkably well-preserved swords in a cave by the Dead Sea. Learn more about these and other 2023 discoveries that changed our perspective on history at the link in bio.

Photography Courtesy Ministero Della Cultura

Photo by @beverlyjoubert | A moment of affection in the heart of Botswana’s Okavango Delta captures the essence of the vital social bonds among male lions. From hunting success to territorial defense, these alliances are crucial to survival in the challenging, competitive, and often brutal world of these big cats. It takes time and many shared trials for these bonds to develop, which makes moments like this one more important than they might seem. Grooming rituals, mutual care, and shared affection form the very fabric of the ties that bind. To see more of my work, follow me @beverlyjoubert.

Learn more at the link in bio.

Less than a decade ago, more than half of the world’s saiga antelope were lost to a mysterious disease. But today, scientists are rejoicing at the saiga’s unlikely rebound and phenomenal conservation success.

Photograph By Valeriy Maleev/ Nature Picture Library

Orcas sank yachts, javelinas destroyed golf courses, and one feisty sea otter stole surfboards. This year, the internet cheered for animals that seemed to rebel against humans—telling the story of a unique cultural moment. Read more at the link in bio. 

Photograph by @brianskerry

Photo by Karine Aigner @kaigner | Sometimes, it’s not your best shot. The boat is writhing, the subject is on the move. But then right before your eyes, among the hyacinth leaves, the water explodes in a fury, followed by silence. A massive head rises out of the green. It looks out at its audience as if to say, Was the performance satisfactory? The audience of floating humans erupts in audible applause—sharing what we know was a moment of privilege awarded by the wild.

Photo by @joelsartore | The mohol bush baby is a tiny, nocturnal primate from southern Africa. Most often found occupying wooded areas, family groups of two to seven bush babies will frequently spend the day nestled together in a tree hollow, but will split up at night to look for food. When apart from one another, bush babies communicate with loud sounds—an alarm call can result in several individuals ganging up on a potential predator. Photo taken at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo. To see more species featured in the Photo Ark follow me @joelsartore. #PhotoArk

Photo by @sofia_jaramillo5 | Athlete Charlie Hagen takes in the sunset during a bikepacking trip near Wyoming's Yellowstone National Park. One study showed that spending 120 minutes a week in nature is the threshold associated with health benefits and well-being. For more adventure images from around the world, follow @sofia_jaramillo5.

Chicken soup. Green smoothie. Steaming hot tea. When you’re sick everyone from grandma to the next-door neighbor has a suggestion for what foods will help you recover. What should we make of this wisdom—do some foods really help us feel better, or even actually get better? Learn more at the link in bio.

Photograph by Natasha Breen, REDA&CO/Getty Images

Photo by Mattias Klum @mattiasklumofficial | A red-billed oxpecker looks for parasites on an impala in Nyerere National Park, Tanzania. These birds can eat hundreds of ticks a day. Although they rid animals of pests, oxpeckers are considered parasites themselves, as their preferred food is blood. While they search for bloated ticks, they also feed on blood directly, pecking at an animal’s wounds to keep them open. Follow @mattiasklumofficial to see more images of wildlife.

At the start of every new year, millions of people across the world give up alcohol for a month. But can your body really change in that time? Experts say yes. Learn more about what benefits you can expect at the link in bio.

Photograph by Victoria Jones, PA Images/Getty Images

Photo by @heidihanskoch | The rump of a brown kiwi looks like the fruit that bears its name. Wispy feathers—much like human hair—don’t support flight but they do help the bird blend in with the undergrowth of the New Zealand forests where it lives.

We got an offer to photograph two private feather collections and those of the National History Museum in Berlin. Feathers are encounters with the irresistibly beautiful in nature. We wanted to present them as a sensual experience, as poetic masterpieces of evolution. 

For this project, we used the method of focus stacking, in which similar photos with different focal planes are blended to achieve a more profound depth of field. Gradually our engagement with nature and technology developed into a kind of meditation. In the end, it took us more than two years.

Photo by @orsolyahaarberg | The islands of the Norwegian Helgeland archipelago are seldom covered by snow near sea level. With coastal Norway warmed by the North Atlantic Current, they have relatively mild winters. But I happened to be on Dønna Island right after a snowstorm. Look closely between the trees and the mountains for a white church that suddenly emerges from this wintry scene. Follow me @orsolyahaarberg for more images from the Nordic countries.

Days after a major earthquake shook the West Coast of Japan, a difficult search for survivors is still underway. The magnitude-7.6 earthquake off the coast of the Noto Peninsula produced the strongest shaking the region had experienced in decades. But experts believe the intensity and offshore location of this earthquake could have produced significantly more devastation had the nation been less prepared. Learn more about how Japan spent decades making itself earthquake resilient at the link in bio.

A viral video of a turtle with a plastic straw lodged in its nose sparked outcry and a movement to ban plastic straws in the 2010s. Soon, going plastic free was simultaneously a trendy aesthetic, a marketing tagline for businesses, and a political movement. But has it made a difference for the environment? Learn more at the link in bio.

Photograph by @beckythale

Photo by @joelsartore | In the wild, gray gibbons call the rainforests on the island of Borneo home. They are exclusively arboreal, meaning they spend almost all of their time in the trees, trying to never let their feet touch the ground. While this might seem impossible, it is actually quite easy for gibbons thanks to their extra-long arms! This species uses those lanky forelimbs for brachiation, a form of movement in which primates swing from tree limb to tree limb using only their arms. Without forests full of tall trees in close proximity to one another, gibbons are unable to move within their home range, meaning they struggle to find the food and shelter they need to survive. Photo taken at Miller Park Zoo. To see more species featured in the Photo Ark follow me @joelsartore. #PhotoArk

A bonobo named Louise was separated from her sister, Loretta, for 26 years—and yet, she still remembers her. Read more about the longest-lasting nonhuman social memory ever documented at the link in bio.

Photograph by Christian Ziegler

On Wednesdays—and every day—flamingos are pink 💗 But have you ever wondered why they’re pink? It’s all in their diet! Shrimplike crustaceans are responsible for the flamingos’ recognizable color, and without them, the birds will pale. Learn more fun flamingo facts at the link in bio.

Photograph by Sam Abell

As mocktails and other nonalcoholic beverages increase in popularity, experts are investigating their role in helping people reduce their alcohol consumption. Find out more at the link in bio.

Photograph by Krista Schlueter, The New York Times/Redux

The climate shadow concept is emerging to replace the carbon footprint—which critics say is at best, time-consuming and at worst, meaningless. Rather than measuring what you eat or how you commute, the climate shadow encompasses all your life choices—the larger the shadow, the greater an individual’s positive impact on the planet. Read more at the link in bio.

Science fiction often exaggerates or distorts science for dramatic effect—but many movies and TV shows have a nugget of realism at their core. Learn what scientists have to say about your favorite at the link in bio. 

Photograph by Giulio Di Sturco, contrasto/Redux

Photo by Javier Aznar @javier_aznar_photography | A shield mantis (Choeradodis rhombicollis) stays in ambush pose over a leaf in Canandé, a forest in Ecuador protected by the nonprofit Fundación de Conservación Jocotoco. With a flat body that looks like a leaf, this formidable hunter waits, camouflaged among foliage of the same color, to launch a mortal attack on its prey.

Stream #ARealBugsLife coming January 24 on @disneyplus to learn more about interesting insects!

Photo by @sofia_jaramillo5 | Two skiers cross Jackson Lake at sunrise in Wyoming's Grand Teton National Park. The high-altitude lake freezes over in winter, providing backcountry access to the northern part of the national park. For skiers and snowboarders climbing and descending iconic routes like Mount Moran, the adventure often starts at Jackson Lake. For more images, follow me @sofia_jaramillo5.

On March 26, 1964, Martin Luther King, Jr. and Malcolm X met for the first and only time. They had both come to the U.S. Senate for the outcome of the vote on the Civil Rights Act. The men were two of the most influential Black activists of the 20th century—and had long been pitted against each other in the media. Within four years, both men would be assassinated. This iconic photograph captured a moment a long time in the making.

The two civil rights leaders came together at the end of their lives. What might have happened had they met earlier? Read more at the link in bio.

Photo by @beverlyjoubert | The intensity. The razor focus. The muscles honed to perfection. It takes physical power, tenacity, and great skill to execute a successful hunt in the swamps of Botswana’s famed Okavango Delta. It's not surprising that the demands—and the bountiful offerings—of this unique environment shape lions that are among the largest and strongest on Earth. The delta also represents one of the last strongholds for an apex predator that increasingly finds itself hemmed by encroaching human activity and diminishing habitat. Lions are now confined to a mere 8% of their historic range. If we want to secure their future, we must protect the fragile wildernesses that still sustain them. To see more of my work, follow me @beverlyjoubert.

Photo by @paoloverzone | I photographed this mummy, KV21B, while it was being transported from a storage room at the Egyptian Museum in Cairo for DNA sampling and a CT scan to determine its family tree. The mummy was found in the KV21 tomb in Egypt’s Valley of the Kings, which was discovered by the Italian explorer Giovanni Battista Belzoni in 1817 and later re-excavated by the American archaeologist Donald P. Ryan in the 1980s. The tomb contained another mummy, KV21A, and both are believed to be 18th dynasty queens. Follow @paoloverzone for more images and stories.

Photo by @mattiasklumofficial | I photographed this Patagonian fox (also called the South American gray fox) in Torres del Paine National Park, Chile, during a @natgeo assignment. This particular individual was a good model: beautiful, easily habituated, and curious. Torres del Paine is stunning and has become one of my favorite parks in South America.

Follow @mattiasklumofficial for more images and films from my projects around the world.

Photo by @chrisburkard | Within the shadow of the sentinels in Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks, an entire ecosystem flourishes on the tree trunks and the forest floor. The sequoias themselves are remarkably resilient, adapted to endure fires that periodically sweep through the Sierra Nevada, relying on their thick, fire-resistant bark for protection. These ancient trees, reaching for the heavens, bear witness to hundreds of years of change and history in the area and are now safely conserved in the national parks. This image was captured while I was on an assignment in the fall of 2023 for Nat Geo.

Though cats use the same five senses as humans, some of theirs are more specialized and more precise, allowing them to view the world differently. Understanding how they use them could help us live more harmoniously with our furry friends. Learn more at the link in bio.

Photograph by Seth Casteel, National Geographic Creative Images

North America’s next solar eclipse is coming April 8, 2024—and won’t occur in the continental U.S. again until 2044. Whether you want to camp out under the stars or party with thousands of other eclipse chasers, head to the link in bio to know where and how to see April’s rare sky show.

Photograph by Natalie Behring, Getty Images

Photo by @amivitale | Ever wonder why elephants don't jump? It's all in their skeletal structure. If you examine their feet, you'll notice the bones point straight down, meaning they're essentially standing on their tiptoes. This design supports their immense weight but lacks the flexibility needed for jumping. These unique toes belong to an orphaned elephant residing in northern Kenya at Reteti Elephant Sanctuary, the first community-owned elephant sanctuary in Africa.

Advances in immunology are lending new insights into how we can allow good inflammation to proceed while squashing the bad that can come from too much of it. For now, there are simple steps people can take to address inflammaging in their own bodies, experts say, including exercise. Learn more at the link in bio.

Photograph by ZEPHYR, Science Source

Photo by Karine Aigner @kaigner | The hyena’s joke really was that funny … 
But if you want to be scientific, this is flehmen, a mammalian behavior. An animal (a horse or cat, for example) opens its mouth with the upper lip curled to increase access of the vomeronasal organ (or Jacobson’s organ) to a scent or pheromone. Animals do this to process info from other scents. You'll see this when lions and all kinds of cats are smelling something in the air they find intriguing or delectable, like the scent of a female.

Or perhaps they really are just laughing—at the fact that there are about 30 hyenas surrounding them and waiting for the exact moment the pride takes leave of the buffalo carcass it has been snacking on for hours. All joking aside.

In 2007, there remained only about 720 mountain gorillas worldwide when seven were found murdered in the Democratic Republic of the Congo’s Virunga National Park. @brentstirton's photographs of the slain gorillas—a casualty of the region’s illegal charcoal trade—ignited global outrage. Today, these gorillas remain endangered by habitat loss and climate change.

Our photo editors selected one image from each year of this century that capture some of this era’s most important stories. See them all at the link in bio.

The Nat Geo documentary film “Bobi Wine: The People’s President” about musician-turned-presidential candidate Bobi Wine, has been nominated for an Academy Award, a move that may broaden the spotlight on his pro-democracy movement.

Learn more about the pop star’s daring presidential run against Uganda’s longtime dictator—and his continued pressure for democracy in his homeland at the link in bio. Stream #BobiWineThePeoplesPresident on @disneyplus and @hulu.

Photograph by Isaac Kasamani, AFP/Getty Image

Scientists have cleared a significant hurdle in the years-long effort to save Africa’s northern white rhinoceros from extinction with the first-ever rhino pregnancy using in vitro fertilization. The lab-assisted pregnancy involved implanting a southern white rhino embryo in a surrogate mother named Curra.

The surrogate mother died three months into her 16-month pregnancy from an unrelated bacterial infection, but the successful embryo transfer and early stages of pregnancy pave the way for next applying the technique to the critically endangered northern white rhino. Learn more at the link in bio.

Photograph by @amivitale

Photo by @javier_aznar_photography | Under strong noon light in the Galápagos Islands, ruddy turnstones steal food from an American oystercatcher. Follow @javier_aznar_photography for more images from the Galápagos Islands.

Have a hard time waking up? We spoke to experts about how to deal with morning grogginess. See what scientists say are ways to develop a better relationship with your alarm clock at the link in bio.

Photograph by @andy_mann

Photo by @acacia.johnson | Would you guess that this photo was taken in Antarctica? This historic hut, built by the Swedish South Polar Expedition led by Otto Nordenskjöld in 1902, stands on the shore of Snow Hill Island in Antarctica's Weddell Sea. Here, six members of the expedition spent 22 months studying the region's geology, geography, meteorology, and more. 

For those who sailed through ice-filled seas to reach this remote spot, spotting emperor penguins along the way, it was surreal to discover this desertlike landscape free of snow. What's more, the soft shale of the island preserves fossils of ancient marine animals between 65 million and 145 million years old—a reminder of Antarctica's deep geological history. 

Follow me at @acacia.johnson for more stories from Antarctica and beyond.

Bans on bear selfies. Prohibitions on pet store sales. Finding forever homes for some research animals. See the U.S. state laws that are slated to improve animal welfare in the year ahead at the link in bio.

Photograph by Alycee Byrd, The New York Times/Redux

Photo by @joelsartore | This adorable amphibian is a Malaysian golden gliding tree frog. Found across Southeast Asia, it resides in a variety of areas including cities and other built-up environments. It breeds in stagnant pools and roadside puddles, where its hungry tadpoles can devour decayed plants, invertebrates, and sometimes even one another. To see more species featured in the Photo Ark, follow me @joelsartore.

… you’re humming the song now aren’t you? 😅 Rasputin’s violent 1916 assassination is the stuff of legend—leaving historians to piece together what is fact and what is fiction. Learn more at the link in bio.

Photograph by Mary Evans/Fotostock

When planning trips to national parks and protected areas across the United States, you hope to see the wolves of Yellowstone or the alligators of the Everglades. But talk to any bug scientist, and they’ll tell you that the best things come in small packages.
From smiley spiders in Hawaiʻi to water-repelling flies in Utah, these incredible insects are worth the trip. Head to the link in bio for where to see these captivating critters.

Photograph By John Abbott/Nature Picture Library

Photo by @dina_litovsky | A young woman takes off her high-heeled shoes at the end of a debutante ball in New York City. These balls are a curious coming-of-age ritual for New York and international high society, a vestige of a bygone era. The debutantes, women between 18 and 25, have to apply and are chosen based on their education, accomplishments, and background. My work explores such rituals and rites of passage of different layers of society. To see more, follow me @dina_litovsky.
Where do you want to go in 2024? Nat Geo's #BestOfTheWorld 2024 picks are here and feature iconic places and experiences for your next adventure. See the full list at the link in bio.

Have you seen mushroom-based products popping up seemingly everywhere? From powdered coffee alternatives to bottled tinctures, some promise everything from mental clarity and anti-aging to immune support and tumor suppression. But questions remain as to the actual health benefits of these so-called superfoods. Head to the link in bio to learn more.

Photograph by Phyllis Ma

Photo by @joelsartore | Meet Trompie, a 5-month-old northern tamandua in Costa Rica's Las Pumas Rescue Center and Sanctuary. Strange looks work to this species' advantage in its forest-and-scrub habitat, where it spends most of the day sleeping in trees, then venturing onto the ground at night in search of food. Tamanduas have a long, prehensile (grasping) tail that can be used as an extra hand or foot while climbing trees, and a specialized mouth and tongue allow these guys to consume up to 9,000 ants a day. The purpose of that thick, kinky hair? To protect tamanduas from being bitten by angry ants as they dine! To see more species featured in the Photo Ark, follow me, @joelsartore. 
#PhotoArk

Photo by @beverlyjoubert | Cats being cats … it’s a tale as old as time. The inherent playfulness, mischief, and exploratory instinct are all a vital part of a young predator’s education. Pouncing, stalking, mock battles, and boisterous play are not just entertainment for a growing cub with energy reserves aplenty. They’re fundamental to honing the physical abilities, coordination, and strategy skills that make lions such formidable hunters. The mother of these cubs in Kenya’s Masai Mara National Reserve displayed remarkable patience with her offspring's antics, even when her tail became the target. To see more of my work, follow me @beverlyjoubert.

🕷️ Spiders aren’t attracted to your body lotion. They don’t crawl in your mouth at night. In fact, they want nothing to do with you. Despite their bad rap (mostly perpetuated by these types of myths), spiders are responsible for keeping hundreds of thousands of insects and agricultural pests in check. Learn more about the truth behind these common myths at the link in bio.

Photograph By Isabelle Betancourt

Whether your next big trip involves a first-class ticket or a full tank of gas, Nat Geo’s Gear of the Year list from our #BestOfTheWorld 2024 guide features 18 expert-approved innovative products every traveler will want to pack.

Photograph by @beckythale and @thiessenphoto

Photo by Keith Ladzinski @ladzinski | One of the greatest gifts an ecosystem can receive is rain, and in a place like the Kalahari, which receives an average of five to 10 inches a year, it’s essential for life. This photo was a collision of serendipity: witnessing this beautiful Kalahari lion under colorful, lightning-filled skies at sunset.

Presented by @Rolex | Nat Geo Explorer and marine biologist Fernando Trujillo holds the snout of an Amazon river dolphin while his team measures and examines the animal before returning it to the water. Freshwater dolphins face an uncertain future as their waterways heat up—but Trujillo has made it his life’s work to advocate for the Amazon’s “pink ambassadors.” Learn more at the link in bio. | This expedition was supported by @Rolex and its Perpetual Planet Initiative, which is partnering with the National Geographic Society on science-based expeditions to explore and document change, and devise solutions, in the planet’s most unique regions. #PerpetualPlanet

Photo by @thomaspeschak

ADHD diagnoses are climbing among adult women. Experts say it’s likely not a wave of misdiagnoses—but a sign that medicine is finally catching up to reality. The overwhelming majority of research on ADHD has been done in boys and men, but symptoms often present differently for girls and women, causing many to go untreated. Head to the link in bio to learn more about the gender gap in ADHD diagnoses.

Photograph by Maskot, Getty Images

Photo by @mattiasklumofficial | Landmannalaugar’s otherworldly volcanic landscape is seen in an afternoon light from a helicopter. This region consists of more geological elements than one can count. It’s one of my favorite spots in Iceland and a creative haven for any visual work. To explore more of my work from Iceland and around the world, please visit @mattiasklumofficial.

We’re back bigger and better for a new season of Limitless! I’m teaming up with National Geographic, @darrenaronofsky, and world-class experts for a new series of epic challenges to explore how we can all live not just longer, but better.

Photo by @katieorlinsky | Caribou approach Arctic Village (Vashraii K’oo), Alaska, during their spring migration, when thousands of Arctic caribou from the Porcupine herd can be found moving near and through the community. The Neets’aii Gwich’in of Arctic Village lead a subsistence-based lifestyle that largely depends on caribou. The town is just south of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, and community members have been vocal opponents of drilling in the refuge, particularly in the coastal plain, the birthing grounds for the Porcupine herd. Read more about caribou at the link in bio.

Few have seen inside Wilson’s facility where dozens of expert craftspeople meticulously put together a product whose design hasn’t changed for about a century. Head to the link in bio to see more behind-the-scenes photos and learn how NFL footballs are made.

Photo by @christopherpaynephoto

Photo by Tristan Spinski @tspinski | A dappling of spotted salamander eggs, some infused with the algae that will help sustain them as they hatch, floats near the surface of a vernal pool in Maine. Fed by rainwater, seasonal, pop-up ponds are vital to the forest ecosystem. Learn more about what thrives in these woodland pools at the link in bio.

There’s no one-size-fits-all solution for mental health, but there are some simple steps you can take that can be put into practice immediately. Over the years, we’ve reported on self-care tips that are backed by science and fairly easy to access—like getting outside and decluttering your space. Head to the link in bio for the full list.

Photograph by @zachkrahmer
Photo by @lynseyaddario | A pride of lions rests in Kenya's Masai Mara National Reserve.

Photo by @orsolyahaarberg | After a long period of cold but fair weather, the arrival of a low-pressure system was accompanied by strong winds in Sweden's Stora Sjofallet National Park. The centuries-old Scotch pines, which had been groaning under the ever increasing burden of snow for weeks, had to withstand gales that stripped them of their thick ice shields in seconds. Follow @orsolyahaarberg for more images from the Nordic countries.

Love is a biological necessity. But it’s the brain and not the heart that gives you the courage to pursue an attraction, love a partner, and form new social bonds when love ends. Learn more about the science of love at the link in bio. ❤️ 

Photograph by Matthieu Paley @paleyphoto

Photo by @simonnorfolkstudio | A heart in nature is seen at the Kronotsky Nature Reserve, a biosphere in the far east of Russia, on the coast of the Kamchatka Peninsula. Now a World Heritage site, it was established in 1934 and covers more than 4,000 square miles (over 10,000 square kilometers). Kronotsky holds Russia's only geyser basin, in addition to mountain ranges with active and extinct volcanoes. The reserve, subject to bitter winters, is accessible only to scientists and a limited number of tourists. #ValentinesDay

Photo by Javier Aznar @javier_aznar_photography | In Ecuador's Chocó forest, a gliding tree frog (Agalychnis spurrelli) clings to a plant in the Canandé Reserve, a wildlife refuge protected by the nonprofit Fundación Jocotoco. Follow @javier_aznar_photography to learn more about the animals of the Chocó.

What do orcas, bonobos, and leaf-cutter ants have in common? They all look to females of the species to ensure they survive and thrive. Numerous species rely on strong female leaders that teach survival skills, resolve conflicts, even sacrifice their bodies for the good of the group. 

Learn more at the link in bio.

Photograph by Vinícius Rodrigues de Souza / Getty

Photo by Prasenjeet Yadav @prasen.yadav | Snow leopards evolved to live on high-elevation deserts and cliffs, and every part of their body shows signs of this adaptation, including the long, thick, furry tail. I was lucky enough to see a snow leopard chase an ibex on a cliff, and that's when I witnessed how essential—and incredible—their tails are. Snow leopards have the longest tails, proportionally, of the big cats—nearly as long as the rest of their body. The tail can be up to a yard (a meter) in length, and it helps the animal balance on steep, rocky slopes. The tail also protects against the cold, as the leopard can wrap it around its nose and legs while resting. Snow leopards patrol their territory, and one of the ways they mark their land is by spraying urine and scent on stones. In this image, a snow leopard approaches a scent-marking location in India's Spiti Valley, in the northern state of Himachal Pradesh, triggering the camera trap. Follow me @prasen.yadav for more photos from the biodiverse states of India.

Photo by @joelsartore | Einstein is a western long-tailed hornbill I photographed at the North Florida Wildlife Center. In the wild, this species is found in the humid forests of West Africa, where it spends most of its time high up in the trees. Named for their large, curved beaks, most hornbills sport a casque, a hollow structure made of keratin. Casques come in a variety of sizes and colors and serve a number of functions such as attracting a mate and resonating sound to help defend territory. To see more species featured in the Photo Ark, follow me @joelsartore. #PhotoArk

Experiencing the Northern Lights in all their majesty is a dream for most travelers. And with 2024 expected to bring some of the brightest Northern Lights displays in over 20 years, there’s never been a better time to try to capture them. We asked a professional travel photographer for their top tips on where, when, and how to capture them. Head to the link in bio to read more.

Photograph by @nori.jemil.travel

It’s been 18 years since Pluto’s celestial status was called into question. Ever since, the worlds of science and pop culture have debated Pluto’s fate. We asked experts from both sides to make their case. Read the full conversation at the link in bio.

Photograph by NASA/Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory/Southwest Research Institute
